   518→while true
   519→    # Pick the ID based on the iteration: the first time we want to
   520→    # read our pending messages, in case we crashed and are recovering.
   521→    # Once we consumed our history, we can start getting new messages.
   522→    if check_backlog
   523→        myid = $lastid
   524→    else
   525→        myid = '>'
   526→    end
   527→
   528→    items = r.xreadgroup('GROUP',GroupName,ConsumerName,'BLOCK','2000','COUNT','10','STREAMS',:my_stream_key,myid)
   529→
   530→    if items == nil
   531→        puts "Timeout!"
   532→        next
   533→    end
   534→
   535→    # If we receive an empty reply, it means we were consuming our history
   536→    # and that the history is now empty. Let's start to consume new messages.
   537→    check_backlog = false if items[0][1].length == 0
   538→
   539→    items[0][1].each{|i|
   540→        id,fields = i
   541→
   542→        # Process the message
   543→        process_message(id,fields)
   544→
   545→        # Acknowledge the message as processed
   546→        r.xack(:my_stream_key,GroupName,id)
   547→
   548→        $lastid = id
   549→    }
   550→end
   551→```
   552→
   553→As you can see the idea here is to start by consuming the history, that is, our list of pending messages. This is useful because the consumer may have crashed before, so in the event of a restart we want to re-read messages that were delivered to us without getting acknowledged. Note that we might process a message multiple times or one time (at least in the case of consumer failures, but there are also the limits of Redis persistence and replication involved, see the specific section about this topic).
   554→
   555→Once the history was consumed, and we get an empty list of messages, we can switch to using the `>` special ID in order to consume new messages.
   556→
   557→## Recovering from permanent failures
   558→
   559→The example above allows us to write consumers that participate in the same consumer group, each taking a subset of messages to process, and when recovering from failures re-reading the pending messages that were delivered just to them. However in the real world consumers may permanently fail and never recover. What happens to the pending messages of the consumer that never recovers after stopping for any reason?
   560→
   561→Redis consumer groups offer a feature that is used in these situations in order to *claim* the pending messages of a given consumer so that such messages will change ownership and will be re-assigned to a different consumer. The feature is very explicit. A consumer has to inspect the list of pending messages, and will have to claim specific messages using a special command, otherwise the server will leave the messages pending forever and assigned to the old consumer. In this way different applications can choose if to use such a feature or not, and exactly how to use it.
   562→
   563→The first step of this process is just a command that provides observability of pending entries in the consumer group and is called [`XPENDING`]({{< relref "/commands/xpending" >}}).
   564→This is a read-only command which is always safe to call and will not change ownership of any message.
   565→In its simplest form, the command is called with two arguments, which are the name of the stream and the name of the consumer group.
   566→
   567→{{< clients-example set="stream_tutorial" step="xpending" description="View pending message summary for a consumer group using XPENDING to monitor unacknowledged messages" difficulty="intermediate" >}}
   568→> XPENDING race:italy italy_riders
   569→1) (integer) 2
   570→2) "1692632647899-0"
   571→3) "1692632662819-0"
   572→4) 1) 1) "Bob"
   573→      2) "2"
   574→{{< /clients-example >}}
   575→
   576→When called in this way, the command outputs the total number of pending messages in the consumer group (two in this case), the lower and higher message ID among the pending messages, and finally a list of consumers and the number of pending messages they have.
   577→We have only Bob with two pending messages because the single message that Alice requested was acknowledged using [`XACK`]({{< relref "/commands/xack" >}}).
   578→
   579→We can ask for more information by giving more arguments to [`XPENDING`]({{< relref "/commands/xpending" >}}), because the full command signature is the following:
   580→
   581→```
   582→XPENDING <key> <groupname> [[IDLE <min-idle-time>] <start-id> <end-id> <count> [<consumer-name>]]
   583→```
   584→
   585→By providing a start and end ID (that can be just `-` and `+` as in [`XRANGE`]({{< relref "/commands/xrange" >}})) and a count to control the amount of information returned by the command, we are able to know more about the pending messages. The optional final argument, the consumer name, is used if we want to limit the output to just messages pending for a given consumer, but won't use this feature in the following example.
   586→
   587→{{< clients-example set="stream_tutorial" step="xpending_plus_minus" description="Get detailed pending message information including idle time and delivery count using XPENDING with range" difficulty="advanced" >}}
   588→> XPENDING race:italy italy_riders - + 10
   589→1) 1) "1692632647899-0"
   590→   2) "Bob"
   591→   3) (integer) 74642
   592→   4) (integer) 1
   593→2) 1) "1692632662819-0"
   594→   2) "Bob"
   595→   3) (integer) 74642
   596→   4) (integer) 1
   597→{{< /clients-example >}}
   598→
   599→Now we have the details for each message: the ID, the consumer name, the *idle time* in milliseconds, which is how many milliseconds have passed since the last time the message was delivered to some consumer, and finally the number of times that a given message was delivered.
   600→We have two messages from Bob, and they are idle for 60000+ milliseconds, about a minute.
   601→
   602→Note that nobody prevents us from checking what the first message content was by just using [`XRANGE`]({{< relref "/commands/xrange" >}}).
   603→
   604→{{< clients-example set="stream_tutorial" step="xrange_pending" description="Retrieve the content of pending messages using XRANGE to inspect what needs to be processed" difficulty="intermediate" >}}
   605→> XRANGE race:italy 1692632647899-0 1692632647899-0
   606→1) 1) "1692632647899-0"
   607→   2) 1) "rider"
   608→      2) "Royce"
   609→{{< /clients-example >}}
   610→
   611→We have just to repeat the same ID twice in the arguments. Now that we have some ideas, Alice may decide that after 1 minute of not processing messages, Bob will probably not recover quickly, and it's time to *claim* such messages and resume the processing in place of Bob. To do so, we use the [`XCLAIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xclaim" >}}) command.
   612→
   613→This command is very complex and full of options in its full form, since it is used for replication of consumer groups changes, but we'll use just the arguments that we need normally. In this case it is as simple as:
   614→
   615→```
   616→XCLAIM <key> <group> <consumer> <min-idle-time> <ID-1> <ID-2> ... <ID-N>
   617→```
   618→
   619→Basically we say, for this specific key and group, I want that the message IDs specified will change ownership, and will be assigned to the specified consumer name `<consumer>`. However, we also provide a minimum idle time, so that the operation will only work if the idle time of the mentioned messages is greater than the specified idle time. This is useful because maybe two clients are retrying to claim a message at the same time:
   620→
   621→```
   622→Client 1: XCLAIM race:italy italy_riders Alice 60000 1692632647899-0
   623→Client 2: XCLAIM race:italy italy_riders Lora 60000 1692632647899-0
   624→```
   625→
   626→However, as a side effect, claiming a message will reset its idle time and will increment its number of deliveries counter, so the second client will fail claiming it. In this way we avoid trivial re-processing of messages (even if in the general case you cannot obtain exactly once processing).
   627→
   628→This is the result of the command execution:
   629→
   630→{{< clients-example set="stream_tutorial" step="xclaim" description="Claim pending messages from another consumer using XCLAIM when a consumer fails to process messages" difficulty="advanced" >}}
   631→> XCLAIM race:italy italy_riders Alice 60000 1692632647899-0
   632→1) 1) "1692632647899-0"
   633→   2) 1) "rider"
   634→      2) "Royce"
   635→{{< /clients-example >}}
   636→
   637→The message was successfully claimed by Alice, who can now process the message and acknowledge it, and move things forward even if the original consumer is not recovering.
   638→
   639→It is clear from the example above that as a side effect of successfully claiming a given message, the [`XCLAIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xclaim" >}}) command also returns it. However this is not mandatory. The **JUSTID** option can be used in order to return just the IDs of the message successfully claimed. This is useful if you want to reduce the bandwidth used between the client and the server (and also the performance of the command) and you are not interested in the message because your consumer is implemented in a way that it will rescan the history of pending messages from time to time.
   640→
   641→Claiming may also be implemented by a separate process: one that just checks the list of pending messages, and assigns idle messages to consumers that appear to be active. Active consumers can be obtained using one of the observability features of Redis streams. This is the topic of the next section.
   642→
   643→## Automatic claiming
   644→
   645→The [`XAUTOCLAIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xautoclaim" >}}) command, added in Redis 6.2, implements the claiming process that we've described above.
   646→[`XPENDING`]({{< relref "/commands/xpending" >}}) and [`XCLAIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xclaim" >}}) provide the basic building blocks for different types of recovery mechanisms.
   647→This command optimizes the generic process by having Redis manage it and offers a simple solution for most recovery needs.
   648→
   649→[`XAUTOCLAIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xautoclaim" >}}) identifies idle pending messages and transfers ownership of them to a consumer.
   650→The command's signature looks like this:
   651→
   652→```
   653→XAUTOCLAIM <key> <group> <consumer> <min-idle-time> <start> [COUNT count] [JUSTID]
   654→```
   655→
   656→So, in the example above, I could have used automatic claiming to claim a single message like this:
   657→
   658→{{< clients-example set="stream_tutorial" step="xautoclaim" description="Practical pattern: Automatically claim idle pending messages using XAUTOCLAIM for simplified consumer failure recovery" difficulty="advanced" >}}
   659→> XAUTOCLAIM race:italy italy_riders Alice 60000 0-0 COUNT 1
   660→1) "0-0"
   661→2) 1) 1) "1692632662819-0"
   662→      2) 1) "rider"
   663→         2) "Sam-Bodden"
   664→{{< /clients-example >}}
   665→
   666→Like [`XCLAIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xclaim" >}}), the command replies with an array of the claimed messages, but it also returns a stream ID that allows iterating the pending entries.
   667→The stream ID is a cursor, and I can use it in my next call to continue in claiming idle pending messages:
   668→
   669→{{< clients-example set="stream_tutorial" step="xautoclaim_cursor" description="Continue automatic claiming using the cursor returned by XAUTOCLAIM to iterate through pending messages" difficulty="advanced" >}}
   670→> XAUTOCLAIM race:italy italy_riders Lora 60000 (1692632662819-0 COUNT 1
   671→1) "1692632662819-0"
   672→2) 1) 1) "1692632647899-0"
   673→      2) 1) "rider"
   674→         2) "Royce"
   675→{{< /clients-example >}}
   676→
   677→When [`XAUTOCLAIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xautoclaim" >}}) returns the "0-0" stream ID as a cursor, that means that it reached the end of the consumer group pending entries list.
   678→That doesn't mean that there are no new idle pending messages, so the process continues by calling [`XAUTOCLAIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xautoclaim" >}}) from the beginning of the stream.
   679→
   680→## Claiming and the delivery counter
   681→
   682→The counter that you observe in the [`XPENDING`]({{< relref "/commands/xpending" >}}) output is the number of deliveries of each message. The counter is incremented in two ways: when a message is successfully claimed via [`XCLAIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xclaim" >}}) or when an [`XREADGROUP`]({{< relref "/commands/xreadgroup" >}}) call is used in order to access the history of pending messages.
   683→
   684→When there are failures, it is normal that messages will be delivered multiple times, but eventually they usually get processed and acknowledged. However there might be a problem processing some specific message, because it is corrupted or crafted in a way that triggers a bug in the processing code. In such a case what happens is that consumers will continuously fail to process this particular message. Because we have the counter of the delivery attempts, we can use that counter to detect messages that for some reason are not processable. So once the deliveries counter reaches a given large number that you chose, it is probably wiser to put such messages in another stream and send a notification to the system administrator. This is basically the way that Redis Streams implements the *dead letter* concept.
   685→
   686→## Working with multiple consumer groups
   687→
   688→Redis Streams can be associated with multiple consumer groups, where each entry is delivered to all the stream's consumer groups. Within each consumer group, consumers handle a portion of the entries collaboratively. This design enables different applications or services to process the same stream data independently.
   689→
   690→Traditionally, when a consumer processesed a message, it acknowledged it using the [`XACK`]({{< relref "/commands/xack" >}}) command, which removed the entry reference from the Pending Entries List (PEL) of that specific consumer group. However, the entry remained in the stream and in the PELs of other consumer groups until they also acknowledge it. Applications needed to implement complex logic to delete entries from the stream only after all consumer groups had acknowledged them. This coordination was challenging to implement correctly and efficiently.
   691→
   692→### Enhanced deletion control in Redis 8.2
   693→
   694→Starting with Redis 8.2, several commands provide enhanced control over how entries are handled with respect to multiple consumer groups:
   695→
   696→* [`XADD`]({{< relref "/commands/xadd" >}}) with trimming options now supports `KEEPREF`, `DELREF`, and `ACKED` modes
   697→* [`XTRIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xtrim" >}}) supports the same reference handling options
   698→* [`XDELEX`]({{< relref "/commands/xdelex" >}}) provides fine-grained deletion control
   699→* [`XACKDEL`]({{< relref "/commands/xackdel" >}}) combines acknowledgment and deletion atomically
   700→
   701→These options control how consumer group references are handled:
   702→
   703→- **KEEPREF** (default): Preserves existing references to entries in all consumer groups' PELs, maintaining backward compatibility
   704→- **DELREF**: Removes all references to entries from all consumer groups' PELs, effectively cleaning up all traces of the messages
   705→- **ACKED**: Only processes entries that have been acknowledged by all consumer groups
   706→
   707→The `ACKED` option is particularly useful as it automates the complex logic of coordinating deletion across multiple consumer groups, ensuring entries are only removed when all groups have finished processing them.
   708→
   709→## Streams observability
   710→
   711→Messaging systems that lack observability are very hard to work with. Not knowing who is consuming messages, what messages are pending, the set of consumer groups active in a given stream, makes everything opaque. For this reason, Redis Streams and consumer groups have different ways to observe what is happening. We already covered [`XPENDING`]({{< relref "/commands/xpending" >}}), which allows us to inspect the list of messages that are under processing at a given moment, together with their idle time and number of deliveries.
   712→
   713→However we may want to do more than that, and the [`XINFO`]({{< relref "/commands/xinfo" >}}) command is an observability interface that can be used with sub-commands in order to get information about streams or consumer groups.
   714→
   715→This command uses subcommands in order to show different information about the status of the stream and its consumer groups. For instance **XINFO STREAM <key>** reports information about the stream itself.
   716→
   717→{{< clients-example set="stream_tutorial" step="xinfo" description="Get detailed stream information including length, encoding, and consumer groups using XINFO STREAM" difficulty="intermediate" >}}
   718→> XINFO STREAM race:italy
   719→ 1) "length"
   720→ 2) (integer) 5
   721→ 3) "radix-tree-keys"
   722→ 4) (integer) 1
   723→ 5) "radix-tree-nodes"
   724→ 6) (integer) 2
   725→ 7) "last-generated-id"
   726→ 8) "1692632678249-0"
   727→ 9) "groups"
   728→10) (integer) 1
   729→11) "first-entry"
   730→12) 1) "1692632639151-0"
   731→    2) 1) "rider"
   732→       2) "Castilla"
   733→13) "last-entry"
   734→14) 1) "1692632678249-0"
   735→    2) 1) "rider"
   736→       2) "Norem"
   737→{{< /clients-example >}}
   738→
   739→The output shows information about how the stream is encoded internally, and also shows the first and last message in the stream. Another piece of information available is the number of consumer groups associated with this stream. We can dig further asking for more information about the consumer groups.
   740→
   741→{{< clients-example set="stream_tutorial" step="xinfo_groups" description="List all consumer groups for a stream using XINFO GROUPS to see group status and pending message counts" difficulty="intermediate" >}}
   742→> XINFO GROUPS race:italy
   743→1) 1) "name"
   744→   2) "italy_riders"
   745→   3) "consumers"
   746→   4) (integer) 3
   747→   5) "pending"
   748→   6) (integer) 2
   749→   7) "last-delivered-id"
   750→   8) "1692632662819-0"
   751→{{< /clients-example >}}
   752→
   753→As you can see in this and in the previous output, the [`XINFO`]({{< relref "/commands/xinfo" >}}) command outputs a sequence of field-value items. Because it is an observability command this allows the human user to immediately understand what information is reported, and allows the command to report more information in the future by adding more fields without breaking compatibility with older clients. Other commands that must be more bandwidth efficient, like [`XPENDING`]({{< relref "/commands/xpending" >}}), just report the information without the field names.
   754→
   755→The output of the example above, where the **GROUPS** subcommand is used, should be clear observing the field names. We can check in more detail the state of a specific consumer group by checking the consumers that are registered in the group.
   756→
   757→{{< clients-example set="stream_tutorial" step="xinfo_consumers" description="Get detailed consumer information for a group using XINFO CONSUMERS to monitor individual consumer status" difficulty="advanced" >}}
   758→> XINFO CONSUMERS race:italy italy_riders
   759→1) 1) "name"
   760→   2) "Alice"
   761→   3) "pending"
   762→   4) (integer) 1
   763→   5) "idle"
   764→   6) (integer) 177546
   765→2) 1) "name"
   766→   2) "Bob"
   767→   3) "pending"
   768→   4) (integer) 0
   769→   5) "idle"
   770→   6) (integer) 424686
   771→3) 1) "name"
   772→   2) "Lora"
   773→   3) "pending"
   774→   4) (integer) 1
   775→   5) "idle"
   776→   6) (integer) 72241
   777→{{< /clients-example >}}
   778→
   779→In case you do not remember the syntax of the command, just ask the command itself for help:
   780→
   781→```
   782→> XINFO HELP
   783→1) XINFO <subcommand> [<arg> [value] [opt] ...]. Subcommands are:
   784→2) CONSUMERS <key> <groupname>
   785→3)     Show consumers of <groupname>.
   786→4) GROUPS <key>
   787→5)     Show the stream consumer groups.
   788→6) STREAM <key> [FULL [COUNT <count>]
   789→7)     Show information about the stream.
   790→8) HELP
   791→9)     Prints this help.
   792→```
   793→
   794→## Differences with Kafka (TM) partitions
   795→
   796→Consumer groups in Redis streams may resemble in some way Kafka (TM) partitioning-based consumer groups, however note that Redis streams are, in practical terms, very different. The partitions are only *logical* and the messages are just put into a single Redis key, so the way the different clients are served is based on who is ready to process new messages, and not from which partition clients are reading. For instance, if the consumer C3 at some point fails permanently, Redis will continue to serve C1 and C2 all the new messages arriving, as if now there are only two *logical* partitions.
   797→
   798→Similarly, if a given consumer is much faster at processing messages than the other consumers, this consumer will receive proportionally more messages in the same unit of time. This is possible since Redis tracks all the unacknowledged messages explicitly, and remembers who received which message and the ID of the first message never delivered to any consumer.
   799→
   800→However, this also means that in Redis if you really want to partition messages in the same stream into multiple Redis instances, you have to use multiple keys and some sharding system such as Redis Cluster or some other application-specific sharding system. A single Redis stream is not automatically partitioned to multiple instances.
   801→
   802→We could say that schematically the following is true:
   803→
   804→* If you use 1 stream -> 1 consumer, you are processing messages in order.
   805→* If you use N streams with N consumers, so that only a given consumer hits a subset of the N streams, you can scale the above model of 1 stream -> 1 consumer.
   806→* If you use 1 stream -> N consumers, you are load balancing to N consumers, however in that case, messages about the same logical item may be consumed out of order, because a given consumer may process message 3 faster than another consumer is processing message 4.
   807→
   808→So basically Kafka partitions are more similar to using N different Redis keys, while Redis consumer groups are a server-side load balancing system of messages from a given stream to N different consumers.
   809→
   810→## Capped Streams
   811→
   812→Many applications do not want to collect data into a stream forever. Sometimes it is useful to have at maximum a given number of items inside a stream, other times once a given size is reached, it is useful to move data from Redis to a storage which is not in memory and not as fast but suited to store the history for, potentially, decades to come. Redis streams have some support for this. One is the **MAXLEN** option of the [`XADD`]({{< relref "/commands/xadd" >}}) command. This option is very simple to use:
   813→
   814→{{< clients-example set="stream_tutorial" step="maxlen" description="Limit stream size using MAXLEN option with XADD to automatically evict old entries and maintain constant memory usage" difficulty="intermediate" >}}
   815→> XADD race:italy MAXLEN 2 * rider Jones
   816→"1692633189161-0"
   817→> XADD race:italy MAXLEN 2 * rider Wood
   818→"1692633198206-0"
   819→> XADD race:italy MAXLEN 2 * rider Henshaw
   820→"1692633208557-0"
   821→> XLEN race:italy
   822→(integer) 2
   823→> XRANGE race:italy - +
   824→1) 1) "1692633198206-0"
   825→   2) 1) "rider"
   826→      2) "Wood"
   827→2) 1) "1692633208557-0"
   828→   2) 1) "rider"
   829→      2) "Henshaw"
   830→{{< /clients-example >}}
   831→
   832→Using **MAXLEN** the old entries are automatically evicted when the specified length is reached, so that the stream is left at a constant size. There is currently no option to tell the stream to just retain items that are not older than a given period, because such command, in order to run consistently, would potentially block for a long time in order to evict items. Imagine for example what happens if there is an insertion spike, then a long pause, and another insertion, all with the same maximum time. The stream would block to evict the data that became too old during the pause. So it is up to the user to do some planning and understand what is the maximum stream length desired. Moreover, while the length of the stream is proportional to the memory used, trimming by time is less simple to control and anticipate: it depends on the insertion rate which often changes over time (and when it does not change, then to just trim by size is trivial).
   833→
   834→However trimming with **MAXLEN** can be expensive: streams are represented by macro nodes into a radix tree, in order to be very memory efficient. Altering the single macro node, consisting of a few tens of elements, is not optimal. So it's possible to use the command in the following special form:
   835→
   836→```
   837→XADD race:italy MAXLEN ~ 1000 * ... entry fields here ...
   838→```
   839→
   840→The `~` argument between the **MAXLEN** option and the actual count means, I don't really need this to be exactly 1000 items. It can be 1000 or 1010 or 1030, just make sure to save at least 1000 items. With this argument, the trimming is performed only when we can remove a whole node. This makes it much more efficient, and it is usually what you want. You'll note here that the client libraries have various implementations of this. For example, the Python client defaults to approximate and has to be explicitly set to a true length.
   841→
   842→There is also the [`XTRIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xtrim" >}}) command, which performs something very similar to what the **MAXLEN** option does above, except that it can be run by itself:
   843→
   844→{{< clients-example set="stream_tutorial" step="xtrim" description="Trim a stream to a maximum length using XTRIM MAXLEN to remove old entries" difficulty="intermediate" >}}
   845→> XTRIM race:italy MAXLEN 10
   846→(integer) 0
   847→{{< /clients-example >}}
   848→
   849→Or, as for the [`XADD`]({{< relref "/commands/xadd" >}}) option:
   850→
   851→{{< clients-example set="stream_tutorial" step="xtrim2" description="Use approximate trimming with XTRIM MAXLEN ~ for more efficient memory management" difficulty="intermediate" >}}
   852→> XTRIM mystream MAXLEN ~ 10
   853→(integer) 0
   854→{{< /clients-example >}}
   855→
   856→However, [`XTRIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xtrim" >}}) is designed to accept different trimming strategies. Another trimming strategy is **MINID**, that evicts entries with IDs lower than the one specified.
   857→
   858→As [`XTRIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xtrim" >}}) is an explicit command, the user is expected to know about the possible shortcomings of different trimming strategies.
   859→
   860→### Trimming with consumer group awareness
   861→
   862→Starting with Redis 8.2, both [`XADD`]({{< relref "/commands/xadd" >}}) with trimming options and [`XTRIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xtrim" >}}) support enhanced control over how trimming interacts with consumer groups through the `KEEPREF`, `DELREF`, and `ACKED` options:
   863→
   864→```
   865→XADD mystream KEEPREF MAXLEN 1000 * field value
   866→XTRIM mystream ACKED MAXLEN 1000
   867→```
   868→
   869→- **KEEPREF** (default): Trims entries according to the strategy but preserves references in consumer group PELs
   870→- **DELREF**: Trims entries and removes all references from consumer group PELs
   871→- **ACKED**: Only trims entries that have been acknowledged by all consumer groups
   872→
   873→The `ACKED` option is particularly useful for maintaining data integrity across multiple consumer groups, ensuring that entries are only removed when all groups have finished processing them.
   874→
   875→Another useful eviction strategy that may be added to [`XTRIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xtrim" >}}) in the future, is to remove by a range of IDs to ease use of [`XRANGE`]({{< relref "/commands/xrange" >}}) and [`XTRIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xtrim" >}}) to move data from Redis to other storage systems if needed.
   876→
   877→## Special IDs in the streams API
   878→
   879→You may have noticed that there are several special IDs that can be used in the Redis API. Here is a short recap, so that they can make more sense in the future.
   880→
   881→The first two special IDs are `-` and `+`, and are used in range queries with the [`XRANGE`]({{< relref "/commands/xrange" >}}) command. Those two IDs respectively mean the smallest ID possible (that is basically `0-1`) and the greatest ID possible (that is `18446744073709551615-18446744073709551615`). As you can see it is a lot cleaner to write `-` and `+` instead of those numbers.
   882→
   883→Then there are APIs where we want to say, the ID of the item with the greatest ID inside the stream. This is what `$` means. So for instance if I want only new entries with [`XREADGROUP`]({{< relref "/commands/xreadgroup" >}}) I use this ID to signify I already have all the existing entries, but not the new ones that will be inserted in the future. Similarly when I create or set the ID of a consumer group, I can set the last delivered item to `$` in order to just deliver new entries to the consumers in the group.
   884→
   885→As you can see `$` does not mean `+`, they are two different things, as `+` is the greatest ID possible in every possible stream, while `$` is the greatest ID in a given stream containing given entries. Moreover APIs will usually only understand `+` or `$`, yet it was useful to avoid loading a given symbol with multiple meanings.
   886→
   887→Another special ID is `>`, that is a special meaning only related to consumer groups and only when the [`XREADGROUP`]({{< relref "/commands/xreadgroup" >}}) command is used. This special ID means that we want only entries that were never delivered to other consumers so far. So basically the `>` ID is the *last delivered ID* of a consumer group.
   888→
   889→Finally the special ID `*`, that can be used only with the [`XADD`]({{< relref "/commands/xadd" >}}) command, means to auto select an ID for us for the new entry.
   890→
   891→So we have `-`, `+`, `$`, `>` and `*`, and all have a different meaning, and most of the time, can be used in different contexts.
   892→
   893→## Persistence, replication and message safety
   894→
   895→A Stream, like any other Redis data structure, is asynchronously replicated to replicas and persisted into AOF and RDB files. However what may not be so obvious is that also the consumer groups full state is propagated to AOF, RDB and replicas, so if a message is pending in the master, also the replica will have the same information. Similarly, after a restart, the AOF will restore the consumer groups' state.
   896→
   897→However note that Redis streams and consumer groups are persisted and replicated using the Redis default replication, so:
   898→
   899→* AOF must be used with a strong fsync policy if persistence of messages is important in your application.
   900→* By default the asynchronous replication will not guarantee that [`XADD`]({{< relref "/commands/xadd" >}}) commands or consumer groups state changes are replicated: after a failover something can be missing depending on the ability of replicas to receive the data from the master.
   901→* The [`WAIT`]({{< relref "/commands/wait" >}}) command may be used in order to force the propagation of the changes to a set of replicas. However note that while this makes it very unlikely that data is lost, the Redis failover process as operated by Sentinel or Redis Cluster performs only a *best effort* check to failover to the replica which is the most updated, and under certain specific failure conditions may promote a replica that lacks some data.
   902→
   903→So when designing an application using Redis streams and consumer groups, make sure to understand the semantical properties your application should have during failures, and configure things accordingly, evaluating whether it is safe enough for your use case.
   904→
   905→## Removing single items from a stream
   906→
   907→Streams also have a special command for removing items from the middle of a stream, just by ID. Normally for an append only data structure this may look like an odd feature, but it is actually useful for applications involving, for instance, privacy regulations. The command is called [`XDEL`]({{< relref "/commands/xdel" >}}) and receives the name of the stream followed by the IDs to delete:
   908→
   909→{{< clients-example set="stream_tutorial" step="xdel" description="Delete specific entries from a stream by ID using XDEL for privacy or data cleanup purposes" difficulty="advanced" >}}
   910→> XRANGE race:italy - + COUNT 2
   911→1) 1) "1692633198206-0"
   912→   2) 1) "rider"
   913→      2) "Wood"
   914→2) 1) "1692633208557-0"
   915→   2) 1) "rider"
   916→      2) "Henshaw"
   917→> XDEL race:italy 1692633208557-0
   918→(integer) 1
   919→> XRANGE race:italy - + COUNT 2
   920→1) 1) "1692633198206-0"
   921→   2) 1) "rider"
   922→      2) "Wood"
   923→{{< /clients-example >}}
   924→
   925→### Enhanced deletion with XDELEX
   926→
   927→Starting with Redis 8.2, the [`XDELEX`]({{< relref "/commands/xdelex" >}}) command provides enhanced control over entry deletion, particularly when working with consumer groups. Like other enhanced commands, it supports `KEEPREF`, `DELREF`, and `ACKED` options:
   928→
   929→```
   930→XDELEX mystream ACKED IDS 2 1692633198206-0 1692633208557-0
   931→```
   932→
   933→This allows you to delete entries only when they have been acknowledged by all consumer groups (`ACKED`), remove all consumer group references (`DELREF`), or preserve existing references (`KEEPREF`).
   934→
   935→## Zero length streams
   936→
   937→A difference between streams and other Redis data structures is that when the other data structures no longer have any elements, as a side effect of calling commands that remove elements, the key itself will be removed. So for instance, a sorted set will be completely removed when a call to [`ZREM`]({{< relref "/commands/zrem" >}}) will remove the last element in the sorted set. Streams, on the other hand, are allowed to stay at zero elements, both as a result of using a **MAXLEN** option with a count of zero ([`XADD`]({{< relref "/commands/xadd" >}}) and [`XTRIM`]({{< relref "/commands/xtrim" >}}) commands), or because [`XDEL`]({{< relref "/commands/xdel" >}}) was called.
   938→
   939→The reason why such an asymmetry exists is because Streams may have associated consumer groups, and we do not want to lose the state that the consumer groups defined just because there are no longer any items in the stream. Currently the stream is not deleted even when it has no associated consumer groups.
   940→
   941→## Total latency of consuming a message
   942→
   943→Non blocking stream commands like [`XRANGE`]({{< relref "/commands/xrange" >}}) and [`XREAD`]({{< relref "/commands/xread" >}}) or [`XREADGROUP`]({{< relref "/commands/xreadgroup" >}}) without the BLOCK option are served synchronously like any other Redis command, so to discuss latency of such commands is meaningless: it is more interesting to check the time complexity of the commands in the Redis documentation. It should be enough to say that stream commands are at least as fast as sorted set commands when extracting ranges, and that [`XADD`]({{< relref "/commands/xadd" >}}) is very fast and can easily insert from half a million to one million items per second in an average machine if pipelining is used.
   944→
   945→However latency becomes an interesting parameter if we want to understand the delay of processing a message, in the context of blocking consumers in a consumer group, from the moment the message is produced via [`XADD`]({{< relref "/commands/xadd" >}}), to the moment the message is obtained by the consumer because [`XREADGROUP`]({{< relref "/commands/xreadgroup" >}}) returned with the message.
   946→
   947→## How serving blocked consumers works
   948→
   949→Before providing the results of performed tests, it is interesting to understand what model Redis uses in order to route stream messages (and in general actually how any blocking operation waiting for data is managed).
   950→
   951→* The blocked client is referenced in a hash table that maps keys for which there is at least one blocking consumer, to a list of consumers that are waiting for such key. This way, given a key that received data, we can resolve all the clients that are waiting for such data.
   952→* When a write happens, in this case when the [`XADD`]({{< relref "/commands/xadd" >}}) command is called, it calls the `signalKeyAsReady()` function. This function will put the key into a list of keys that need to be processed, because such keys may have new data for blocked consumers. Note that such *ready keys* will be processed later, so in the course of the same event loop cycle, it is possible that the key will receive other writes.
   953→* Finally, before returning into the event loop, the *ready keys* are finally processed. For each key the list of clients waiting for data is scanned, and if applicable, such clients will receive the new data that arrived. In the case of streams the data is the messages in the applicable range requested by the consumer.
   954→
   955→As you can see, basically, before returning to the event loop both the client calling [`XADD`]({{< relref "/commands/xadd" >}}) and the clients blocked to consume messages, will have their reply in the output buffers, so the caller of [`XADD`]({{< relref "/commands/xadd" >}}) should receive the reply from Redis at about the same time the consumers will receive the new messages.
   956→
   957→This model is *push-based*, since adding data to the consumers buffers will be performed directly by the action of calling [`XADD`]({{< relref "/commands/xadd" >}}), so the latency tends to be quite predictable.
   958→
   959→## Latency tests results
   960→
   961→In order to check these latency characteristics a test was performed using multiple instances of Ruby programs pushing messages having as an additional field the computer millisecond time, and Ruby programs reading the messages from the consumer group and processing them. The message processing step consisted of comparing the current computer time with the message timestamp, in order to understand the total latency.
   962→
   963→Results obtained:
   964→
   965→```
   966→Processed between 0 and 1 ms -> 74.11%
   967→Processed between 1 and 2 ms -> 25.80%
   968→Processed between 2 and 3 ms -> 0.06%
   969→Processed between 3 and 4 ms -> 0.01%
   970→Processed between 4 and 5 ms -> 0.02%
   971→```
   972→
   973→So 99.9% of requests have a latency <= 2 milliseconds, with the outliers that remain still very close to the average.
   974→
   975→Adding a few million unacknowledged messages to the stream does not change the gist of the benchmark, with most queries still processed with very short latency.
   976→
   977→A few remarks:
   978→
   979→* Here we processed up to 10k messages per iteration, this means that the `COUNT` parameter of [`XREADGROUP`]({{< relref "/commands/xreadgroup" >}}) was set to 10000. This adds a lot of latency but is needed in order to allow the slow consumers to be able to keep with the message flow. So you can expect a real world latency that is a lot smaller.
   980→* The system used for this benchmark is very slow compared to today's standards.
   981→
   982→## Learn more
   983→
   984→* [Redis Streams Explained](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z8qcpXyMAiA) is an entertaining introduction to streams in Redis.
   985→* [Redis University's RU202](https://university.redis.com/courses/ru202/) is a free, online course dedicated to Redis Streams.
   986→

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

[TextBlock(text='Based on the Redis Streams documentation, here's how to use Redis Streams for message queuing:

## Basic Message Queuing with Redis Streams

### 1. Adding Messages (Producer)

Use `XADD` to append messages to a stream:

```bash
# Add a message with auto-generated ID (*)
XADD myqueue * task "process-order" order_id 12345 priority high

# Returns: "1692632086370-0" (auto-generated ID)
```

### 2. Reading Messages (Simple Consumer)

Use `XREAD` to consume messages:

```bash
# Read new messages (blocking for 5 seconds if none available)
XREAD BLOCK 5000 COUNT 10 STREAMS myqueue $

# $ means "only new messages from now on"
```

### 3. Consumer Groups (Recommended for Message Queuing)

Consumer groups enable multiple workers to process different messages from the same stream:

**Create a consumer group:**
```bash
XGROUP CREATE myqueue workers $ MKSTREAM
```

**Read messages as a consumer:**
```bash
# Consumer "worker-1" reads up to 10 messages
XREADGROUP GROUP workers worker-1 COUNT 10 STREAMS myqueue >

# > means "new messages never delivered to other consumers"
```

**Acknowledge processed messages:**
```bash
XACK myqueue workers 1692632086370-0
```

### 4. Complete Worker Pattern

```ruby
# Pseudocode for a reliable worker
consumer_name = "worker-1"
group_name = "workers"

loop do
  # First, check for pending messages (recovery from crash)
  messages = XREADGROUP GROUP workers worker-1 STREAMS myqueue 0
  
  if messages.empty?
    # No pending messages, get new ones
    messages = XREADGROUP GROUP workers worker-1 BLOCK 2000 COUNT 10 STREAMS myqueue >
  end
  
  messages.each do |msg|
    process_message(msg)
    XACK myqueue workers msg.id
  end
end
```

### 5. Handling Failed Messages

**Check pending messages:**
```bash
XPENDING myqueue workers
```

**Claim messages from failed workers:**
```bash
# Claim messages idle for 60+ seconds
XAUTOCLAIM myqueue workers worker-2 60000 0-0 COUNT 10
```

### Key Features for Message Queuing

- **Load balancing**: Multiple consumers automatically get different messages
- **At-least-once delivery**: Messages stay pending until acknowledged
- **Failure recovery**: Claim idle messages from crashed workers
- **Message history**: All messages retained (unless trimmed)
- **Observability**: `XINFO` and `XPENDING` for monitoring

### Capping Stream Size

```bash
# Keep only last 10,000 messages
XADD myqueue MAXLEN ~ 10000 * task "new-task"

# Or trim separately
XTRIM myqueue MAXLEN ~ 10000
```

[Source: /home/shenzt/ws/knowledge-base-search/tests/fixtures/kb-sources/redis-docs/content/develop/data-types/streams/_index.md]')]

Based on the Redis Streams documentation, here's how to use Redis Streams for message queuing:

## Basic Message Queuing with Redis Streams

### 1. Adding Messages (Producer)

Use `XADD` to append messages to a stream:

```bash
# Add a message with auto-generated ID (*)
XADD myqueue * task "process-order" order_id 12345 priority high

# Returns: "1692632086370-0" (auto-generated ID)
```

### 2. Reading Messages (Simple Consumer)

Use `XREAD` to consume messages:

```bash
# Read new messages (blocking for 5 seconds if none available)
XREAD BLOCK 5000 COUNT 10 STREAMS myqueue $

# $ means "only new messages from now on"
```

### 3. Consumer Groups (Recommended for Message Queuing)

Consumer groups enable multiple workers to process different messages from the same stream:

**Create a consumer group:**
```bash
XGROUP CREATE myqueue workers $ MKSTREAM
```

**Read messages as a consumer:**
```bash
# Consumer "worker-1" reads up to 10 messages
XREADGROUP GROUP workers worker-1 COUNT 10 STREAMS myqueue >

# > means "new messages never delivered to other consumers"
```

**Acknowledge processed messages:**
```bash
XACK myqueue workers 1692632086370-0
```

### 4. Complete Worker Pattern

```ruby
# Pseudocode for a reliable worker
consumer_name = "worker-1"
group_name = "workers"

loop do
  # First, check for pending messages (recovery from crash)
  messages = XREADGROUP GROUP workers worker-1 STREAMS myqueue 0
  
  if messages.empty?
    # No pending messages, get new ones
    messages = XREADGROUP GROUP workers worker-1 BLOCK 2000 COUNT 10 STREAMS myqueue >
  end
  
  messages.each do |msg|
    process_message(msg)
    XACK myqueue workers msg.id
  end
end
```

### 5. Handling Failed Messages

**Check pending messages:**
```bash
XPENDING myqueue workers
```

**Claim messages from failed workers:**
```bash
# Claim messages idle for 60+ seconds
XAUTOCLAIM myqueue workers worker-2 60000 0-0 COUNT 10
```

### Key Features for Message Queuing

- **Load balancing**: Multiple consumers automatically get different messages
- **At-least-once delivery**: Messages stay pending until acknowledged
- **Failure recovery**: Claim idle messages from crashed workers
- **Message history**: All messages retained (unless trimmed)
- **Observability**: `XINFO` and `XPENDING` for monitoring

### Capping Stream Size

```bash
# Keep only last 10,000 messages
XADD myqueue MAXLEN ~ 10000 * task "new-task"

# Or trim separately
XTRIM myqueue MAXLEN ~ 10000
```

query: Redis Bloom Filter 的误判率怎么配置？
answer:
Redis Bloom Filter 的误判率可以通过以下方式配置：

## 1. 创建时指定（推荐）

使用 `BF.RESERVE` 命令创建 Bloom Filter 时指定误判率：

```redis
BF.RESERVE {key} {error_rate} {capacity} [EXPANSION expansion] [NONSCALING]
```

**参数说明：**
- `error_rate`：误判率，取值范围 `(0, 1)`，例如：
  - `0.001` = 0.1% 误判率（千分之一）
  - `0.01` = 1% 误判率（百分之一）
  - `0.0001` = 0.01% 误判率（万分之一）

**示例：**
```redis
BF.RESERVE bikes:models 0.001 1000000
```
创建一个容量 100 万、误判率 0.1% 的 Bloom Filter。

## 2. 全局默认配置

在 `redis.conf` 中设置默认误判率（Redis 8.0+）：

```conf
bf-error-rate 0.01
```

- **类型**：double
- **有效范围**：`(0, 1)`，但大于 `0.25` 的值会被视为 `0.25`
- **默认值**：`0.01`（1% 误判率）
- **运行时修改**：支持通过 `CONFIG SET bf-error-rate 0.001` 动态调整

## 3. 误判率与内存的权衡

不同误判率对应的内存开销：

| 误判率 | 哈希函数数量 | 每项所需位数 |
|--------|-------------|-------------|
| 1%     | 7           | 9.585 bits  |
| 0.1%   | 10          | 14.378 bits |
| 0.01%  | 14          | 19.170 bits |

**计算公式：**
- 哈希函数数量 = `ceil(-ln(error_rate) / ln(2))`
- 总位数 = `capacity * -ln(error_rate) / ln(2)^2`

## 4. 注意事项

- **容量规划**：如果实际存储量超过 `capacity`，会自动扩展（创建子过滤器），但会增加查询延迟
- **NONSCALING 标志**：如果确定不会超过初始容量，使用此标志可减少一个哈希函数，提升性能
- **误判率增长**：容量不足时，误判率会逐渐上升

---

**[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/configuration.md > Default parameters for Bloom filters > bf-error-rate]**

Though the valid range is `(0 .. 1)` (corresponding to `> 0%` to `< 100%` false positive rate), any value greater than `0.25` is treated as `0.25`.\\\\n\\\\nDefault: `0.01`\\\\n\\\\nAdded in v8.0.0.\\\\n\\\\nExpansion factor for Bloom filters.\\\\n\\\\nType: integer\\\\n\\\\nValid range: `[0 .. 32768]`.\\\\n\\\\nDefault: `2`\\\\n\\\\nInitial capacity for Bloom filters.\\\\n\\\\nType: integer\\\\n\\\\nValid range: `[1 .. 1048576]`\\\\n\\\\nDefault: `100`\\"\\n },\\n {\\n \\"score\\": 4.6566,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"1760b768\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"1760b768-004\\",\\n \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/bloom-filter.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Bloom filter\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"Reserving Bloom filters > Total size of a Bloom filter\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"The actual memory used by a Bloom filter is a function of the chosen error rate:\\\\n\\\\nThe optimal number of hash functions is `ceil(-ln(error_rate) / ln(2))`.\\\\n\\\\nThe required number of bits per item, given the desired `error_rate` and the optimal number of hash functions, is `-ln(error_rate) / ln(2)^2`. Hence, the required number of bits in the filter is `capacity * -ln(error_rate) / ln(2)^2`.\\\\n\\\\n* **1%** error rate requires 7 hash functions and 9.585 bits per item.\\\\n* **0.1%** error rate requires 10 hash functions and 14.378 bits per item.\\\\n* **0.01%** error rate requires 14 hash functions and 19.170 bits per item.\\\\n\\\\nJust as a comparison, when using a Redis set for membership testing the memory needed is:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nmemory_with_sets = capacity*(192b + value)\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nFor a set of IP addresses, for example, we would have around 40 bytes (320 bits) per item - considerably higher than the 19.170 bits we need for a Bloom filter with a 0.01% false positives rate.\\"\\n },\\n {\\n \\"score\\": 3.3047,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"1760b768\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"1760b768-003\\",\\n \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/bloom-filter.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Bloom filter\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"Reserving Bloom filters > 4. `NONSCALING`\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"The rate is a decimal value between 0 and 1. For example, for a desired false positive rate of 0.1% (1 in 1000), error_rate should be set to 0.001.\\\\n\\\\nThis is the number of items you expect having in your filter in total and is trivial when you have a static set but it becomes more challenging when your set grows over time. It\'s important to get the number right because if you **oversize** - you\'ll end up wasting memory. If you **undersize**, the filter will fill up and a new one will have to be stacked on top of it (sub-filter stacking). In the cases when a filter consists of multiple sub-filters stacked on top of each other latency for adds stays the same, but the latency for presence checks increases. The reason for this is the way the checks work: a regular check would first be performed on the top (latest) filter and if a negative answer is returned the next one is checked and so on. That\'s where the added latency comes from.\\\\n\\\\nAdding an item to a Bloom filter never fails due to the data structure \\\\\\"filling up\\\\\\". Instead, the error rate starts to grow. To keep the error close to the one set on filter initialization, the Bloom filter will auto-scale, meaning, when capacity is reached, an additional sub-filter will be created. \\\\n The size of the new sub-filter is the size of the last sub-filter multiplied by `EXPANSION`. If the number of items to be stored in the filter is unknown, we recommend that you use an expansion of 2 or more to reduce the number of sub-filters. Otherwise, we recommend that you use an expansion of 1 to reduce memory consumption. The default expansion value is 2. \\\\n \\\\n The filter will keep adding more hash functions for every new sub-filter in order to keep your desired error rate. \\\\n\\\\nMaybe you\'re wondering \\\\\\"Why would I create a smaller filter with a high expansion rate if I know I\'m going to scale anyway?\\\\\\"; the answer is: for cases where you need to keep many filters (let\'s say a filter per user, or per product) and most of them will stay small, but some with more activity will have to scale.\\\\n\\\\nIf you know you\'re not going to scale use the `NONSCALING` flag because that way the filter will use one hash function less. Just remember that if you ever do reach the initially assigned capacity - your error rate will start to grow.\\"\\n },\\n {\\n \\"score\\": 2.7903,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"1760b768\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"1760b768-002\\",\\n \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/bloom-filter.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Bloom filter\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"Reserving Bloom filters\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"Consider a bike manufacturer that makes a million different kinds of bikes and you\'d like to avoid using a duplicate model name in new models. A Bloom filter can be used to detect duplicates. In the example that follows, you\'ll create a filter with space for a million entries and with a 0.1% error rate. Add one model name and check if it exists. Then add multiple model names and check if they exist.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> BF.RESERVE bikes:models 0.001 1000000\\\\nOK\\\\n> BF.ADD bikes:models \\\\\\"Smoky Mountain Striker\\\\\\"\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> BF.EXISTS bikes:models \\\\\\"Smoky Mountain Striker\\\\\\"\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> BF.MADD bikes:models \\\\\\"Rocky Mountain Racer\\\\\\" \\\\\\"Cloudy City Cruiser\\\\\\" \\\\\\"Windy City Wippet\\\\\\"\\\\n1) (integer) 1\\\\n2) (integer) 1\\\\n3) (integer) 1\\\\n> BF.MEXISTS bikes:models \\\\\\"Rocky Mountain Racer\\\\\\" \\\\\\"Cloudy City Cruiser\\\\\\" \\\\\\"Windy City Wippet\\\\\\"\\\\n1) (integer) 1\\\\n2) (integer) 1\\\\n3) (integer) 1\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nNote: there is always a chance that even with just a few items, there could be a false positive, meaning an item could \\\\\\"exist\\\\\\" even though it has not been explicitly added to the Bloom filter. For a more in depth understanding of the probabilistic nature of a Bloom filter, check out the blog posts linked at the bottom of this page.\\\\n\\\\nWith the Redis Bloom filter, most of the sizing work is done for you: \\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nBF.RESERVE {key} {error_rate} {capacity} [EXPANSION expansion] [NONSCALING]\\\\n```\\"\\n },\\n {\\n \\"score\\": 1.1392,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"0065cf20\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"0065cf20-000\\",\\n \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/configuration.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Configuration Parameters\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis probabilistic data structure configuration parameters\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"As of Redis 8 in Redis Open Source (Redis 8), configuration parameters for the probabilistic data structures are now set in the following ways:\\\\n* At load time via your `redis.conf` file.\\\\n* At run time (where applicable) using the [`CONFIG SET`]() command.\\\\n\\\\nAlso, Redis 8 persists probabilistic configuration parameters just like any other configuration parameters (e.g., using the [`CONFIG REWRITE`]() command).\\\\n\\\\nThe following table summarizes which Bloom filter configuration parameters can be set at run-time, and compatibility with Redis Software and Redis Cloud.\\\\n\\\\n| Parameter name
(version < 8.0) | Parameter name
(version ≥ 8.0) | Run-time | Redis
Software | Redis
Cloud |\\\\n| :------- | :------- | :------- | :------- | :------- |\\\\n| ERROR_RATE | [bf-error-rate](#bf-error-rate) | :white_check_mark: | ✅ Supported

 | ✅ Flexible & Annual

- **类型**：double
- **有效范围**：`(0, 1)`，但大于 `0.25` 的值会被视为 `0.25`
- **默认值**：`0.01`（1% 误判率）
- **运行时修改**：支持通过 `CONFIG SET bf-error-rate 0.001` 动态调整

## 3. 误判率与内存的权衡

不同误判率对应的内存开销：

| 误判率 | 哈希函数数量 | 每项所需位数 |
|--------|-------------|-------------|
| 1%     | 7           | 9.585 bits  |
| 0.1%   | 10          | 14.378 bits |
| 0.01%  | 14          | 19.170 bits |

**计算公式：**
- 哈希函数数量 = `ceil(-ln(error_rate) / ln(2))`
- 总位数 = `capacity * -ln(error_rate) / ln(2)^2`

## 4. 注意事项

- **容量规划**：如果实际存储量超过 `capacity`，会自动扩展（创建子过滤器），但会增加查询延迟
- **NONSCALING 标志**：如果确定不会超过初始容量，使用此标志可减少一个哈希函数，提升性能
- **误判率增长**：容量不足时，误判率会逐渐上升

---

query: When should I use Redis Hashes vs JSON?
answer:
Based on the Redis documentation, here's when to use Hashes vs JSON:

## Use **JSON** when you need:

1. **Nested data structures** - JSON is the only type that supports deeply nested fields and arrays
2. **Geospatial indexing/querying** with Redis query engine
3. **Access to sub-values** - Retrieve nested values without transmitting the entire object over the network
4. **Atomic partial updates** - Increment values, add/remove array elements, append strings atomically
5. **Complex querying** - Index and query nested structures with Redis Query Engine

## Use **Hashes** when you need:

1. **Indexing/querying without nested structures** - Hashes support Redis query engine with lower memory overhead and faster field access than JSON
2. **Field-level expiration** - Set expiration times on individual fields within the document
3. **Frequent access to individual fields** - More efficient than JSON for simple field access with string/binary values
4. **Lower memory footprint** - Hashes have less memory overhead than JSON

## Use **Strings** when:
- You only need simple bit fields with integer indices
- You don't need frequent field access
- You want the most compact storage

## Decision Tree Summary:
```
Need nested structures or geospatial? → JSON
Need indexing but flat structure is OK? → Hashes  
Need field-level expiration? → Hashes
Need frequent field access with strings? → Hashes
Simple storage, no field access? → Strings
```

For example, you can serialize JSON and save it in a Redis String.\\\\n\\\\nHowever, Redis JSON provides several benefits over this approach.\\\\n\\\\n**Access and retrieval of subvalues**\\\\n\\\\nWith JSON, you can get nested values without having to transmit the entire object over the network. Being able to access sub-objects can lead to greater efficiencies when you\'re storing large JSON objects in Redis.\\\\n\\\\n**Atomic partial updates**\\\\n\\\\nJSON allows you to atomically run operations like incrementing a value, adding, or removing elements from an array, append strings, and so on. When a string value appears multiple times, either within the same JSON document\\\\nor across different documents on the same node, Redis stores only a single copy of that string and uses references to it.\\\\nThis approach is especially efficient when many documents share similar structures.\\\\n\\\\nHowever, the `JSON.DEBUG MEMORY` command reports memory usage as if each string instance is stored independently, even when it\'s actually reused.\\\\nFor example, the document `{\\\\\\"foo\\\\\\": [\\\\\\"foo\\\\\\", \\\\\\"foo\\\\\\"]}` reuses the string `\\\\\\"foo\\\\\\"` internally, but the reported memory usage counts the string three times: once for the key and once for each array element.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -1.4519,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"91f82bad\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"91f82bad-001\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisjson/redisjson-2.0-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisjson 2.0 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"v2.0.4 (November 2021) > Headlines\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"RedisJSON is a [high-performance JSON document store](https://redis.com/blog/redisjson-public-preview-performance-benchmarking/) that allows developers to build modern applications. It stores and processes JSON in-memory, supporting millions of operations per second with sub-millisecond response times. The combination of `RediSearch`, native indexing, querying, and full-text search of JSON documents allows developers to create secondary indexes and query data at lightning speed.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -1.6132,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"74eb0b57\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"74eb0b57-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/json/ram.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis JSON RAM Usage\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Because of ongoing feature additions, improvements, and optimizations, JSON memory consumption may vary depending on the Redis version.\\\\nRedis 8 in Redis Open Source was used for the examples on this page.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nEvery key in Redis takes memory and requires at least the amount of RAM to store the key name, as\\\\nwell as some per-key overhead that Redis uses. On top of that, the value in the key also requires\\\\nRAM.\\\\n\\\\nRedis JSON stores JSON values as binary data after deserialization. This representation is often more\\\\nexpensive, size-wise, than the serialized form. All JSON values occupy at least 8 bytes (on 64-bit architectures) because each is represented as a thin wrapper around a pointer. The type information is stored in the lower bits of the pointer, which are guaranteed to be zero due to alignment restrictions. This allows those bits to be repurposed to store some auxiliary data.\\\\n\\\\nFor some types of JSON values, 8 bytes is all that’s needed. Nulls and booleans don’t require any additional storage. Small integers are stored in static memory because they’re frequently used, so they also use only the initial 8 bytes. Similarly, empty strings, arrays, and objects don’t require any bookkeeping. Instead, they point to static instances of a _null_ string, array, or object. Here are some examples that use the [JSON.DEBUG MEMORY]() command to report on memory consumption:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.SET boolean . \'true\'\\\\nOK\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.DEBUG MEMORY boolean\\\\n(integer) 8\\\\n\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.SET null . null\\\\nOK\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.DEBUG MEMORY null\\\\n(integer) 8\\\\n\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.SET emptystring . \'\\\\\\"\\\\\\"\'\\\\nOK\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.DEBUG MEMORY emptystring\\\\n(integer) 8\\\\n\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.SET emptyarr . \'[]\'\\\\nOK\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.DEBUG MEMORY emptyarr\\\\n(integer) 8\\\\n\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.SET emptyobj . \'{}\'\\\\nOK\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.DEBUG MEMORY emptyobj\\\\n(integer) 8\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThis RAM requirement is the same for all scalar values, but strings require additional space\\\\ndepending on their length. For example, a 3-character string will use 3 additional bytes:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.SET foo . \'\\\\\\"bar\\\\\\"\'\\\\nOK\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.DEBUG MEMORY foo\\\\n(integer) 11\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nIn the following four examples, each array requires 56 bytes. This breaks down as:\\\\n- 8 bytes for the initial array value pointer\\\\n- 16 bytes of metadata: 8 bytes for the allocated capacity and 8 bytes for the point-in-time size of the array\\\\n- 32 bytes for the array. The initial capacity of an array is 4. Therefore, the calculation is `4 * 8` bytes\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.SET arr . \'[\\\\\\"\\\\\\"]\'\\\\nOK\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.DEBUG MEMORY arr\\\\n(integer) 56\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.SET arr . \'[\\\\\\"\\\\\\", \\\\\\"\\\\\\"]\'\\\\nOK\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.DEBUG MEMORY arr\\\\n(integer) 56\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.SET arr . \'[\\\\\\"\\\\\\", \\\\\\"\\\\\\", \\\\\\"\\\\\\"]\'\\\\nOK\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.DEBUG MEMORY arr\\\\n(integer) 56\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.SET arr . \'[\\\\\\"\\\\\\", \\\\\\"\\\\\\", \\\\\\"\\\\\\", \\\\\\"\\\\\\"]\'\\\\nOK\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.DEBUG MEMORY arr\\\\n(integer) 56\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nOnce the current capacity is insufficient to fit a new value, the array reallocates to double its capacity. An array with 5 elements will have a capacity of 8, therefore consuming `8 + 16 + 8 * 8 = 88` bytes.\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.SET arr . \'[\\\\\\"\\\\\\", \\\\\\"\\\\\\", \\\\\\"\\\\\\", \\\\\\"\\\\\\", \\\\\\"\\\\\\"]\'\\\\nOK\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.DEBUG MEMORY arr\\\\n(integer) 88\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nBecause reallocation operations can be expensive, Redis grows JSON arrays geometrically rather than linearly. This approach spreads the cost across many insertions.\\\\n\\\\nThis table gives the size (in bytes) of a few of the test files from the [module repo](https://github.com/RedisJSON/RedisJSON/tree/master/tests/files), stored using\\\\nJSON. The _MessagePack_ column is for reference purposes and reflects the length of the value when stored using [MessagePack](https://msgpack.org/index.html).\\\\n\\\\n| File                                    | File size | Redis JSON | MessagePack |\\\\n| --------------------------------------- | --------- | ---------- | ----------- |\\\\n| /tests/files/pass-100.json              | 381       | 1069       | 140         |\\\\n| /tests/files/pass-jsonsl-1.json         | 1387      | 2190       | 757         |\\\\n| /tests/files/pass-json-parser-0000.json | 3718      | 5469       | 2393        |\\\\n| /tests/files/pass-jsonsl-yahoo2.json    | 22466     | 26901      | 16869       |\\\\n| /tests/files/pass-jsonsl-yelp.json      | 46333     | 57513      | 35529       |\\\\n\\\\n> Note: In the current version, deleting values from containers **does not** free the container\'s\\\\nallocated memory.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

query: How does HyperLogLog count unique elements in Redis?
answer:
HyperLogLog in Redis is a probabilistic data structure that estimates the cardinality (count of unique elements) of a set using a clever algorithm that trades perfect accuracy for extremely efficient memory usage.

## How it works

Instead of storing actual elements (which would require memory proportional to the number of items), HyperLogLog maintains only a mathematical "state" that allows it to estimate uniqueness. The algorithm uses:

- **Constant memory**: Only 12 KB maximum, regardless of how many unique elements you're counting
- **Standard error rate**: Less than 1% (0.81% in Redis implementation)
- **Capacity**: Can estimate cardinality of sets with up to 2^64 members

## Key operations

```redis
> PFADD bikes Hyperion Deimos Phobes Quaoar
(integer) 1
> PFCOUNT bikes
(integer) 4
> PFADD commuter_bikes Salacia Mimas Quaoar
(integer) 1
> PFMERGE all_bikes bikes commuter_bikes
OK
> PFCOUNT all_bikes
(integer) 6
```

- `PFADD`: Adds an element to the HyperLogLog (O(1) time and space)
- `PFCOUNT`: Returns the estimated count of unique elements (O(1))
- `PFMERGE`: Combines multiple HyperLogLogs (O(n) where n is number of HLLs)

## Common use cases

- Counting unique visitors to a web page (especially useful when storing IP addresses is restricted by privacy laws)
- Tracking unique queries in a search form per day
- Counting unique plays of songs/videos

The magic is that you get approximate uniqueness counting with minimal memory overhead—perfect for analytics at scale where exact counts aren't critical.

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/hyperloglogs.md > Use cases]

However, a set of algorithms exist that trade \\\\nmemory for precision: they return an estimated measure with a standard error, \\\\nwhich, in the case of the Redis implementation for HyperLogLog, is less than 1%.\\\\nThe magic of this algorithm is that you no longer need to use an amount of memory\\\\nproportional to the number of items counted, and instead can use a\\\\nconstant amount of memory; 12k bytes in the worst case, or a lot less if your\\\\nHyperLogLog (We\'ll just call them HLL from now) has seen very few elements.\\\\n\\\\nHLLs in Redis, while technically a different data structure, are encoded\\\\nas a Redis string, so you can call [`GET`]() to serialize a HLL, and [`SET`]()\\\\nto deserialize it back to the server.\\\\n\\\\nConceptually the HLL API is like using Sets to do the same task. combines two or more HyperLogLogs into one.\\\\n\\\\nSee the [complete list of HyperLogLog commands](?group=hyperloglog).\\\\n\\\\nWriting ([`PFADD`]()) to and reading from ([`PFCOUNT`]()) the HyperLogLog is done in constant time and space.\\\\nMerging HLLs is O(n), where _n_ is the number of sketches.\\\\n\\\\nThe HyperLogLog can estimate the cardinality of sets with up to 18,446,744,073,709,551,616 (2^64) members.\\\\n\\\\n* [Redis new data structure: the HyperLogLog](http://antirez.com/news/75) has a lot of details about the data structure and its implementation in Redis.\\\\n* [Redis HyperLogLog Explained](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MunL8nnwscQ) shows you how to use Redis HyperLogLog data structures to build a traffic heat map.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n
