\\"title\\": \\"Redis sets\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Examples\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"A Redis set is an unordered collection of unique strings (members).\\\\nYou can use Redis sets to efficiently:\\\\n\\\\n* Track unique items (e.g., track all unique IP addresses accessing a given blog post).\\\\n* Represent relations (e.g., the set of all users with a given role).\\\\n* Perform common set operations such as intersection, unions, and differences.\\\\n\\\\n* [`SADD`]() adds a new member to a set.\\\\n* [`SREM`]() removes the specified member from the set.\\\\n* [`SISMEMBER`]() tests a string for set membership.\\\\n* [`SINTER`]() returns the set of members that two or more sets have in common (i.e., the intersection).\\\\n* [`SCARD`]() returns the size (a.k.a. cardinality) of a set.\\\\n\\\\nSee the [complete list of set commands](?group=set).\\\\n\\\\n* Store the sets of bikes racing in France and the USA. Note that\\\\nif you add a member that already exists, it will be ignored.\\\\n\\\\n> SADD bikes:racing:france bike:1\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> SADD bikes:racing:france bike:1\\\\n(integer) 0\\\\n> SADD bikes:racing:france bike:2 bike:3\\\\n(integer) 2\\\\n> SADD bikes:racing:usa bike:1 bike:4\\\\n(integer) 2\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* Check whether bike:1 or bike:2 are racing in the US.\\\\n\\\\n> SISMEMBER bikes:racing:usa bike:1\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> SISMEMBER bikes:racing:usa bike:2\\\\n(integer) 0\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* Which bikes are competing in both races?\\\\n\\\\n> SINTER bikes:racing:france bikes:racing:usa\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:1\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* How many bikes are racing in France?\\\\n\\\\n> SCARD bikes:racing:france\\\\n(integer) 3\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.0388,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"d5698fee\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"d5698fee-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/gears-v1/python/quickstart.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Event handling function registration\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Batch processing\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"For this tutorial, you need:\\\\n\\\\n- Either:\\\\n    - A Redis Software cluster with the [RedisGears module and Python plugin installed]() and [enabled on a database]()\\\\n    - A Redis Open Source database with the RedisGears module\\\\n- `redis-cli` with connectivity to a Redis database\\\\n\\\\nIn this quick start guide, we\'ll see how to use RedisGears to perform batch processing and event processing.\\\\n\\\\nWith RedisGears, **batch processing** means processing the data already stored in a Redis database. **Event processing** means processing changes to the Redis key space.\\\\n\\\\nThe examples below assume an empty Redis database.\\\\n\\\\nLet\'s start with the simplest example. From the `redis-cli`, run the following command:\\\\n\\\\n```sh\\\\nredis.cloud:6379> RG.PYEXECUTE \\\\\\"GearsBuilder().run()\\\\\\"\\\\n1) (empty array)\\\\n2) (empty array)\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThis command doesn\'t do much; it simply iterates over the keyspace. Let\'s add a key and run it again:\\\\n\\\\n```sh\\\\nredis.cloud:6379> SET message \\\\\\"hello world\\\\\\"\\\\nOK\\\\nredis.cloud:6379> RG.PYEXECUTE \\\\\\"GearsBuilder().run()\\\\\\"\\\\n1) 1) \\\\\\"{\'event\': None, \'key\': \'message\', \'type\': \'string\', \'value\': \'hello world\'}\\\\\\"\\\\n2) (empty array)\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWe\'ve added a single string, and you can see that this gears function processes it, even though it does nothing with the data. Let\'s actually do something with the data. So first, we\'ll add a few more strings:\\\\n\\\\n```sh\\\\nredis.cloud::6379> SET message:2 \\\\\\"hello galaxy\\\\\\"\\\\nOK\\\\nredis.cloud:6379> SET message:3 \\\\\\"hello universe\\\\\\"\\\\nOK\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWe now have three strings in our database. Suppose we want to perform a unique word count on these strings. We can write a RedisGears function to do this just that. So open a file called `wordcount.py`, and add the following code:\\\\n\\\\n```py\\\\ngb = GearsBuilder()\\\\ngb.map(lambda x: x[\'value\'])     # map each key object to its string value\\\\ngb.flatmap(lambda x: x.split())  # split each string into a list of words\\\\ngb.countby()                     # run a count-unique on these words\\\\ngb.run()\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThere are two ways to load files into RedisGears. For production deployments, we recommend using the special [`gears-cli`](https://github.com/gears-project/gears-cli). However, for the purpose of this demonstration, the easiest way is to pass the filename through the `redis-cli` command, like so:\\\\n\\\\n```sh\\\\n$ redis-cli rg.pyexecute \\\\\\"`cat wordcount.py`\\\\\\"\\\\n1) 1) \\\\\\"{\'key\': \'world\', \'value\': 1}\\\\\\"\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"{\'key\': \'galaxy\', \'value\': 1}\\\\\\"\\\\n   3) \\\\\\"{\'key\': \'hello\', \'value\': 3}\\\\\\"\\\\n   4) \\\\\\"{\'key\': \'universe\', \'value\': 1}\\\\\\"\\\\n2) (empty array)\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThe results here show the number of occurrences of each word in all of our strings. So, we\'ve effectively processed the data in our Redis database all at once, in a batch.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.0306,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"7aa61062\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"7aa61062-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/sorted-sets.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis sorted sets\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"A Redis sorted set is a collection of unique strings (members) ordered by an associated score.\\\\nWhen more than one string has the same score, the strings are ordered lexicographically.\\\\nSome use cases for sorted sets include:\\\\n\\\\n* Leaderboards. For example, you can use sorted sets to easily maintain  ordered lists of the highest scores in a massive online game.\\\\n* Rate limiters. In particular, you can use a sorted set to build a sliding-window rate limiter to prevent excessive API requests.\\\\n\\\\nYou can think of sorted sets as a mix between a Set and\\\\na Hash. Like sets, sorted sets are composed of unique, non-repeating\\\\nstring elements, so in some sense a sorted set is a set as well.\\\\n\\\\nHowever while elements inside sets are not ordered, every element in\\\\na sorted set is associated with a floating point value, called *the score*\\\\n(this is why the type is also similar to a hash, since every element\\\\nis mapped to a value).\\\\n\\\\nMoreover, elements in a sorted set are *taken in order* (so they are not\\\\nordered on request, order is a peculiarity of the data structure used to\\\\nrepresent sorted sets). They are ordered according to the following rule:\\\\n\\\\n* If B and A are two elements with a different score, then A > B if A.score is > B.score.\\\\n* If B and A have exactly the same score, then A > B if the A string is lexicographically greater than the B string. B and A strings can\'t be equal since sorted sets only have unique elements.\\\\n\\\\nLet\'s start with a simple example, we\'ll add all our racers and the score they got in the first race:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> ZADD racer_scores 10 \\\\\\"Norem\\\\\\"\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> ZADD racer_scores 12 \\\\\\"Castilla\\\\\\"\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> ZADD racer_scores 8 \\\\\\"Sam-Bodden\\\\\\" 10 \\\\\\"Royce\\\\\\" 6 \\\\\\"Ford\\\\\\" 14 \\\\\\"Prickett\\\\\\"\\\\n(integer) 4\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nAs you can see [`ZADD`]() is similar to [`SADD`](), but takes one additional argument\\\\n(placed before the element to be added) which is the score.\\\\n[`ZADD`]() is also variadic, so you are free to specify multiple score-value\\\\npairs, as shown in the example above.\\\\n\\\\nWith sorted sets it is trivial to return a list of racers sorted by their\\\\nscore because actually *they are already sorted*.\\\\n\\\\nImplementation note: Sorted sets are implemented via a\\\\ndual-ported data structure containing both a skip list and a hash table, so\\\\nevery time we add an element Redis performs an O(log(N)) operation. That\'s\\\\ngood, so when we ask for sorted elements, Redis does not have to do any work at\\\\nall, it\'s already sorted. Note that the [`ZRANGE`]() order is low to high, while the [`ZREVRANGE`]() order is high to low:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> ZRANGE racer_scores 0 -1\\\\n1) \\\\\\"Ford\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"Sam-Bodden\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"Norem\\\\\\"\\\\n4) \\\\\\"Royce\\\\\\"\\\\n5) \\\\\\"Castilla\\\\\\"\\\\n6) \\\\\\"Prickett\\\\\\"\\\\n> ZREVRANGE racer_scores 0 -1\\\\n1) \\\\\\"Prickett\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"Castilla\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"Royce\\\\\\"\\\\n4) \\\\\\"Norem\\\\\\"\\\\n5) \\\\\\"Sam-Bodden\\\\\\"\\\\n6) \\\\\\"Ford\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nNote: 0 and -1 means from element index 0 to the last element (-1 works\\\\nhere just as it does in the case of the [`LRANGE`]() command).\\\\n\\\\nIt is possible to return scores as well, using the `WITHSCORES` argument:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> ZRANGE racer_scores 0 -1 withscores\\\\n 1) \\\\\\"Ford\\\\\\"\\\\n 2) \\\\\\"6\\\\\\"\\\\n 3) \\\\\\"Sam-Bodden\\\\\\"\\\\n 4) \\\\\\"8\\\\\\"\\\\n 5) \\\\\\"Norem\\\\\\"\\\\n 6) \\\\\\"10\\\\\\"\\\\n 7) \\\\\\"Royce\\\\\\"\\\\n 8) \\\\\\"10\\\\\\"\\\\n 9) \\\\\\"Castilla\\\\\\"\\\\n10) \\\\\\"12\\\\\\"\\\\n11) \\\\\\"Prickett\\\\\\"\\\\n12) \\\\\\"14\\\\\\"\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text='HyperLogLog in Redis is a probabilistic data structure that estimates the cardinality (count of unique elements) of a set using a clever algorithm that trades perfect accuracy for extremely efficient memory usage.

## How it works

Instead of storing actual elements (which would require memory proportional to the number of items), HyperLogLog maintains only a mathematical "state" that allows it to estimate uniqueness. The algorithm uses:

- **Constant memory**: Only 12 KB maximum, regardless of how many unique elements you're counting
- **Standard error rate**: Less than 1% (0.81% in Redis implementation)
- **Capacity**: Can estimate cardinality of sets with up to 2^64 members

## Key operations

```redis
> PFADD bikes Hyperion Deimos Phobes Quaoar
(integer) 1
> PFCOUNT bikes
(integer) 4
> PFADD commuter_bikes Salacia Mimas Quaoar
(integer) 1
> PFMERGE all_bikes bikes commuter_bikes
OK
> PFCOUNT all_bikes
(integer) 6
```

- `PFADD`: Adds an element to the HyperLogLog (O(1) time and space)
- `PFCOUNT`: Returns the estimated count of unique elements (O(1))
- `PFMERGE`: Combines multiple HyperLogLogs (O(n) where n is number of HLLs)

## Common use cases

- Counting unique visitors to a web page (especially useful when storing IP addresses is restricted by privacy laws)
- Tracking unique queries in a search form per day
- Counting unique plays of songs/videos

The magic is that you get approximate uniqueness counting with minimal memory overhead—perfect for analytics at scale where exact counts aren't critical.

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/hyperloglogs.md > Use cases]')]

messages.result:
HyperLogLog in Redis is a probabilistic data structure that estimates the cardinality (count of unique elements) of a set using a clever algorithm that trades perfect accuracy for extremely efficient memory usage.

## How it works

Instead of storing actual elements (which would require memory proportional to the number of items), HyperLogLog maintains only a mathematical "state" that allows it to estimate uniqueness. The algorithm uses:

- **Constant memory**: Only 12 KB maximum, regardless of how many unique elements you're counting
- **Standard error rate**: Less than 1% (0.81% in Redis implementation)
- **Capacity**: Can estimate cardinality of sets with up to 2^64 members

## Key operations

```redis
> PFADD bikes Hyperion Deimos Phobes Quaoar
(integer) 1
> PFCOUNT bikes
(integer) 4
> PFADD commuter_bikes Salacia Mimas Quaoar
(integer) 1
> PFMERGE all_bikes bikes commuter_bikes
OK
> PFCOUNT all_bikes
(integer) 6
```

- `PFADD`: Adds an element to the HyperLogLog (O(1) time and space)
- `PFCOUNT`: Returns the estimated count of unique elements (O(1))
- `PFMERGE`: Combines multiple HyperLogLogs (O(n) where n is number of HLLs)

## Common use cases

- Counting unique visitors to a web page (especially useful when storing IP addresses is restricted by privacy laws)
- Tracking unique queries in a search form per day
- Counting unique plays of songs/videos

The magic is that you get approximate uniqueness counting with minimal memory overhead—perfect for analytics at scale where exact counts aren't critical.

query: Redis Lists 作为消息队列和 Streams 有什么区别？
answer:
根据检索结果，我找到了 Redis Lists 和 Streams 作为消息队列的相关信息。让我为你总结它们的区别：

## Redis Lists vs Streams 作为消息队列的区别

### 1. 数据结构实现

**Lists**：
- 基于链表（Linked Lists）实现
- 在头部或尾部添加元素是常数时间操作 O(1)
- 按索引访问元素较慢（需要遍历）
- 适合实现栈和队列，以及后台任务队列管理

**Streams**：
- 使用 Radix Tree 索引实现（与 Lists 的链表结构不同）
- 专为流式数据处理设计
- 提供真正的流式 API（real streaming API），数据一进入就立即处理

### 2. 消息处理能力

**Lists**：
- 基本命令：`LPUSH`/`RPUSH`（添加）、`LPOP`/`RPOP`（移除）、`LMOVE`（原子移动）
- 简单的生产者-消费者模式
- 无内置的消费者组（Consumer Group）概念

**Streams**：
- 支持消费者组（Consumer Groups）
- 提供幂等性保证（at-most-once guarantee）
- 新增 `IDMPAUTO` 和 `IDMP` 参数实现消息去重
- 支持消息确认（ACK）机制

### 3. 数据保留策略

**Lists**：
- 使用 `LTRIM` 按范围限制列表长度
- 按消息数量（count）进行限制

**Streams**：
- 支持基于时间窗口的保留策略（retention policy in milliseconds）
- 更适合时间序列场景，可以保留"最近 N 毫秒"的数据
- 支持 `XTRIM` 命令和多种修剪策略（如 `DELREF`/`ACKED`）

### 4. 使用场景

**Lists 适合**：
- 简单的任务队列
- 后台 worker 系统
- 需要快速头尾操作的场景

**Streams 适合**：
- 需要消费者组协作的场景
- 需要消息去重和幂等性保证
- 基于时间窗口的数据处理
- 需要消息确认机制的可靠队列

---

**[来源]**：
- `/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/lists.md > Basic commands`
- `/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md > v1.0.0 (June 2019) > Features`
- `/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/deprecated-features/triggers-and-functions/concepts/triggers/Stream_Triggers.md`

With Streams, you can create a [capped stream](, effectively limiting the number of messages by count. In RedisTimeSeries, you can apply a retention policy in milliseconds. This is better for time series use cases, because they are typically interested in the data during a given time window, rather than a fixed number of samples.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.5967,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"43b5f91b\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"43b5f91b-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/lists.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis lists\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Basic commands\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Redis lists are linked lists of string values.\\\\nRedis lists are frequently used to:\\\\n\\\\n* Implement stacks and queues.\\\\n* Build queue management for background worker systems.\\\\n\\\\n* [`LPUSH`]() adds a new element to the head of a list; [`RPUSH`]() adds to the tail.\\\\n* [`LPOP`]() removes and returns an element from the head of a list; [`RPOP`]() does the same but from the tails of a list. \\\\n* [`LLEN`]() returns the length of a list.\\\\n* [`LMOVE`]() atomically moves elements from one list to another.\\\\n* [`LRANGE`]() extracts a range of elements from a list.\\\\n* [`LTRIM`]() reduces a list to the specified range of elements.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.0599,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"4103dc5c\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"4103dc5c-001\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/deprecated-features/triggers-and-functions/concepts/triggers/Stream_Triggers.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Stream triggers\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Register a stream consumer\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Triggers and functions provide an API that allows to register a stream trigger. Do not get confused with [Redis streams consumer groups](), triggers and functions uses the Redis Module API to efficiently read the stream and manage its consumers. This approach gives a much better performance as there is no need to invoke any Redis commands in order to read from the stream. Lets see a simple example:\\\\n\\\\n```js\\\\n#!js api_version=1.0 name=myFirstLibrary\\\\n\\\\nredis.registerStreamTrigger(\\\\n    \\\\\\"consumer\\\\\\", // consumer name\\\\n    \\\\\\"stream\\\\\\", // streams prefix\\\\n    function(c, data) {\\\\n        // callback to run on each element added to the stream\\\\n        redis.log(JSON.stringify(data, (key, value) =>\\\\n            typeof value === \'bigint\'\\\\n                ? value.toString()\\\\n                : value // return everything else unchanged\\\\n        ));\\\\n    }\\\\n);\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nArgument Description:\\\\n\\\\n* consumer - the consumer name.\\\\n* stream - streams name prefix on which to trigger the callback.\\\\n* callback - the callback to invoke on each element in the stream. Following the same rules of [sync and async invocation](). The callback will be invoke only on primary shard.\\\\n\\\\nIf we register this library (see the [quick start]() section to learn how to Register a RedisGears function) and run the following command on our Redis:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nXADD stream:1 * foo1 bar1\\\\nXADD stream:1 * foo2 bar2\\\\nXADD stream:2 * foo1 bar1\\\\nXADD stream:2 * foo2 bar2\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWe will see the following line on the Redis log file:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n2630021:M 05 Jul 2022 17:13:22.506 * <redisgears_2> {\\\\\\"id\\\\\\":[\\\\\\"1657030402506\\\\\\",\\\\\\"0\\\\\\"],\\\\\\"stream_name\\\\\\":\\\\\\"stream:1\\\\\\",\\\\\\"record\\\\\\":[[\\\\\\"foo1\\\\\\",\\\\\\"bar1\\\\\\"]]}\\\\n2630021:M 05 Jul 2022 17:13:25.323 * <redisgears_2> {\\\\\\"id\\\\\\":[\\\\\\"1657030405323\\\\\\",\\\\\\"0\\\\\\"],\\\\\\"stream_name\\\\\\":\\\\\\"stream:1\\\\\\",\\\\\\"record\\\\\\":[[\\\\\\"foo2\\\\\\",\\\\\\"bar2\\\\\\"]]}\\\\n2630021:M 05 Jul 2022 17:13:29.475 * <redisgears_2> {\\\\\\"id\\\\\\":[\\\\\\"1657030409475\\\\\\",\\\\\\"0\\\\\\"],\\\\\\"stream_name\\\\\\":\\\\\\"stream:2\\\\\\",\\\\\\"record\\\\\\":[[\\\\\\"foo1\\\\\\",\\\\\\"bar1\\\\\\"]]}\\\\n2630021:M 05 Jul 2022 17:13:32.715 * <redisgears_2> {\\\\\\"id\\\\\\":[\\\\\\"1657030412715\\\\\\",\\\\\\"0\\\\\\"],\\\\\\"stream_name\\\\\\":\\\\\\"stream:2\\\\\\",\\\\\\"record\\\\\\":[[\\\\\\"foo2\\\\\\",\\\\\\"bar2\\\\\\"]]}\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThe `data` argument which pass to the stream consumer callback are in the following format:\\\\n\\\\n```json\\\\n{\\\\n    \\\\\\"id\\\\\\": [\\\\\\"<ms>\\\\\\", \\\\\\"<seq>\\\\\\"],\\\\n [\\\\\\"<key>\\\\\\", \\\\\\"<value>\\\\\\"],\\\\n        .\\\\n        .\\\\n        [\\\\\\"<key>\\\\\\", \\\\\\"<value>\\\\\\"]\\\\n    ],\\\\n    \\\\\\"record_raw\\\\\\":[\\\\n        [\\\\\\"<key_raw>\\\\\\", \\\\\\"<value_raw>\\\\\\"],\\\\n        .\\\\n        .\\\\n        [\\\\\\"<key_raw>\\\\\\", \\\\\\"<value_raw>\\\\\\"]\\\\n    ],\\\\n}\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThe reason why the record is a list of touples and not an object is because the Redis Stream specifications allows duplicate keys.\\\\n\\\\nNotice that `stream_name` and `record` fields might contains `null`\'s if the \\"Idempotency modes > Automatic mode (`IDMPAUTO`)\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Specify both producer ID (pid) and iid explicitly:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nXADD mystream IDMP producer1 msg1 * field value\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n- `pid`: Unique identifier for the message producer.\\\\n- `iid`: Unique identifier for a specific message.\\\\n- Performance: Faster processing (no hash calculation).\\\\n- Control: Full control over ID generation and uniqueness.\\\\n\\\\nSpecify only the pid; Redis generates the iid from message content:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nXADD mystream IDMPAUTO producer1 * field value\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n- `pid`: Unique identifier for the message producer.\\\\n- Automatic deduplication: Redis calculates an iid from field-value pairs.\\\\n- Content-based: The same content produces the same iid.\\\\n- Performance: Slightly slower due to hash calculation.\\\\n\\\\nFor both IDMP and IDMPAUTO, each producer application is required to use the same pid after it restarts.\\\\n\\\\nFor IDMP, each producer application is responsible for:\\\\n\\\\n- Providing a unique iid for each entry (either globally, or just for each pid).\\\\n- Reusing the same (pid, iid) specification\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Network layer\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"To communicate with the Redis server, Redis clients use a protocol called Redis Serialization Protocol (RESP).\\\\nWhile the protocol was designed specifically for Redis, you can use it for other client-server software projects.\\\\n\\\\nRESP is a compromise among the following considerations:\\\\n\\\\n* Simple to implement.\\\\n* Fast to parse.\\\\n* Human readable.\\\\n\\\\nRESP can serialize different data types including integers, strings, and arrays.\\\\nIt also features an error-specific type.\\\\nA client sends a request to the Redis server as an array of strings.\\\\nThe array\'s contents are the command and its arguments that the server should execute.\\\\nThe server\'s reply type is command-specific.\\\\n\\\\nRESP is binary-safe and uses prefixed length to transfer bulk data so it does not require processing bulk data transferred from one process to another.\\\\n\\\\nRESP is the protocol you should implement in your Redis client.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nThe protocol outlined here is used only for client-server communication.\\\\n[Redis Cluster]() uses a different binary protocol for exchanging messages between nodes.\\\\n\\\\nSupport for the first version of the RESP protocol was introduced in Redis 1.2.\\\\nUsing RESP with Redis 1.2 was optional and had mainly served the purpose of working the kinks out of the protocol.\\\\n\\\\nIn Redis 2.0, the protocol\'s next version, a.k.a RESP2, became the standard communication method for clients with the Redis server.\\\\n\\\\n[RESP3](https://github.com/redis/redis-specifications/blob/master/protocol/RESP3.md) is a superset of RESP2 that mainly aims to make a client author\'s life a little bit easier.\\\\nRedis 6.0 introduced experimental opt-in support of RESP3\'s features (excluding streaming strings and streaming aggregates).\\\\nIn addition, the introduction of the [`HELLO`]() command allows clients to handshake and upgrade the connection\'s protocol version (see [Client handshake](#client-handshake)).\\\\n\\\\nFrom Redis version 7 and forward, both RESP2 and RESP3 clients can invoke all core commands.\\\\nHowever, commands may return differently typed replies for different protocol versions.\\\\nEach command has descriptions of RESP2 and RESP3 return values that you can reference.\\\\n\\\\nFuture versions of Redis may change the default protocol version, but it is unlikely that RESP2 will become entirely deprecated.\\\\nIt is possible, however, that new features in upcoming versions will require the use of RESP3.\\\\n\\\\nA client connects to a Redis server by creating a TCP connection to its port (the default is 6379).\\\\n\\\\nWhile RESP is technically non-TCP specific, the protocol is used exclusively with TCP connections (or equivalent stream-oriented connections like Unix sockets) in the context of Redis.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n [TextBlock(text='根据检索结果，我找到了 Redis Lists 和 Streams 作为消息队列的相关信息。让我为你总结它们的区别：

## Redis Lists vs Streams 作为消息队列的区别

### 1. 数据结构实现

**Lists**：
- 基于链表（Linked Lists）实现
- 在头部或尾部添加元素是常数时间操作 O(1)
- 按索引访问元素较慢（需要遍历）
- 适合实现栈和队列，以及后台任务队列管理

**Streams**：
- 使用 Radix Tree 索引实现（与 Lists 的链表结构不同）
- 专为流式数据处理设计
- 提供真正的流式 API（real streaming API），数据一进入就立即处理

### 2. 消息处理能力

**Lists**：
- 基本命令：`LPUSH`/`RPUSH`（添加）、`LPOP`/`RPOP`（移除）、`LMOVE`（原子移动）
- 简单的生产者-消费者模式
- 无内置的消费者组（Consumer Group）概念

**Streams**：
- 支持消费者组（Consumer Groups）
- 提供幂等性保证（at-most-once guarantee）
- 新增 `IDMPAUTO` 和 `IDMP` 参数实现消息去重
- 支持消息确认（ACK）机制

### 3. 数据保留策略

**Lists**：
- 使用 `LTRIM` 按范围限制列表长度
- 按消息数量（count）进行限制

**Streams**：
- 支持基于时间窗口的保留策略（retention policy in milliseconds）
- 更适合时间序列场景，可以保留"最近 N 毫秒"的数据
- 支持 `XTRIM` 命令和多种修剪策略（如 `DELREF`/`ACKED`）

### 4. 使用场景

**Lists 适合**：
- 简单的任务队列
- 后台 worker 系统
- 需要快速头尾操作的场景

**Streams 适合**：
- 需要消费者组协作的场景
- 需要消息去重和幂等性保证
- 基于时间窗口的数据处理
- 需要消息确认机制的可靠队列

---

**[来源]**：
- `/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/lists.md > Basic commands`
- `/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md > v1.0.0 (June 2019) > Features`
- `/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/deprecated-features/triggers-and-functions/concepts/triggers/Stream_Triggers.md`')]

query: What are Redis Bitfields and when would I use them?
answer:
Based on the search results, here's what Redis Bitfields are and when to use them:

## What are Redis Bitfields?

Redis Bitfields let you **set, increment, and get integer values of arbitrary bit length**. You can operate on anything from unsigned 1-bit integers to signed 63-bit integers. These values are stored using binary-encoded Redis strings and support **atomic read, write, and increment operations**.

## Key Commands

- `BITFIELD` - atomically sets, increments, and reads one or more values
- `BITFIELD_RO` - read-only variant of BITFIELD

## When to Use Them

Bitfields are ideal for **managing counters and similar numerical values** where you need:

1. **Multiple related counters in a single key** - Store several metrics together efficiently
2. **Atomic operations** - Update multiple counters atomically in one command
3. **Space efficiency** - Pack multiple integer values into a single Redis string

## Practical Example

The documentation shows a bicycle tracking system with two 32-bit counters per bike:
- Counter at offset 0: current price
- Counter at offset 1: number of owners

```redis
> BITFIELD bike:1:stats SET u32 #0 1000
1) (integer) 0

> BITFIELD bike:1:stats INCRBY u32 #0 -50 INCRBY u32 #1 1
1) (integer) 950
2) (integer) 1

> BITFIELD bike:1:stats INCRBY u32 #0 500 INCRBY u32 #1 1
1) (integer) 1450
2) (integer) 2

> BITFIELD bike:1:stats GET u32 #0 GET u32 #1
1) (integer) 1450
2) (integer) 2
```

This atomically updates price and owner count in a single operation, making bitfields perfect for scenarios where you need to maintain multiple related metrics per entity.

**Performance**: `BITFIELD` is O(n), where n is the number of counters accessed.

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/bitfields.md > Performance]

commands you can treat the Redis string type as a random access array.\\\\nFor instance, if you have an application where users are identified by a unique progressive integer number,\\\\nyou can use a bitmap to save information about the subscription of users in a mailing list,\\\\nsetting the bit for subscribed and clearing it for unsubscribed, or the other way around.\\\\nWith 100 million users this data will take just 12 megabytes of RAM in a Redis instance.\\\\nYou can do the same using [`GETRANGE`](/commands/getrange) and [`SETRANGE`](/commands/setrange) to store one byte of information \\"09b2bae2\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"09b2bae2-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/bitmaps.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis bitmaps\\",\\n which is treated like a bit vector.\\\\nSince strings are binary safe blobs and their maximum length is 512 MB,\\\\nthey are suitable to set up to 2^32 different bits.\\\\n\\\\nYou can perform bitwise operations on one or more strings.\\\\nSome examples of bitmap use cases include:\\\\n\\\\n* Efficient set representations for cases where the members of a set correspond to the integers 0-N.\\\\n* Object permissions, where each bit represents a particular permission, similar to the way that file systems store permissions.\\\\n\\\\n* [`SETBIT`]() sets a bit at the provided offset to 0 or 1.\\\\n* [`GETBIT`]() returns the value of a bit at a given offset.\\\\n\\\\nSee the [complete list of bitmap commands](?group=bitmap).\\\\n\\\\nSuppose you have 1000 cyclists racing through the country-side, with sensors on their bikes labeled 0-999.\\\\nYou want to quickly determine whether a given sensor has pinged a tracking server within the hour to check in on a rider. \\\\n\\\\nYou can represent this scenario using a bitmap whose key references the current hour.\\\\n\\\\n* Rider 123 pings the server on January 1, 2024 within the 00:00 hour. You can then confirm that rider 123 pinged the server. You can also check to see if rider 456 has pinged the server for that same hour.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> SETBIT pings:2024-01-01-00:00 123 1\\\\n(integer) 0\\\\n> GETBIT pings:2024-01-01-00:00 123\\\\n1\\\\n> GETBIT pings:2024-01-01-00:00 456\\\\n0\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.1276,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"43b5f91b\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"43b5f91b-005\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/lists.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis lists\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Examples > Capped lists\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Lists are useful for a number of tasks, two very representative use cases\\\\nare the following:\\\\n\\\\n* Remember the latest updates posted by users into a social network.\\\\n* Communication between processes, using a consumer-producer pattern where the producer pushes items into a list, and a consumer (usually a *worker*) consumes those items and executes actions. Redis has special list commands to make this use case both more reliable and efficient.\\\\n\\\\nFor example both the popular Ruby libraries [resque](https://github.com/resque/resque) and\\\\n[sidekiq](https://github.com/mperham/sidekiq) use Redis lists under the hood in order to\\\\nimplement background jobs.\\\\n\\\\nThe popular Twitter social network [takes the latest tweets](http://www.infoq.com/presentations/Real-Time-Delivery-Twitter)\\\\nposted by users into Redis lists.\\\\n\\\\nTo describe a common use case step by step, imagine your home page shows the latest\\\\nphotos published in a photo sharing social network and you want to speedup access.\\\\n\\\\n* Every time a user posts a new photo, we add its ID into a list with [`LPUSH`]().\\\\n* When users visit the home page, we use `LRANGE 0 9` in order to get the latest 10 posted items.\\\\n\\\\nIn many use cases we just want to use lists to store the *latest items*,\\\\nwhatever they are: social network updates, logs, or anything else.\\\\n\\\\nRedis allows us to use lists as a capped collection, only remembering the latest\\\\nN items and discarding all the oldest items using the [`LTRIM`]() command.\\\\n\\\\nThe [`LTRIM`]() command is similar to [`LRANGE`](), but **instead of displaying the\\\\nspecified range of elements** it sets this range as the new list value. All\\\\nthe elements outside the given range are removed.\\\\n\\\\nFor example, if you\'re adding bikes on the end of a list of repairs, but only\\\\nwant to worry about the 3 that have been on the list the longest:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL bikes:repairs\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3 bike:4 bike:5\\\\n(integer) 5\\\\n> LTRIM bikes:repairs 0 2\\\\nOK\\\\n> LRANGE bikes:repairs 0 -1\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:1\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"bike:2\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"bike:3\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nThe above [`LTRIM`]() command tells Redis to keep just list elements from index\\\\n0 to 2, everything else will be discarded. This allows for a very simple but\\\\nuseful pattern: doing a List push operation + a List trim operation together \\\\nto add a new element and discard elements exceeding a limit. Using \\\\n[`LTRIM`]() with negative indexes can then be used to keep only the 3 most recently added:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL bikes:repairs\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3 bike:4 bike:5\\\\n(integer) 5\\\\n> LTRIM bikes:repairs -3 -1\\\\nOK\\\\n> LRANGE bikes:repairs 0 -1\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:3\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"bike:4\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"bike:5\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nThe above combination adds new elements and keeps only the 3\\\\nnewest elements into the list. With [`LRANGE`]() you can access the top items\\\\nwithout any need to remember very old data.\\\\n\\\\nNote: while [`LRANGE`]() is technically an O(N) command, accessing small ranges\\\\ntowards the head or the tail of the list is a constant time operation.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

query: How to store and query geospatial data in Redis?
answer:
Redis provides built-in geospatial data support through its **Geospatial indexes** data type. Here's how to store and query geospatial data:

## Storing Geospatial Data

Use the `GEOADD` command to add locations with their coordinates (longitude, latitude):

```redis
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.27652 37.805186 station:1
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.2674626 37.8062344 station:2
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.2469854 37.8104049 station:3
```

**Important**: Longitude comes before latitude in this command.

## Querying Geospatial Data

Use `GEOSEARCH` to find locations within a radius or bounding box:

```redis
GEOSEARCH bikes:rentable FROMLONLAT -122.2612767 37.7936847 BYRADIUS 5 km WITHDIST
```

This returns locations within 5km of the specified coordinates along with their distances:

```
1) 1) "station:1"
   2) "1.8523"
2) 1) "station:2"
   2) "1.4979"
3) 1) "station:3"
   2) "2.2441"
```

## Use Cases

Geospatial indexes are ideal for:
- Finding nearby points within a given radius
- Location-based searches (e.g., bike rental stations, restaurants, stores)
- Proximity queries with distance calculations

## Advanced: Geo Polygons (Redis Stack 7.2+)

For more complex shapes, Redis Stack 7.2 introduced `GEOSHAPE` field type supporting polygon queries:

- Supports `POLYGON` and `POINT` shapes using WKT notation
- Enables `WITHIN` and `CONTAINS` operations
- Supports both cartesian (X,Y) and geographic (lon, lat) coordinate systems

**Note**: The basic Geospatial data type is simpler and suitable for most use cases. For advanced format options and complex queries, consider Redis Query Engine's geospatial features.

[来源: redis-docs/develop/data-types/geospatial.md]  
[来源: redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisstack/redisstack-7.2-release-notes.md > Redis Stack 7.2.0-v0 > Headlines]

Notes\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Stack 7.2.0-v0 (August 2023) > Headlines:\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"Redis server 7.2 introduces significant memory and speed Redis 7.2 brings behavior changes by introducing a new format (version 11) for RDB files, which is incompatible with older versions, changing module API, and other changes.\\\\n\\\\n**Search and Query**:\\\\nThis new major version introduces the frequently asked [Geo Polygon](https://redis.io/commands/ft.search/#examples) Search. Adding the [GEOSHAPE](https://redis.io/commands/ft.create/) field type that supports polygon shapes using the [WKT notation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Well-known_text_representation_of_geometry). In addition to the existing `GEO` for geo range queries, now an alias for `GEOPOINT`, we add `GEOSHAPE` with the support for `POLYGON` and `POINT` as new shapes formats and polygons operations.\\\\n\\\\nIn addition, 7.2 brings improvements in performance for `SORT BY` operations using [`FT.SEARCH`](https://redis.io/commands/ft.search/#optional-arguments) and [`FT.AGGREGATE`](https://redis.io/commands/ft.aggregate/#optional-arguments), and the new `FORMAT` for better readability and future support for better error handling responses on `FT.SEARCH` and `FT.AGGREGATE` in RESP3 only.\\\\n\\\\n**JSON**:\\\\nJSON introduces two new commands:\\\\n - [JSON.MERGE](https://redis.io/commands/json.merge/) merges a given JSON value into matching paths so that the JSON values at the matching paths are updated, deleted, or expanded.\\\\n - [JSON.MSET](https://redis.io/commands/json.mset/) sets or updates one or more JSON values according to specified key-path-value triplets.\\\\n\\\\n**Graph**:\\\\n\\\\nGraph capabilities are no longer included in Redis Stack. See the [RedisGraph End-of-Life Announcement](https://redis.com/blog/redisgraph-eol/).\\\\n\\\\n> [!WARNING] \\\\nIf you are using graph capabilities with an older version of Redis Stack - please don\'t upgrade.\\\\n\\\\n**Triggers and functions preview**:\\\\nTriggers and functions is part of Redis Stack 7.2 as public preview, any feedback is highly appreciated.\\\\n\\\\nTriggers and functions provides support for running JavaScript functions inside the Redis process. These functions can be executed on-demand, by an event-driven trigger, or by a stream processing trigger. Triggers and functions empowers developers to build and maintain real-time applications by moving logic closer to the data, ensuring a lower latency whilst delivering the best developer experience.\\\\n\\\\nTry it out with the [triggers and functions quick start](https://redis.io/docs/interact/programmability/triggers-and-functions/quick_start/).\\"\\n },\\n {\\n \\"score\\": 1.1558,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"9f4edca5\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"9f4edca5-000\\",\\n \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/search/commands.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Commands\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"The following table lists search and query commands. Geographic coordinate system using spherical indexing as default (`SPHERICAL`).\\\\n * [#3046](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3046) Introduce performance optimization for sorting operations on `FT.SEARCH` and `FT.AGGREGATE` as default on `DIALECT 4`. It will improve performance in 4 different scenarios, listed below:\\\\n * Skip Sorter - applied when there is no sort of any kind. The query can return once it reaches the `LIMIT` requested results.\\\\n * Partial Range - applied when there is a `SORTBY` a numeric field, with no filter or filter by the same numeric field, the query iterate on a range large enough to satisfy the `LIMIT` requested results.\\\\n * Hybrid - applied when there is a `SORTBY` a numeric field in addition to another non-numeric filter. Some results will get filtered, and the initial range may not be large enough. The iterator then is rewinded with the following ranges, and an additional iteration takes place to collect `LIMIT` requested results.\\\\n * No optimization - If there is a sort by score or by non-numeric field, there is no other option but to retrieve all results and compare their values.\\\\n * [#3651](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3651) Add `WITHCOUNT` argument that allow return accurate counts for the query results with sorting. This operation processes all results in order to get accurate count, being less performant than the optimised option (default behaviour on `DIALECT 4`).\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* **JSON**:\\\\n * [#916](https://github.com/RedisJSON/RedisJSON/pull/916) Introduce the new `JSON.MERGE` in compliance with [RFC 7396](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7396), supporting:\\\\n * Creating new attributes on an existing JSON document\\\\n * Updating and replacing values in parent and child attributes\\\\n * Deleting existing attributes (giving `null` as value)\\\\n * Array update - replacing an entire array with the new value.\\\\n * [#944](https://github.com/RedisJSON/RedisJSON/pull/944) Introduce `JSON.MSET`, supporting atomic multiple sets for keys in the same hash slot.\\\\n\\\\n* **Triggers and Functions**:\\\\n * [#875](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/875) The api_version was added to the library prologue indicating the minimum required API version. Indicating the library works on the specified API version and later minor versions.\\\\n[#896](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/896) Additional optional callback on a KeySpace trigger that can perform read operations exactly when the notification happens.\\\\n * [#910](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/910) The JavaScript API is updated to be inline with JavaScript best practices. Registrations of functions and triggers is done with mandatory arguments and a single optional object.\\\\n * [#935](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/935) Ability to load an RDB from a Redis Server with the RedisGears module loaded but NOT used into a Redis Server without the RedisGears module.\\\\n * Updated commands:\\\\n * [#910](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/910) `TFUNCTION` and `TFCALL` is used instead of `RG.FUNCTION` and `RG.FCALL`.\\\\n * [#939](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/939) The commands are updated to match the Redis Functions commands. `TFCALL` combines the library and function in a single argument with \'.\' separated. Example: `TFCALL .`.\\\\n * [#900](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/900) rated the ability to run functions as a coroutine in `TFCALLASYNC`. Clients rely on `TFCALL` to never block shared connections so other commands are not delayed on such connections.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n **Improvements**\\\\n* **Search and Query**:\\\\n * [#3641](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3641) Indexing sanitizing trigger in heavily data updates scenario.\\\\n * [#3614](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3614) Several improvements in the aggregations execution pipeline.\\\\n\\\\n* **Triggers and Functions**:\\\\n * [#906](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/906) Limit the total memory usage of all combined libraries, the values can be configured during module load.\\\\n * [#940](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/940) Validate the current memory usage when uploading a new library to not exceed the max memory limit.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n**Changed Behavior**\\\\n* **Search and Query**:\\\\n * [#3355](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3355), [#3635](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3635) Expired keys deleted from slave\'s index, returning an empty array instead of `nil`.\\\\n\\\\n**Bug Fixes**\\\\n* **Search and Query**:\\\\n * [#3597](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3597) Duplicating alias as output name on `FT.AGGREGATE` reducer (`REDUCE` argument) isn\'t return results.\\\\n * [#3654](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3654) Added check for `@` prefix on `GROUPBY` fields returnig an error instead of wrong results.\\\\n * [#3501](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3501) Sorting by 2 or more fields follow the order not ignoring the second argument.\\\\n * [#3582](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3582) Sorter will set lower rank in documents expired during query time, preventing clients to freeze.\\\\n\\\\n* **JSON**:\\\\n * [#1025](https://github.com/RedisJSON/RedisJSON/pull/1025) `JSON.TOGGLE` key space notification fix.\\\\n\\\\n* **Time series**:\\\\n * [#1471](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/RedisTimeSeries/pull/1471) Potential crash on `MRANGE` when aggregating millions of time series.\\\\n * [#1469](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/RedisTimeSeries/pull/1469) Potential memory leak in `MRANGE` after eviction.\\\\n\\\\n* **Triggers and Functions**:\\\\n * [#913](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/913) Do not trigger notifications when Redis is loading from a persistence file.\\\\n\\\\n**Redis version**\\\\n* __[Redis 7.2 RC2](https://github.com/redis/redis/blob/7.2/00-RELEASENOTES)__\\\\n\\\\n**Module versions**\\\\t\\\\n* __[RediSearch 2.8.3](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/releases/tag/v2.8.3)__\\\\n* __[RedisJSON 2.6.2](https://github.com/RedisJSON/RedisJSON/releases/tag/v2.6.2)__\\\\n* __[RedisTimeSeries 1.10.1](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/RedisTimeSeries/releases/tag/v1.10.1)__\\\\n* __[RedisBloom 2.6.1](https://github.com/RedisBloom/RedisBloom/releases/tag/v2.6.1)__\\\\n* __[RedisGears 2.0.6](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/releases/tag/v2.0.6-m07)__\\\\n\\\\n**Recommended Client Libraries**\\\\n* Java\\\\n * [Jedis 4.4.3 or greater](https://github.com/redis/jedis/releases/tag/v4.4.3)\\\\n * [redis-om-spring 0.8.1 or greater](https://github.com/redis/redis-om-spring/releases/tag/v0.8.1)\\\\n* Python\\\\n * [redis-py 4.5.5 or greater ](https://github.com/redis/redis-py/releases/tag/v4.5.5)\\\\n * [redis-om-python 0.1.2 or greater](https://github.com/redis/redis-om-python/releases/tag/v0.1.2)\\\\n* NodeJS\\\\n * [node-redis 4.6.7 or greater](https://github.com/redis/node-redis/releases/tag/redis%404.6.7)\\\\n * [redis-om-node 0.2.0 or greater](https://github.com/redis/redis-om-node/releases/tag/v0.2.0)\\\\n* .NET\\\\n * [redis-om-dotnet 0.5.1 or greater](https://github.com/redis/redis-om-dotnet/releases/tag/v0.5.1)\\\\n * [NRedisStack 0.7.0 or greater](https://github.com/redis/NRedisStack/releases/tag/v0.7.0)\\\\n* Go\\\\n * [go-redis 9.0.4 or greater](https://github.com/redis/go-redis/releases/tag/v9.0.4)\\\\n * [rueidis 1.0.3 or greater](https://github.com/redis/rueidis/releases/tag/v1.0.3)\\\\n\\\\nCompatible with the latest [RedisInsight](https://redis.io/download). The docker image redis/redis-stack for this version is bundled with [RedisInsight 2.26](https://github.com/RedisInsight/RedisInsight/releases/tag/2.26.0).\\\\n\\\\nNote: version numbers follow the pattern:\\\\n\\\\n`x.y.z-b`\\\\n* `x.y` Redis major version\\\\n* `z` increases with even numbers as a module x.y version increases.\\\\n* `b` denotes a patch to Redis or a module (any `z` of Redis or modules). `b` will consist of a `v` + numeric value.\\"\\n }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text='Redis provides built-in geospatial data support through its **Geospatial indexes** data type. Here's how to store and query geospatial data:

## Storing Geospatial Data

Use the `GEOADD` command to add locations with their coordinates (longitude, latitude):

```redis
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.27652 37.805186 station:1
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.2674626 37.8062344 station:2
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.2469854 37.8104049 station:3
```

**Important**: Longitude comes before latitude in this command.

## Querying Geospatial Data

Use `GEOSEARCH` to find locations within a radius or bounding box:

```redis
GEOSEARCH bikes:rentable FROMLONLAT -122.2612767 37.7936847 BYRADIUS 5 km WITHDIST
```

This returns locations within 5km of the specified coordinates along with their distances:

```
1) 1) "station:1"
   2) "1.8523"
2) 1) "station:2"
   2) "1.4979"
3) 1) "station:3"
   2) "2.2441"
```

## Use Cases

Geospatial indexes are ideal for:
- Finding nearby points within a given radius
- Location-based searches (e.g., bike rental stations, restaurants, stores)
- Proximity queries with distance calculations

## Advanced: Geo Polygons (Redis Stack 7.2+)

For more complex shapes, Redis Stack 7.2 introduced `GEOSHAPE` field type supporting polygon queries:

- Supports `POLYGON` and `POINT` shapes using WKT notation
- Enables `WITHIN` and `CONTAINS` operations
- Supports both cartesian (X,Y) and geographic (lon, lat) coordinate systems

**Note**: The basic Geospatial data type is simpler and suitable for most use cases. For advanced format options and complex queries, consider Redis Query Engine's geospatial features.

[来源: redis-docs/develop/data-types/geospatial.md]  
[来源: redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisstack/redisstack-7.2-release-notes.md > Redis Stack 7.2.0-v0 > Headlines]')]

query: Redis TimeSeries 适合什么场景？怎么配置 retention？
answer:
## Redis TimeSeries 使用场景

Redis TimeSeries 适合以下典型场景：

### 1. 监控与运维（数据中心）
- 服务器 CPU 利用率监控
- 服务间网络延迟追踪
- 存储系统 IO 带宽分析
- 应用响应时间（如 99th percentile）统计

### 2. 环境与气象分析
- 降雨量、温度、日照时长等气象数据
- CO2 浓度长期趋势分析
- 跨地理区域的气候数据聚合

### 3. 物联网与传感器数据
- **飞行数据记录**：高度、航迹、引擎温度、振动、压力
- **船舶日志**：风速、海况、航速、位置
- **车联网**：油耗、轮胎压力、加速度、位置、保养里程
- **智能电表**：能源消耗/生产数据

### 4. 金融与股票交易
- 高频交易数据（百万级 ops/秒）
- 价格波动分析
- 异常检测（如内幕交易识别）

### 5. 电信服务质量
- 基站流量监控
- 负载均衡与容量规划

---

## Retention（数据保留）配置

### 配置优先级
Retention 可以在三个层级设置，优先级从高到低：

1. **Key 级别**：通过 `TS.CREATE` 或 `TS.ALTER` 的 `RETENTION` 参数
2. **全局配置**：`ts-retention-policy` 配置参数
3. **无保留策略**（默认）

### 配置方法

#### Redis 8.0 之前（启动时加载）
```bash
redis-server --loadmodule ./redistimeseries.so RETENTION_POLICY 25920000000
```

#### Redis 8.0 及以上（运行时配置）
```bash
# 设置默认保留 300 天（25920000000 毫秒）
redis> CONFIG SET ts-retention-policy 25920000000

# 持久化到配置文件
redis> CONFIG REWRITE
```

#### Key 级别示例
```bash
# 创建时指定保留 60 秒
TS.CREATE temperature RETENTION 60000 LABELS sensor_id 2 area_id 32
```

### 工作原理
- Retention 以**毫秒**为单位指定时间窗口
- 超出时间窗口的旧数据会被自动删除
- 比基于固定样本数量的策略更适合时序场景

---

**来源**：
- [/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/use_cases.md]
- [/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/configuration.md > RETENTION_POLICY / ts-retention-policy > Example]
- [/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md > v1.0.0 > Features]

[ToolResultBlock(tool_use_id='tooluse_jHYY50YMiGlWX0OwKStx12', content='{"result":"[\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 3.3456,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"7b673af6\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"7b673af6-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/use_cases.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Use cases\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"**Monitoring (data center)**\\\\n\\\\nModern data centers have a lot of moving pieces, such as infrastructure (servers and networks) and software systems (applications and services) that need to be monitored around the clock.\\\\n\\\\nRedis Time Series allows you to plan for new resources upfront, optimize the utilization of existing resources, reconstruct the circumstances that led to outages, and identify application performance issues by analyzing and reporting on the following metrics:\\\\n\\\\n- Maximum CPU utilization per server\\\\n- Maximum network latency between two services\\\\n- Average IO bandwidth utilization of a storage system\\\\n- 99th percentile of the response time of a specific application outages\\\\n\\\\n**Weather analysis (environment)**\\\\n\\\\nRedis Time Series can be used to track environmental measurements such as the number of daily sunshine hours and hourly rainfall depth, over a period of many years. Seasonally, you can measure average rainfall depth, average daily temperature, and the maximum number of sunny hours per day, for example. Watch the increase of the maximum daily temperature over the years. Predict the expected temperature and rainfall depth in a specific location for a particular week of the year.\\\\n\\\\nMultiple time series can be collected, each for a different location. By utilizing secondary indexes, measurements can be aggregated over given geographical regions (e.g., minimal and maximal daily temperature in Europe) or over locations with specific attributes (e.g., average rainfall depth in mountainous regions).\\\\n\\\\nExample metrics include: \\\\n\\\\n- Rain (cm)\\\\n- Temperature (C)\\\\n- Sunny periods (h)\\\\n\\\\n**Analysis of the atmosphere (environment)**\\\\n\\\\nThe atmospheric concentration of CO2 is more important than ever before. Use TimeSeries to track average, maximum and minimum CO2 level per season and average yearly CO2 over the last decades. Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Concentration of CO2 (ppm)\\\\n- Location\\\\n\\\\n**Flight data recording (sensor data and IoT)**\\\\n\\\\nPlanes have a multitude of sensors. This sensor data is stored in a black box and also shared with external systems. TimeSeries can help you reconstruct the sequence of events over time, optimize operations and maintenance intervals, improve safety, and provide feedback to the equipment manufacturers about the part quality. Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Altitude\\\\n- Flight path\\\\n- Engine temperature\\\\n- Level of vibrations\\\\n- Pressure\\\\n\\\\n**Ship logbooks (sensor data and IoT)**\\\\n\\\\nIt\'s very common to keep track of ship voyages via (digital) logbooks. Use TimeSeries to calculate optimal routes using these metrics:\\\\n\\\\n- Wind (km/h)\\\\n- Ocean conditions (classes)\\\\n- Speed (knots)\\\\n- Location (long, lat)\\\\n\\\\n**Connected car (sensor data and IoT)**\\\\n\\\\nModern cars are exposing several metrics via a standard interface. Use TimeSeries to correlate average fuel consumption with the tire pressure, figure out how long to keep a car in the fleet, determine optimal maintenance intervals, and calculate tax savings by type of the road (taxable vs. nontaxable roads). Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Acceleration\\\\n- Location (long, lat)\\\\n- Fuel level (liter)\\\\n- Distances (km)\\\\n- Speed (km/h)\\\\n- Tire pressure\\\\n- Distance until next maintenance check\\\\n\\\\n**Smart metering (sensor data and IoT)**\\\\n\\\\nModern houses and facilities gather details about energy consumption/production. Use Redis Time Series to aggregate billing based on monthly consumption. Optimize the network by redirecting the energy delivery relative to the fluctuations in need. Provide recommendations on how to improve the energy consumption behavior. Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Consumption per location\\\\n- Produced amount of electrical energy per location\\\\n\\\\n**Quality of service (telecom)**\\\\n\\\\nMobile phone usage is increasing, producing a natural growth that just correlates to the increasing number of cellphones. However, there might also be spikes that correlate with specific events (for example, more messages around world championships). \\\\n\\\\nTelecom providers need to ensure that they are providing the necessary infrastructure to deliver the right quality of service. This includes using mini towers for short-term peaks. Use TimeSeries to correlate traffic peaks to specific events, load balance traffic over several towers or mini towers, and predictively plan the infrastructure. Metrics include the amount of traffic per tower.\\\\n\\\\n**Stock trading (finance)**\\\\n\\\\nStock trading is highly automated today. Algorithms, and not just human beings, are trading, from the amount of bids and asks for the trading of a stock to the extreme volumes of trades per second (millions of ops per second). Computer-driven trading requires millisecond response times. It\'s necessary to keep a lot of data points within a very short period of time (for example, price fluctuations per second within a minute). In addition, the long-term history needs to be kept to make statements about trends or for regulatory purposes.  \\\\n\\\\nUse Redis Time Series to identify correlations between the trading behavior and other events (for example, social network posts). Discover a developing market. Detect anomalies to discover insider trades. Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Exact time and order of a trade by itself\\\\n- Type of the event (trade/bid)\\\\n- The stock price\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 2.7569,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"6072bd82\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"6072bd82-002\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redistimeseries 1.0 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"v1.0.0 (June 2019) > Features > Integrations\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"If you want to keep all of your raw data points indefinitely, your data set will grow linearly over time. However, if your use case allows you to have less fine-grained data further back in time, downsampling can be applied. This allows you to keep fewer historical data points by aggregating raw data for a given time window using a given aggregation function. RedisTimeSeries supports downsampling with the following aggregations: avg, sum, min, max, range, count, first and last.\\\\n\\\\nWhen using Redis’ core data structures, you can only retrieve a time series by knowing the exact key holding the time series. Unfortunately, for many time series use cases (such as root cause analysis or monitoring), your application won’t know the exact key it’s looking for. These use cases typically want to query a set of time series that relate to each other in a couple of dimensions to extract the insight you need. You could create your own secondary index with core Redis data structures to help with this, but it would come with a high development cost and require you to manage edge cases to make sure the index is correct.\\\\n\\\\nRedisTimeSeries does this indexing for you based on `field value` pairs (a.k.a labels) you can add to each time series, and use to filter at query time (a full list of these filters is available in our documentation). Here’s an example of creating a time series with two labels (sensor_id and area_id are the fields with values 2 and 32 respectively) and a retention window of 60,000 milliseconds:\\\\n\\\\n```sh\\\\nTS.CREATE temperature RETENTION 60000 LABELS sensor_id 2 area_id 32\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWhen you need to query a time series, it’s cumbersome to stream all raw data points if you’re only interested in, say, an average over a given time interval. RedisTimeSeries follows the Redis philosophy to only transfer the minimum required data to ensure lowest latency. Below is an example of aggregation query over time buckets of 5,000 milliseconds with an aggregation function:  \\\\n\\\\n```sh\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> TS.RANGE temperature:3:32 1548149180000 1548149210000 AGGREGATION avg 5000\\\\n1) 1) (integer) 1548149180000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"26.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n2) 1) (integer) 1548149185000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"27.399999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n3) 1) (integer) 1548149190000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"24.800000000000001\\\\\\"\\\\n4) 1) (integer) 1548149195000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"23.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n5) 1) (integer) 1548149200000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"25.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n6) 1) (integer) 1548149205000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"28\\\\\\"\\\\n7) 1) (integer) 1548149210000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"20\\\\\\"\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nRedisTimeSeries comes with several integrations into existing time series tools. One such integration is our [RedisTimeSeries adapter for Prometheus](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/prometheus-redistimeseries-adapter), which keeps all your monitoring metrics inside RedisTimeSeries while leveraging the entire Prometheus ecosystem.\\\\nFurthermore, we also created direct integration for [Grafana](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/grafana-redistimeseries). [This repository](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/prometheus-demos) contains a docker-compose setup of RedisTimeSeries, its remote write adaptor, Prometheus and Grafana. It also comes with a set of data generators and pre-built Grafana dashboards.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.3689,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"43b5f91b\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"43b5f91b-005\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/lists.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis lists\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Examples > Capped lists\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Lists are useful for a number of tasks, two very representative use cases\\\\nare the following:\\\\n\\\\n* Remember the latest updates posted by users into a social network.\\\\n* Communication between processes, using a consumer-producer pattern where the producer pushes items into a list, and a consumer (usually a *worker*) consumes those items and executes actions. Redis has special list commands to make this use case both more reliable and efficient.\\\\n\\\\nFor example both the popular Ruby libraries [resque](https://github.com/resque/resque) and\\\\n[sidekiq](https://github.com/mperham/sidekiq) use Redis lists under the hood in order to\\\\nimplement background jobs.\\\\n\\\\nThe popular Twitter social network [takes the latest tweets](http://www.infoq.com/presentations/Real-Time-Delivery-Twitter)\\\\nposted by users into Redis lists.\\\\n\\\\nTo describe a common use case step by step, imagine your home page shows the latest\\\\nphotos published in a photo sharing social network and you want to speedup access.\\\\n\\\\n* Every time a user posts a new photo, we add its ID into a list with [`LPUSH`]().\\\\n* When users visit the home page, we use `LRANGE 0 9` in order to get the latest 10 posted items.\\\\n\\\\nIn many use cases we just want to use lists to store the *latest items*,\\\\nwhatever they are: social network updates, logs, or anything else.\\\\n\\\\nRedis allows us to use lists as a capped collection, only remembering the latest\\\\nN items and discarding all the oldest items using the [`LTRIM`]() command.\\\\n\\\\nThe [`LTRIM`]() command is similar to [`LRANGE`](), but **instead of displaying the\\\\nspecified range of elements** it sets this range as the new list value. All\\\\nthe elements outside the given range are removed.\\\\n\\\\nFor example, if you\'re adding bikes on the end of a list of repairs, but only\\\\nwant to worry about the 3 that have been on the list the longest:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL bikes:repairs\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3 bike:4 bike:5\\\\n(integer) 5\\\\n> LTRIM bikes:repairs 0 2\\\\nOK\\\\n> LRANGE bikes:repairs 0 -1\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:1\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"bike:2\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"bike:3\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nThe above [`LTRIM`]() command tells Redis to keep just list elements from index\\\\n0 to 2, everything else will be discarded. This allows for a very simple but\\\\nuseful pattern: doing a List push operation + a List trim operation together \\\\nto add a new element and discard elements exceeding a limit. Using \\\\n[`LTRIM`]() with negative indexes can then be used to keep only the 3 most recently added:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL bikes:repairs\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3 bike:4 bike:5\\\\n(integer) 5\\\\n> LTRIM bikes:repairs -3 -1\\\\nOK\\\\n> LRANGE bikes:repairs 0 -1\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:3\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"bike:4\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"bike:5\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nThe above combination adds new elements and keeps only the 3\\\\nnewest elements into the list. With [`LRANGE`]() you can access the top items\\\\nwithout any need to remember very old data.\\\\n\\\\nNote: while [`LRANGE`]() is technically an O(N) command, accessing small ranges\\\\ntowards the head or the tail of the list is a constant time operation.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.3259,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"6072bd82\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"6072bd82-001\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redistimeseries 1.0 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"v1.0.0 (June 2019) > Features\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"In RedisTimeSeries, we are introducing a new data type that uses chunks of memory of fixed size for time series samples, indexed by the same [Radix Tree implementation](https://github.com/antirez/rax) as Redis Streams. With Streams, you can create a [capped stream](, effectively limiting the number of messages by count. In RedisTimeSeries, you can apply a retention policy in milliseconds. This is better for time series use cases, because they are typically interested in the data during a given time window, rather than a fixed number of samples.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -0.8369,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"9f2d8d5c\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"9f2d8d5c-003\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/reference/cluster-spec.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis cluster specification\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Client and Server roles in the Redis cluster protocol > Write safety\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Redis Cluster uses asynchronous replication between nodes, and **last failover wins** implicit merge function. This means that the last elected master dataset eventually replaces all the other replicas. There is always a window of time when it is possible to lose writes during partitions. However these windows are very different in the case of a client that is connected to the majority of masters, and a client that is connected to the minority of masters.\\\\n\\\\nRedis Cluster tries harder to retain writes that are performed by clients connected to the majority of masters, compared to writes performed in the minority side.\\\\nThe following are examples of scenarios that lead to loss of acknowledged\\\\nwrites received in the majority partitions during failures:\\\\n\\\\n1. A write may reach a master, but while the master may be able to reply to the client, the write may not be propagated to replicas via the asynchronous replication used between master and replica nodes. If the master dies without the write reaching the replicas, the write is lost forever if the master is unreachable for a long enough period that one of its replicas is promoted. This is usually hard to observe in the case of a total, sudden failure of a master node since masters try to reply to clients (with the acknowledge of the write) and replicas (propagating the write) at about the same time. However it is a real world failure mode.\\\\n\\\\n2. Another theoretically possible failure mode where writes are lost is the following:\\\\n\\\\n* A master is unreachable because of a partition.\\\\n* It gets failed over by one of its replicas.\\\\n* After some time it may be reachable again.\\\\n* A client with an out-of-date routing table may write to the old master before it is converted into a replica (of the new master) by the cluster.\\\\n\\\\nThe second failure mode is unlikely to happen because master nodes unable to communicate with the majority of the other masters for enough time to be failed over will no longer accept writes, and when the partition is fixed writes are still refused for a small amount of time to allow other nodes to inform about configuration changes. This failure mode also requires that the client\'s routing table has not yet been updated.\\\\n\\\\nWrites targeting the minority side of a partition have a larger window in which to get lost. For example, Redis Cluster loses a non-trivial number of writes on partitions where there is a minority of masters and at least one or more clients, since all the writes sent to the masters may potentially get lost if the masters are failed over in the majority side.\\\\n\\\\nSpecifically, for a master to be failed over it must be unreachable by the majority of masters for at least `NODE_TIMEOUT`, so if the partition is fixed before that time, no writes are lost. When the partition lasts for more than `NODE_TIMEOUT`, all the writes performed in the minority side up to that point may be lost. However the minority side of a Redis Cluster will start refusing writes as soon as `NODE_TIMEOUT` time has elapsed without contact with the majority, so there is a maximum window after which the minority becomes no longer available. Hence, no writes are accepted or lost after that time.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

\\"608370db-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/configuration.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Configuration Parameters\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Open Source - set configuration parameters\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Before Redis 8 in Redis Open Source (version 8.0), all time series configuration parameters are load-time parameters.\\\\nUse one of the following methods to set the values of load-time configuration parameters:\\\\n\\\\n- Pass them as command-line arguments following the `loadmodule` argument when starting `redis-server`:\\\\n\\\\n  `redis-server --loadmodule ./{modulename}.so [OPT VAL]...`\\\\n\\\\n- Add them as arguments to the `loadmodule` directive in your configuration file (for example, `redis.conf`):\\\\n\\\\n  `loadmodule ./{modulename}.so [OPT VAL]...`\\\\n\\\\n- Use the `MODULE LOAD path [arg [arg ...]]` command.\\\\n\\\\n- Use the `MODULE LOADEX path [CONFIG name value [CONFIG name value ...]] [ARGS args [args ....]]` command.\\\\n\\\\nStarting with Redis 8.0, most time series configuration parameters are runtime parameters.\\\\nWhile you can set runtime parameters at load time, using the Redis `CONFIG` command is easier and works the same way as with Redis runtime configuration parameters.\\\\n\\\\nThis means:\\\\n\\\\n- `CONFIG SET parameter value [parameter value ...] `\\\\n\\\\n  Set one or more configuration parameters.\\\\n\\\\n- `CONFIG GET parameter [parameter ...]`\\\\n\\\\n  Read the current value of one of more parameters.\\\\n\\\\n- `CONFIG REWRITE`\\\\n\\\\n  Rewrite your Redis configuration file (for example, the `redis.conf` file) to reflect the configuration changes.\\\\n\\\\nStarting with Redis 8.0, you can specify time series configuration parameters directly in your Redis configuration file the same way you would for Redis configuration parameters.\\\\n\\\\nOnce a value is set with `CONFIG SET` or added manually to your configuration file, it will overwrite values set with `--loadmodule`, `loadmodule`, `MODULE LOAD`, or `MODULE LOADEX`.\\\\n\\\\nIn a cluster, you must run `CONFIG SET` and `CONFIG REWRITE` on each node separately.\\\\n\\\\nIn Redis 8.0, new names for the time series configuration parameters were introduced to align the naming with the Redis configuration parameters.\\\\nYou must use the new names when using the `CONFIG` command.\\\\n\\\\nSee also [Redis configuration]().\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text='## Redis TimeSeries 使用场景

Redis TimeSeries 适合以下典型场景：

### 1. 监控与运维（数据中心）
- 服务器 CPU 利用率监控
- 服务间网络延迟追踪
- 存储系统 IO 带宽分析
- 应用响应时间（如 99th percentile）统计

### 2. 环境与气象分析
- 降雨量、温度、日照时长等气象数据
- CO2 浓度长期趋势分析
- 跨地理区域的气候数据聚合

### 3. 物联网与传感器数据
- **飞行数据记录**：高度、航迹、引擎温度、振动、压力
- **船舶日志**：风速、海况、航速、位置
- **车联网**：油耗、轮胎压力、加速度、位置、保养里程
- **智能电表**：能源消耗/生产数据

### 4. 金融与股票交易
- 高频交易数据（百万级 ops/秒）
- 价格波动分析
- 异常检测（如内幕交易识别）

### 5. 电信服务质量
- 基站流量监控
- 负载均衡与容量规划

---

## Retention（数据保留）配置

### 配置优先级
Retention 可以在三个层级设置，优先级从高到低：

1. **Key 级别**：通过 `TS.CREATE` 或 `TS.ALTER` 的 `RETENTION` 参数
2. **全局配置**：`ts-retention-policy` 配置参数
3. **无保留策略**（默认）

### 配置方法

#### Redis 8.0 之前（启动时加载）
```bash
redis-server --loadmodule ./redistimeseries.so RETENTION_POLICY 25920000000
```

#### Redis 8.0 及以上（运行时配置）
```bash
# 设置默认保留 300 天（25920000000 毫秒）
redis> CONFIG SET ts-retention-policy 25920000000

# 持久化到配置文件
redis> CONFIG REWRITE
```

#### Key 级别示例
```bash
# 创建时指定保留 60 秒
TS.CREATE temperature RETENTION 60000 LABELS sensor_id 2 area_id 32
```

### 工作原理
- Retention 以**毫秒**为单位指定时间窗口
- 超出时间窗口的旧数据会被自动删除
- 比基于固定样本数量的策略更适合时序场景

---

**来源**：
- [/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/use_cases.md]
- [/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/configuration.md > RETENTION_POLICY / ts-retention-policy > Example]
- [/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md > v1.0.0 > Features]')]

messages.result:
## Redis TimeSeries 使用场景

Redis TimeSeries 适合以下典型场景：

### 1. 监控与运维（数据中心）
- 服务器 CPU 利用率监控
- 服务间网络延迟追踪
- 存储系统 IO 带宽分析
- 应用响应时间（如 99th percentile）统计

### 2. 环境与气象分析
- 降雨量、温度、日照时长等气象数据
- CO2 浓度长期趋势分析
- 跨地理区域的气候数据聚合

### 3. 物联网与传感器数据
- **飞行数据记录**：高度、航迹、引擎温度、振动、压力
- **船舶日志**：风速、海况、航速、位置
- **车联网**：油耗、轮胎压力、加速度、位置、保养里程
- **智能电表**：能源消耗/生产数据

### 4. 金融与股票交易
- 高频交易数据（百万级 ops/秒）
- 价格波动分析
- 异常检测（如内幕交易识别）

### 5. 电信服务质量
- 基站流量监控
- 负载均衡与容量规划

---

## Retention（数据保留）配置

### 配置优先级
Retention 可以在三个层级设置，优先级从高到低：

1. **Key 级别**：通过 `TS.CREATE` 或 `TS.ALTER` 的 `RETENTION` 参数
2. **全局配置**：`ts-retention-policy` 配置参数
3. **无保留策略**（默认）

### 配置方法

#### Redis 8.0 之前（启动时加载）
```bash
redis-server --loadmodule ./redistimeseries.so RETENTION_POLICY 25920000000
```

#### Redis 8.0 及以上（运行时配置）
```bash
# 设置默认保留 300 天（25920000000 毫秒）
redis> CONFIG SET ts-retention-policy 25920000000

# 持久化到配置文件
redis> CONFIG REWRITE
```

#### Key 级别示例
```bash
# 创建时指定保留 60 秒
TS.CREATE temperature RETENTION 60000 LABELS sensor_id 2 area_id 32
```

### 工作原理
- Retention 以**毫秒**为单位指定时间窗口
- 超出时间窗口的旧数据会被自动删除
- 比基于固定样本数量的策略更适合时序场景

---

**来源**：
- [/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/use_cases.md]
- [/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/configuration.md > RETENTION_POLICY / ts-retention-policy > Example]

query: Compare Count-Min Sketch and Top-K in Redis probabilistic data structures
answer:
Based on the search results from the Redis knowledge base, here's a comparison of Count-Min Sketch and Top-K probabilistic data structures:

## Overview

Both are probabilistic data structures in Redis for analyzing data streams, but they serve different purposes:

- **Count-Min Sketch (CMS)**: Estimates the frequency/count of elements in a stream
- **Top-K**: Identifies the K highest-frequency elements in a stream

## Key Differences

### Purpose & Use Case

**Count-Min Sketch:**
- Answers: "How many times has element X appeared?"
- Best for: Tracking frequency of ALL elements when you need counts above a certain threshold
- Example: Sales volume tracking where you want counts for products contributing most to sales

**Top-K:**
- Answers: "What are the K most frequent elements?"
- Best for: Finding the top performers/heavy hitters in real-time
- Example: Detecting network anomalies, trending hashtags, most-read news articles

### Algorithm & Implementation

**Count-Min Sketch:**
- Uses a 2D array of counters with multiple hash functions (depth)
- Each element hashes to multiple positions; increment all counters
- Query returns the minimum of all hashed positions
- Only useful for **higher counts** - low counts should be ignored as noise

**Top-K:**
- Based on the [HeavyKeepers algorithm](https://www.usenix.org/conference/atc18/presentation/gong)
- Uses two structures in tandem:
  - Hash table with probabilistic counts (similar to CMS)
  - Min heap holding the K items with highest counts
- Uses "count-with-exponential-decay" strategy biased against small flows
- Provides real-time notifications when elements enter/leave the top-K list

### Performance Characteristics

**Count-Min Sketch:**
- Space: Sub-linear, determined by error rate and probability parameters
- Accuracy: Over-counts due to collisions; threshold = error × total_count
- Best when: You need counts for many elements with non-uniform distribution

**Top-K:**
- Space: Fraction of what a Sorted Set would require
- Time: `O(K*log(k))` for listing top-K items
- Accuracy: Higher than previous probabilistic algorithms
- Best when: K is small and you only care about the top performers

### Overlap & When to Use Each

The documentation explicitly notes: "There is, indeed, some overlap with the functionality of Count-Min Sketch, but the two data structures have their differences and should be applied for different use cases."

**Use Count-Min Sketch when:**
- You need frequency estimates for arbitrary elements
- You're tracking many elements but only care about high-frequency ones
- You have non-uniform distribution (some heavy hitters, many low-frequency items)

**Use Top-K when:**
- You only need to know the top K elements
- You need real-time updates when top-K membership changes
- You want better performance for small K values
- You need to detect sudden spikes (DDoS attacks, trending topics)

## Example Commands

**Count-Min Sketch:**
```redis
CMS.INITBYPROB bikes:profit 0.001 0.002
CMS.INCRBY bikes:profit "Mountain Bike" 100
CMS.QUERY bikes:profit "Mountain Bike"
```

**Top-K:**
```redis
TOPK.RESERVE trending:hashtags 10
TOPK.ADD trending:hashtags "#redis"
TOPK.LIST trending:hashtags
```

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/top-k.md > Use case]
[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/count-min-sketch.md > Examples]
