\\"Special encoding of small aggregate data types\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Since Redis 2.2 many data types are optimized to use less space up to a certain size.\\\\nHashes, Lists, Sets composed of just integers, and Sorted Sets, when smaller than a given number of elements, and up to a maximum element size, are encoded in a very memory-efficient way that uses *up to 10 times less memory* (with 5 times less memory used being the average saving).\\\\n\\\\nThis is completely transparent from the point of view of the user and API.\\\\nSince this is a CPU / memory tradeoff it is possible to tune the maximum \\\\nnumber of elements and maximum element size for special encoded types \\\\nusing the following redis.conf directives (defaults are shown):\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.9398,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"b7e8b170\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"b7e8b170-003\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/memory-optimization.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Memory optimization\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Using hashes to abstract a very memory-efficient plain key-value store on top of Redis\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"I understand the title of this section is a bit scary, but I\'m going to explain in detail what this is about.\\\\n\\\\nBasically it is possible to model a plain key-value store using Redis\\\\nwhere values can just be just strings, which is not just more memory efficient\\\\nthan Redis plain keys but also much more memory efficient than memcached.\\\\n\\\\nLet\'s start with some facts: a few keys use a lot more memory than a single key\\\\ncontaining a hash with a few fields. How is this possible? We use a trick.\\\\nIn theory to guarantee that we perform lookups in constant time\\\\n(also known as O(1) in big O notation) there is the need to use a data structure\\\\nwith a constant time complexity in the average case, like a hash table.\\\\n\\\\nBut many times hashes contain just a few fields. When hashes are small we can\\\\ninstead just encode them in an O(N) data structure, like a linear\\\\narray with length-prefixed key-value pairs. Since we do this only when N\\\\nis small, the amortized time for [`HGET`](/commands/hget) and [`HSET`](/commands/hset) commands is still O(1): the\\\\nhash will be converted into a real hash table as soon as the number of elements\\\\nit contains grows too large (you can configure the limit in redis.conf).\\\\n\\\\nThis does not only work well from the point of view of time complexity, but\\\\nalso from the point of view of constant times since a linear array of key-value pairs happens to play very well with the CPU cache (it has a better\\\\ncache locality than a hash table).\\\\n\\\\nHowever since hash fields and values are not (always) represented as full-featured Redis objects, hash fields can\'t have an associated time to live\\\\n(expire) like a real key, and can only contain a string. But we are okay with\\\\nthis, this was the intention anyway when the hash data type API was\\\\ndesigned (we trust simplicity more than features, so nested data structures\\\\nare not allowed, as expires of single fields are not allowed).\\\\n\\\\nSo hashes are memory efficient. This is useful when using hashes\\\\nto represent objects or to model other problems when there are group of\\\\nrelated fields. But what about if we have a plain key value business?\\\\n\\\\nImagine we want to use Redis as a cache for many small objects, which can be JSON encoded objects, small HTML fragments, simple key -> boolean values\\\\nand so forth. Basically, anything is a string -> string map with small keys\\\\nand values.\\\\n\\\\nNow let\'s assume the objects we want to cache are numbered, like:\\\\n\\\\n * object:102393\\\\n * object:1234\\\\n * object:5\\\\n\\\\nThis is what we can do. Every time we perform a\\\\nSET operation to set a new value, we actually split the key into two parts,\\\\none part used as a key, and the other part used as the field name for the hash. For instance, the\\\\nobject named \\\\\\"object:1234\\\\\\" is actually split into:\\\\n\\\\n* a Key named object:12\\\\n* a Field named 34\\\\n\\\\nSo we use all the characters but the last two for the key, and the final\\\\ntwo characters for the hash field name. To set our key we use the following\\\\ncommand:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nHSET object:12 34 somevalue\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nAs you can see every hash will end up containing 100 fields, which is an optimal compromise between CPU and memory saved.\\\\n\\\\nThere is another important thing to note, with this schema\\\\nevery hash will have more or\\\\nless 100 fields regardless of the number of objects we cached. This is because our objects will always end with a number and not a random string. In some way, the final number can be considered as a form of implicit pre-sharding.\\\\n\\\\nWhat about small numbers? Like object:2? We handle this case using just\\\\n\\\\\\"object:\\\\\\" as a key name, and the whole number as the hash field name.\\\\nSo object:2 and object:10 will both end inside the key \\\\\\"object:\\\\\\", but one\\\\nas field name \\\\\\"2\\\\\\" and one as \\\\\\"10\\\\\\".\\\\n\\\\nHow much memory do we save this way?\\\\n\\\\nI used the following Ruby program to test how this works:\\\\n\\\\n```ruby\\\\nrequire \'rubygems\'\\\\nrequire \'redis\'\\\\n\\\\nUSE_OPTIMIZATION = true\\\\n\\\\ndef hash_get_key_field(key)\\\\n  s = key.split(\':\')\\\\n  if s[1].length > 2\\\\n    { key: s[0] + \':\' + s[1][0..-3], field: s[1][-2..-1] }\\\\n  else\\\\n    { key: s[0] + \':\', field: s[1] }\\\\n  end\\\\nend\\\\n\\\\ndef hash_set(r, key, value)\\\\n  kf = hash_get_key_field(key)\\\\n  r.hset(kf[:key], kf[:field], value)\\\\nend\\\\n\\\\ndef hash_get(r, key, value)\\\\n  kf = hash_get_key_field(key)\\\\n  r.hget(kf[:key], kf[:field], value)\\\\nend\\\\n\\\\nr = Redis.new\\\\n(0..100_000).each do |id|\\\\n  key = \\\\\\"object:#{id}\\\\\\"\\\\n  if USE_OPTIMIZATION\\\\n    hash_set(r, key, \'val\')\\\\n  else\\\\n    r.set(key, \'val\')\\\\n  end\\\\nend\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThis is the result against a 64 bit instance of Redis 2.2:\\\\n\\\\n * USE_OPTIMIZATION set to true: 1.7 MB of used memory\\\\n * USE_OPTIMIZATION set to false; 11 MB of used memory\\\\n\\\\nThis is an order of magnitude, I think this makes Redis more or less the most\\\\nmemory efficient plain key value store out there.\\\\n\\\\n*WARNING*: for this to work, make sure that in your redis.conf you have\\\\nsomething like this:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nhash-max-zipmap-entries 256\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nAlso remember to set the following field accordingly to the maximum size\\\\nof your keys and values:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nhash-max-zipmap-value 1024\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nEvery time a hash exceeds the number of elements or element size specified\\\\nit will be converted into a real hash table, and the memory saving will be lost.\\\\n\\\\nYou may ask, why don\'t you do this implicitly in the normal key space so that\\\\nI don\'t have to care? There are two reasons: one is that we tend to make\\\\ntradeoffs explicit, and this is a clear tradeoff between many things: CPU,\\\\nmemory, and max element size. The second is that the top-level key space must\\\\nsupport a lot of interesting things like expires, LRU data, and so\\\\nforth so it is not practical to do this in a general way.\\\\n\\\\nBut the Redis Way is that the user must understand how things work so that he can pick the best compromise and to understand how the system will\\\\nbehave exactly.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.6567,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"1a112c0f\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"1a112c0f-001\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/get-started/faq.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis FAQ\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Are Redis on-disk snapshots atomic?\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Yes, a common design pattern involves taking very write-heavy small data\\\\nin Redis (and data you need the Redis data structures to model your problem\\\\nin an efficient way), and big *blobs* of data into an SQL or eventually\\\\nconsistent on-disk database. Similarly sometimes Redis is used in order to\\\\ntake in memory another copy of a subset of the same data stored in the on-disk\\\\ndatabase. This may look similar to caching, but actually is a more advanced model\\\\nsince normally the Redis dataset is updated together with the on-disk DB dataset,\\\\nand not refreshed on cache misses.\\\\n\\\\nA good practice is to consider memory consumption when mapping your logical data model to the physical data model within Redis. These considerations include using specific data types, key patterns, and normalization.\\\\n\\\\nBeyond data modeling, there is more info in the [Memory Optimization page]().\\\\n\\\\nRedis has built-in protections allowing the users to set a max limit on memory\\\\nusage, using the `maxmemory` option in the configuration file to put a limit\\\\nto the memory Redis can use. If this limit is reached, Redis will start to reply\\\\nwith an error to write commands (but will continue to accept read-only\\\\ncommands).\\\\n\\\\nYou can also configure Redis to evict keys when the max memory limit\\\\nis reached. See the [eviction policy docs]() for more information on this.\\\\n\\\\nShort answer: `echo 1 > /proc/sys/vm/overcommit_memory` :)\\\\n\\\\nAnd now the long one:\\\\n\\\\nThe Redis background saving schema relies on the copy-on-write semantic of the `fork` system call in\\\\nmodern operating systems: Redis forks (creates a child process) that is an\\\\nexact copy of the parent. The child process dumps the DB on disk and finally\\\\nexits. In theory the child should use as much memory as the parent being a\\\\ncopy, but actually thanks to the copy-on-write semantic implemented by most\\\\nmodern operating systems the parent and child process will _share_ the common\\\\nmemory pages. A page will be duplicated only when it changes in the child or in\\\\nthe parent. Since in theory all the pages may change while the child process is\\\\nsaving, Linux can\'t tell in advance how much memory the child will take, so if\\\\nthe `overcommit_memory` setting is set to zero the fork will fail unless there is\\\\nas much free RAM as required to really duplicate all the parent memory pages.\\\\nIf you have a Redis dataset of 3 GB and just 2 GB of free\\\\nmemory it will fail.\\\\n\\\\nSetting `overcommit_memory` to 1 tells Linux to relax and perform the fork in a\\\\nmore optimistic allocation fashion, and this is indeed what you want for Redis.\\\\n\\\\nYou can refer to the [proc(5)][proc5] man page for explanations of the\\\\navailable values.\\\\n\\\\n[proc5]: http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man5/proc.5.html\\\\n\\\\nYes, the Redis background saving process is always forked when the server is\\\\noutside of the execution of a command, so every command reported to be atomic\\\\nin RAM is also atomic from the point of view of the disk snapshot.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.6135,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"b7e8b170\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"b7e8b170-002\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/memory-optimization.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Memory optimization\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Use hashes when possible\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"When Redis is compiled as a 32-bit target, it uses a lot less memory per key, since pointers are small,\\\\nbut such an instance will be limited to 4 GB of maximum memory usage.\\\\nTo compile Redis as 32-bit binary use *make 32bit*.\\\\nRDB and AOF files are compatible between 32-bit and 64-bit instances\\\\n(and between little and big endian of course) so you can switch from 32 to 64-bit, or the contrary, without problems.\\\\n\\\\nRedis 2.2 introduced new bit and byte level operations: [`GETRANGE`](/commands/getrange), [`SETRANGE`](/commands/setrange), [`GETBIT`](/commands/getbit) and [`SETBIT`](/commands/setbit).\\\\nUsing these commands you can treat the Redis string type as a random access array.\\\\nFor instance, if you have an application where users are identified by a unique progressive integer number,\\\\nyou can use a bitmap to save information about the subscription of users in a mailing list,\\\\nsetting the bit for subscribed and clearing it for unsubscribed, or the other way around.\\\\nWith 100 million users this data will take just 12 megabytes of RAM in a Redis instance.\\\\nYou can do the same using [`GETRANGE`](/commands/getrange) and [`SETRANGE`](/commands/setrange) to store one byte of information for each user.\\\\nThis is just an example but it is possible to model several problems in very little space with these new primitives.\\\\n\\\\nSmall hashes are encoded in a very small space, so you should try representing your data using hashes whenever possible.\\\\nFor instance, if you have objects representing users in a web application, \\\\ninstead of using different keys for name, surname, email, password, use a single hash with all the required fields.\\\\n\\\\nIf you want to know more about this, read the next section.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.0872,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"0a0527f7\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"0a0527f7-033\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisstack/redisstack-7.2-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisstack 7.2 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Stack 7.2.0-v0 (August 2023) > Headlines:\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Redis server 7.2 introduces significant memory and speed optimizations for lists, sets, and sorted sets, several improvements, including encoding improvements for sets and lists, stream consumer group improvements, and improved durability.\\\\nSearch and Query brings the frequently asked Geo polygons queries for basic shapes and improved query performance on sorting in different scenarios. \\\\nJSON introduces two new commands: [JSON.MERGE](https://redis.io/commands/json.merge/) and [JSON.MSET](https://redis.io/commands/json.mset/) for more efficient data manipulation.\\\\nPreview of triggers and functions that allows developers to run JavaScript functions inside the Redis process.\\\\nLastly, 7.2 adds the option to use the new protocol [RESP3](https://github.com/redis/redis-specifications/blob/master/protocol/RESP3.md) improving the response format for all commands.\\\\n\\\\n**Redis server**:\\\\nRedis server 7.2 brings performance and resource utilization improvements, including significant memory and speed optimizations for lists, sets, and sorted sets. This new version adds a new `WITHSCORE` command argument for [ZRANK](https://redis.io/commands/zrank/) and [ZREVRANK](https://redis.io/commands/zrevrank/), new commands, such as [CLIENT NO-TOUCH](https://redis.io/commands/client-no-touch/) for clients to run commands without affecting LRU/LFU of keys, and more. Redis 7.2 brings behavior changes by introducing a new format (version 11) for RDB files, which is incompatible with older versions, changing module API, and other changes.\\\\n\\\\n**Search and Query**:\\\\nThis new major version introduces the frequently asked [Geo Polygon](https://redis.io/commands/ft.search/#examples) Search. Adding the [GEOSHAPE](https://redis.io/commands/ft.create/) field type that supports polygon shapes using the [WKT notation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Well-known_text_representation_of_geometry). In addition to the existing `GEO` for geo range queries, now an alias for `GEOPOINT`, we add `GEOSHAPE` with the support for `POLYGON` and `POINT` as new shapes formats and polygons operations.\\\\n\\\\nIn addition, 7.2 brings improvements in performance for `SORT BY` operations using [`FT.SEARCH`](https://redis.io/commands/ft.search/#optional-arguments) and [`FT.AGGREGATE`](https://redis.io/commands/ft.aggregate/#optional-arguments), and the new `FORMAT` for better readability and future support for better error handling responses on `FT.SEARCH` and `FT.AGGREGATE` in RESP3 only.\\\\n\\\\n**JSON**:\\\\nJSON introduces two new commands:\\\\n - [JSON.MERGE](https://redis.io/commands/json.merge/) merges a given JSON value into matching paths so that the JSON values at the matching paths are updated, deleted, or expanded.\\\\n - [JSON.MSET](https://redis.io/commands/json.mset/) sets or updates one or more JSON values according to specified key-path-value triplets.\\\\n\\\\n**Graph**:\\\\n\\\\nGraph capabilities are no longer included in Redis Stack. See the [RedisGraph End-of-Life Announcement](https://redis.com/blog/redisgraph-eol/).\\\\n\\\\n> [!WARNING]  \\\\nIf you are using graph capabilities with an older version of Redis Stack - please don\'t upgrade.\\\\n\\\\n**Triggers and functions preview**:\\\\nTriggers and functions is part of Redis Stack 7.2 as public preview, any feedback is highly appreciated.\\\\n\\\\nTriggers and functions provides support for running JavaScript functions inside the Redis process. These functions can be executed on-demand, by an event-driven trigger, or by a stream processing trigger. Triggers and functions empowers developers to build and maintain real-time applications by moving logic closer to the data, ensuring a lower latency whilst delivering the best developer experience.\\\\n\\\\nTry it out with the [triggers and functions quick start](https://redis.io/docs/interact/programmability/triggers-and-functions/quick_start/).\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.9381,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"20fca0b7\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"20fca0b7-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/admin.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis administration\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis setup tips > Replication\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"* Deploy Redis using the Linux operating system. Redis is also tested on OS X, and from time to time on FreeBSD and OpenBSD systems. However, Linux is where most of the stress testing is performed, and where most production deployments are run.\\\\n\\\\n* Set the Linux kernel overcommit memory setting to 1. Add `vm.overcommit_memory = 1` to `/etc/sysctl.conf`. Then, reboot or run the command `sysctl vm.overcommit_memory=1` to activate the setting. See [FAQ: Background saving fails with a fork() error on Linux?]() for details. \\\\n\\\\n* To ensure the Linux kernel feature Transparent Huge Pages does not impact Redis memory usage and latency, run the command: `echo never > /sys/kernel/mm/transparent_hugepage/enabled` to disable it. See [Latency Diagnosis - Latency induced by transparent huge pages]() for additional context.\\\\n\\\\n* Ensured that swap is enabled and that your swap file size is equal to amount of memory on your system. If Linux does not have swap set up, and your Redis instance accidentally consumes too much memory, Redis can crash when it is out of memory, or the Linux kernel OOM killer can kill the Redis process. When swapping is enabled, you can detect latency spikes and act on them.\\\\n\\\\n* Set an explicit `maxmemory` option limit in your instance to make sure that it will report errors instead of failing when the system memory limit is near to be reached. Note that `maxmemory` should be set by calculating the overhead for Redis, other than data, and the fragmentation overhead. So if you think you have 10 GB of free memory, set it to 8 or 9.\\\\n\\\\n* If you are using Redis in a write-heavy application, while saving an RDB file on disk or rewriting the AOF log, Redis can use up to 2 times the memory normally used. The additional memory used is proportional to the number of memory pages modified by writes during the saving process, so it is often proportional to the number of keys (or aggregate types items) touched during this time. Make sure to size your memory accordingly.\\\\n\\\\n* See the [`LATENCY DOCTOR`](/commands/latency-doctor) and [`MEMORY DOCTOR`](/commands/memory-doctor) commands to assist in troubleshooting.\\\\n\\\\n* When running under daemontools, use `daemonize no`.\\\\n\\\\n* Set up a non-trivial replication backlog in proportion to the amount of memory Redis is using. The backlog allows replicas to sync with the primary (master) instance much more easily.\\\\n\\\\n* If you use replication, Redis performs RDB saves even if persistence is disabled. (This does not apply to diskless replication.) If you don\'t have disk usage on the master, enable diskless replication.\\\\n\\\\n* If you are using replication, ensure that either your master has persistence enabled, or that it does not automatically restart on crashes. Replicas will try to maintain an exact copy of the master, so if a master restarts with an empty data set, replicas will be wiped as well.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.4785,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"7f44ec96\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"7f44ec96-021\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/reference/modules/modules-api-ref.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Modules API reference\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"String objects APIs > `RedisModule_TrimStringAllocation`\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"void RedisModule_TrimStringAllocation(RedisModuleString *str);\\\\n\\\\n**Available since:** 7.0.0\\\\n\\\\nTrim possible excess memory allocated for a `RedisModuleString`.\\\\n\\\\nSometimes a `RedisModuleString` may have more memory allocated for\\\\nit than required, typically for argv arguments that were constructed\\\\nfrom network buffers. This function optimizes such strings by reallocating\\\\ntheir memory, which is useful for strings that are not short lived but\\\\nretained for an extended duration.\\\\n\\\\nThis operation is *not thread safe* and should only be called when\\\\nno concurrent access to the string is guaranteed. Using it for an argv\\\\nstring in a module command before the string is potentially available\\\\nto other threads is generally safe.\\\\n\\\\nCurrently, Redis may also automatically trim retained strings when a\\\\nmodule command returns. Auto-trimming as currently implemented is *not thread safe*.\\\\n   A background thread manipulating a recently retained string may end up\\\\n   in a race condition with the auto-trim, which could result with\\\\n   data corruption.\\\\n\\\\n<span id=\\\\\\"section-reply-apis\\\\\\"></span>\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.3812,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"21068857\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"21068857-001\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisce/redisos-8.6-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisos 8.6 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Open Source 8.6.0 (February 2026) > Known bugs and limitations\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"- Substantial performance improvements.\\\\n- Substantial memory reduction for hashes (hashtable-encoded) and sorted sets (skiplist-encoded).\\\\n- Streams: `XADD` idempotency (at-most-once guarantee) with new `IDMPAUTO` and `IDMP` arguments.\\\\n- New eviction policies - least recently modified: `volatile-lrm` and `allkeys-lrm`.\\\\n- Hot keys detection and reporting; new command: `HOTKEYS`.\\\\n- TLS certificate-based automatic client authentication.\\\\n- Time series: support NaN values; new aggregators: `COUNTNAN` and `COUNTALL`.\\\\n\\\\n- Alpine and Debian Docker images - https://hub.docker.com/_/redis\\\\n- Install using snap - see https://github.com/redis/redis-snap\\\\n- Install using brew - see https://github.com/redis/homebrew-redis\\\\n- Install using RPM - see https://github.com/redis/redis-rpm\\\\n- Install using Debian APT - see https://github.com/redis/redis-debian\\\\n\\\\n- Ubuntu 22.04 (Jammy Jellyfish), 24.04 (Noble Numbat)\\\\n- Rocky Linux 8.10, 9.5\\\\n- AlmaLinux 8.10, 9.5, 10.1\\\\n- Debian 12 (Bookworm), Debian 13 (Trixie)\\\\n- macOS 14 (Sonoma), 15 (Sequoia)\\\\n\\\\n- [#14695](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14695) Keys memory size histograms.\\\\n\\\\n- [#14714](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14714) Optimize user ACL permission verification.\\\\n- [#14692](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14692) Optimize peak memory metric collection.\\\\n- [#14739](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14739) Avoid allocating and releasing list node in reply copy avoidance.\\\\n- [#14713](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14713) Reduce per command syscalls by reusing cached time when hardware monotonic clock is available.\\\\n- [#14726](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14726) Optimize `XREADGROUP CLAIM`.\\\\n- [#13962](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/13962) Vector set: replace manual popcount with __builtin_popcountll for binary vector distance (Intel, AMD, ARM).\\\\n- [#14474](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14474) Vector set: vectorized the quantized 8-bit vector distance calculation (Intel, AMD).\\\\n- [#14492](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14492) Vector set: vectorize binary quantization path for vectorsets distance calculation (Intel, AMD).\\\\n\\\\n- [#14719](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14719) `cluster-slot-stats-enabled` - per-slot resource consumptions statistics to collect.\\\\n- [#14695](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14695) `key-memory-histograms` collect memory consumption histograms per data type.\\\\n\\\\n- [#14695](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14695) `db0_distrib_lists_sizes`, `db0_distrib_sets_sizes`, `db0_distrib_hashes_sizes`, `db0_distrib_zsets_sizes`.\\\\n\\\\n- Streams: avoid using `XADD` with the new `IDMP` or `IDMPAUTO` options when using `appendonly yes` with `aof-use-rdb-preamble no` (non default).\\\\n  This limitation will be removed in the next patch.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text="Based on the knowledge base search, here are the Redis memory optimization best practices:

## 1. Configure Memory Limits

- **Set `maxmemory`**: Always configure an explicit memory limit to prevent Redis from consuming all system memory. Calculate overhead for Redis operations and fragmentation - if you have 10GB free, set it to 8-9GB.
- **Set eviction policy**: Configure `maxmemory-policy` (consider `noeviction` to return errors instead of silently evicting data)

[来源: redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/memory-optimization.md > Memory allocation]

## 2. Use Special Encoding for Small Data Types

Redis automatically optimizes small aggregate data types, using **up to 10x less memory** (5x average):

- **Hashes, Lists, Sets, Sorted Sets**: When smaller than configured thresholds, Redis uses memory-efficient encoding
- Configure thresholds in redis.conf:
  - `hash-max-zipmap-entries 256`
  - `hash-max-zipmap-value 1024`

[来源: redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/memory-optimization.md > Special encoding]

## 3. Use Hashes for Key-Value Storage

Instead of many individual keys, use hashes with multiple fields:

- **Memory savings**: Storing 100,000 objects as hash fields uses ~1.7MB vs 11MB as individual keys (6x reduction)
- **Technique**: Split keys like `object:1234` into hash key `object:12` with field `34`
- Each hash should contain ~100 fields for optimal CPU/memory tradeoff

[来源: redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/memory-optimization.md > Using hashes]

## 4. Use Bit/Byte Operations for Compact Storage

- **Bitmaps**: Store boolean flags using `GETBIT`/`SETBIT` - 100 million users = only 12MB
- **Byte arrays**: Use `GETRANGE`/`SETRANGE` for compact data representation

[来源: redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/memory-optimization.md > Use hashes when possible]

## 5. Vector Sets Memory Optimization

For vector similarity search, use quantization:

| Mode | Memory Reduction | Recall | Use Case |
|------|-----------------|--------|----------|
| `Q8` | 4x smaller | High | Default - best tradeoff |
| `BIN` | 32x smaller | Lower | Ultra-efficient, coarse search |
| `NOQUANT` | Full size | Highest | Maximum precision |

**Additional techniques**:
- Lower HNSW `M` parameter to reduce graph connections
- Use `REDUCE` option to apply random projection (e.g., 300D → 100D)
- Minimize JSON attributes and use short labels

[来源: redis-docs/develop/data-types/vector-sets/memory.md]

## 6. Memory Allocation Considerations

- **Peak memory provisioning**: Redis doesn't always return freed memory to OS - provision based on peak usage, not average
- **Fragmentation**: After freeing data, allocators reuse memory chunks efficiently
- **32-bit builds**: Use 32-bit Redis for <4GB datasets to save pointer space

[来源: redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/memory-optimization.md > Memory allocation]

## 7. System Configuration

- Enable swap to detect memory pressure (prevents OOM kills)
- Set `vm.overcommit_memory = 1` for background saves
- Account for 2x memory usage during RDB saves/AOF rewrites in write-heavy workloads

[来源: redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/admin.md > Redis setup tips]")]

Redis automatically optimizes small aggregate data types, using **up to 10x less memory** (5x average):

- **Hashes, Lists, Sets, Sorted Sets**: When smaller than configured thresholds, Redis uses memory-efficient encoding
- Configure thresholds in redis.conf:
  - `hash-max-zipmap-entries 256`
  - `hash-max-zipmap-value 1024`

[来源: redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/memory-optimization.md > Special encoding]

## 3. Use Hashes for Key-Value Storage

Instead of many individual keys, use hashes with multiple fields:

- **Memory savings**: Storing 100,000 objects as hash fields uses ~1.7MB vs 11MB as individual keys (6x reduction)
- **Technique**: Split keys like `object:1234` into hash key `object:12` with field `34`
- Each hash should contain ~100 fields for optimal CPU/memory tradeoff

[来源: redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/memory-optimization.md > Using hashes]

## 4. Use Bit/Byte Operations for Compact Storage

- **Bitmaps**: Store boolean flags using `GETBIT`/`SETBIT` - 100 million users = only 12MB
- **Byte arrays**: Use `GETRANGE`/`SETRANGE` for compact data representation

[来源: redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/memory-optimization.md > Use hashes when possible]

## 5. Vector Sets Memory Optimization

For vector similarity search, use quantization:

| Mode | Memory Reduction | Recall | Use Case |
|------|-----------------|--------|----------|
| `Q8` | 4x smaller | High | Default - best tradeoff |
| `BIN` | 32x smaller | Lower | Ultra-efficient, coarse search |
| `NOQUANT` | Full size | Highest | Maximum precision |

**Additional techniques**:
- Lower HNSW `M` parameter to reduce graph connections
- Use `REDUCE` option to apply random projection (e.g., 300D → 100D)
- Minimize JSON attributes and use short labels

[来源: redis-docs/develop/data-types/vector-sets/memory.md]

## 6. Memory Allocation Considerations

- **Peak memory provisioning**: Redis doesn't always return freed memory to OS - provision based on peak usage, not average
- **Fragmentation**: After freeing data, allocators reuse memory chunks efficiently
- **32-bit builds**: Use 32-bit Redis for <4GB datasets to save pointer space

[来源: redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/memory-optimization.md > Memory allocation]

- Enable swap to detect memory pressure (prevents OOM kills)

- Account for 2x memory usage during RDB saves/AOF rewrites in write-heavy workloads

query: How to enable TLS encryption for Redis connections?
answer:
Based on the search results, here's how to enable TLS encryption for Redis connections:

## Building Redis with TLS Support

Redis supports SSL/TLS starting from version 6. You need to compile Redis with TLS enabled:

```bash
make BUILD_TLS=yes
```

**Prerequisites:** Install OpenSSL development libraries (e.g., `libssl-dev` on Debian/Ubuntu)

## Configuration

Configure Redis with the required certificates and keys in `redis.conf`:

```
tls-cert-file /path/to/redis.crt
tls-key-file /path/to/redis.key
tls-ca-cert-file /path/to/ca.crt
tls-dh-params-file /path/to/redis.dh
```

## Enabling TLS Port

Enable TLS on a specific port (in addition to regular TCP):

```
tls-port 6379
```

To use **only TLS** and disable non-encrypted connections:

```
port 0
tls-port 6379
```

## Starting Redis Server with TLS

```bash
./src/redis-server --tls-port 6379 --port 0 \
    --tls-cert-file ./tests/tls/redis.crt \
    --tls-key-file ./tests/tls/redis.key \
    --tls-ca-cert-file ./tests/tls/ca.crt
```

## Connecting with redis-cli

```bash
./src/redis-cli --tls \
    --cert ./tests/tls/redis.crt \
    --key ./tests/tls/redis.key \
    --cacert ./tests/tls/ca.crt
```

## Additional Configurations

- **Client Authentication:** By default, Redis uses mutual TLS. To disable client certificate authentication: `tls-auth-clients no`
- **Replication:** For replica servers to use TLS: `tls-replication yes`
- **Cluster:** For Redis Cluster: `tls-cluster yes`
- **Sentinel:** Inherits TLS settings; uses `tls-replication` directive

## Performance Note

TLS adds overhead for encryption/decryption and integrity checks, which decreases throughput. Redis 8.0+ supports I/O threading with TLS to improve performance.

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/security/encryption.md > TLS]

Run `./utils/gen-test-certs.sh` to generate a root CA and a server\\\\n   certificate.\\\\n\\\\n2. Run `./runtest --tls` or `./runtest-cluster --tls` to run Redis and Redis\\\\n   Cluster tests in TLS mode.\\\\n\\\\nTo manually run a Redis server with TLS mode (assuming `gen-test-certs.sh` was\\\\ninvoked so sample certificates/keys are available):\\\\n\\\\n    ./src/redis-server --tls-port 6379 --port 0 \\\\\\\\\\\\n        --tls-cert-file ./tests/tls/redis.crt \\\\\\\\\\\\n        --tls-key-file ./tests/tls/redis.key \\\\\\\\\\\\n        --tls-ca-cert-file ./tests/tls/ca.crt\\\\n\\\\nTo connect to this Redis server with `redis-cli`:\\\\n\\\\n    ./src/redis-cli --tls \\\\\\\\\\\\n        --cert ./tests/tls/redis.crt \\\\\\\\\\\\n        --key ./tests/tls/redis.key \\\\\\\\\\\\n        --cacert ./tests/tls/ca.crt\\\\n\\\\nIn order to support TLS, Redis must be configured with a X.509 certificate and a\\\\nprivate key. In addition, it is necessary to specify a CA certificate bundle\\\\nfile or path to be used as a trusted root when validating certificates. To\\\\nsupport DH based ciphers, a DH params file can also be configured. For example:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\ntls-cert-file /path/to/redis.crt\\\\ntls-key-file /path/to/redis.key\\\\ntls-ca-cert-file /path/to/ca.crt\\\\ntls-dh-params-file /path/to/redis.dh\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThe `tls-port` configuration directive enables accepting SSL/TLS connections on\\\\nthe specified port. **Prerequisites:** Install OpenSSL development libraries (e.g., `libssl-dev` on Debian/Ubuntu)

## Configuration

Configure Redis with the required certificates and keys in `redis.conf`:

```
tls-cert-file /path/to/redis.crt
tls-key-file /path/to/redis.key
tls-ca-cert-file /path/to/ca.crt
tls-dh-params-file /path/to/redis.dh
```

## Enabling TLS Port

Enable TLS on a specific port (in addition to regular TCP):

```
tls-port 6379
```

To use **only TLS** and disable non-encrypted connections:

```
port 0
tls-port 6379
```

## Starting Redis Server with TLS

```bash
./src/redis-server --tls-port 6379 --port 0 \
    --tls-cert-file ./tests/tls/redis.crt \
    --tls-key-file ./tests/tls/redis.key \
    --tls-ca-cert-file ./tests/tls/ca.crt
```

## Connecting with redis-cli

```bash
./src/redis-cli --tls \
    --cert ./tests/tls/redis.crt \
    --key ./tests/tls/redis.key \
    --cacert ./tests/tls/ca.crt
```

## Additional Configurations

- **Client Authentication:** By default, Redis uses mutual TLS. To disable client certificate authentication: `tls-auth-clients no`
- **Replication:** For replica servers to use TLS: `tls-replication yes`
- **Cluster:** For Redis Cluster: `tls-cluster yes`
- **Sentinel:** Inherits TLS settings; uses `tls-replication` directive

## Performance Note

TLS adds overhead for encryption/decryption and integrity checks, which decreases throughput. Redis 8.0+ supports I/O threading with TLS to improve performance.

query: Redis debugging 有哪些常用工具和命令？
answer:
根据检索结果，Redis debugging 有以下常用工具和命令：

## 1. 客户端管理与调试

**CLIENT 命令系列** — 检查和管理客户端连接状态：
- `CLIENT LIST` — 列出所有连接的客户端及其状态（地址、文件描述符、空闲时间、执行的命令等）
- `CLIENT KILL` — 关闭指定客户端连接
- `CLIENT SETNAME` / `CLIENT GETNAME` — 设置/获取客户端连接名称（便于在 SLOWLOG 中识别）

## 2. Lua 脚本调试

**LDB (Lua Debugger)** — Redis 3.2+ 内置的完整 Lua 调试器：
```bash
redis-cli --ldb --eval /tmp/script.lua
```

主要调试命令：
- `step` / `next` — 单步执行
- `continue` — 运行到下一个断点
- `break <line>` — 设置断点
- `print <var>` — 查看变量值
- `list` — 查看源代码
- `redis <cmd>` — 执行 Redis 命令
- `redis.debug()` — 在脚本中输出调试信息到控制台

## 3. GDB 调试（崩溃分析）

当 Redis 进程崩溃时：
- 使用 `make noopt` 编译无优化版本（便于调试）
- 用 GDB 附加到运行中的进程或分析 core dump 文件
- 适用于需要深入分析内存状态和崩溃原因的场景

## 4. 内存测试

**redis-server --test-memory** — 内置内存测试工具，用于排查硬件 RAM 问题（很多崩溃实际是由损坏的 RAM 引起）

## 5. 向量集调试（Vector Sets）

针对向量搜索的专用调试命令：
- `VSIM ... TRUTH` — 使用线性扫描验证结果准确性
- `VGETATTR` — 检查元素属性（排查过滤器问题）
- `VLINKS ... WITHSCORES` — 检查 HNSW 图的节点连接情况

## 6. 日志与监控

- `redis.log()` — 在 Lua 脚本或 Redis Stack 函数中写入日志
- `SLOWLOG` — 查看慢查询日志（配合 CLIENT SETNAME 识别问题客户端）
- Pub/Sub — 用于无法访问日志文件时的调试输出

## 7. 性能与延迟排查

参考 Redis 延迟故障排查指南（Latency Troubleshooting Guide）处理性能问题。

---

Usually tracking and fixing a bug is an exercise in\\\\ngathering more information about the state of the program at the moment the\\\\nbug happens, so GDB is an extremely useful tool.\\\\n\\\\nGDB can be used in two ways:\\\\n\\\\n* It can attach to a running program and inspect the state of it at runtime.\\\\n* It can inspect the state of a program that already terminated using what is called a *core file*, that is, the image of the memory at the time the program was running.\\\\n\\\\nFrom the point of view of investigating Redis bugs we need to use both of these\\\\nGDB modes. This makes the Redis executable faster, but at the\\\\nsame time it makes Redis (like any other program) harder to inspect using GDB.\\\\n\\\\nIt is better to attach GDB to Redis compiled without optimizations using the\\\\n`make noopt` command (instead of just using the plain `make` command). GDB still works\\\\nagainst executables compiled with optimizations.\\\\n\\\\nYou should not be overly concerned at the loss of performance from compiling Redis\\\\nwithout optimizations. The default kernels shipped with these distributions are not recommended. See [the latency page]() for more information.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -0.3281,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"81091cbf\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"81091cbf-001\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/programmability/lua-debugging.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Debugging Lua scripts in Redis\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Quick start\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"A simple way to get started with the Lua debugger is to watch this video\\\\nintroduction:\\\\n\\\\n<iframe width=\\\\\\"560\\\\\\" height=\\\\\\"315\\\\\\" src=\\\\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/IMvRfStaoyM\\\\\\" frameborder=\\\\\\"0\\\\\\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\\\\n\\\\n> Important Note:  please make sure to avoid debugging Lua scripts using your Redis production server.\\\\nUse a development server instead.\\\\nAlso note that using the synchronous debugging mode (which is NOT the default) results in the Redis server blocking for all the time the debugging session lasts.\\\\n\\\\nTo start a new debugging session using `redis-cli` do the following:\\\\n\\\\n1. Create your script in some file with your preferred editor. Let\'s assume you are editing your Redis Lua script located at `/tmp/script.lua`.\\\\n2. Start a debugging session with:\\\\n\\\\n    ./redis-cli --ldb --eval /tmp/script.lua\\\\n\\\\nNote that with the `--eval` option of `redis-cli` you can pass key names and arguments to the script, separated by a comma, like in the following example:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n./redis-cli --ldb --eval /tmp/script.lua mykey somekey , arg1 arg2\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nYou\'ll enter a special mode where `redis-cli` no longer accepts its normal\\\\ncommands, but instead prints a help screen and passes the unmodified debugging\\\\ncommands directly to Redis.\\\\n\\\\nThe only commands which are not passed to the Redis debugger are:\\\\n\\\\n* `quit` -- this will terminate the debugging session.\\\\nIt\'s like removing all the breakpoints and using the `continue` debugging command.\\\\nMoreover the command will exit from `redis-cli`.\\\\n* `restart` -- the debugging session will restart from scratch, **reloading the new version of the script from the file**.\\\\nSo a normal debugging cycle involves modifying the script after some debugging, and calling `restart` in order to start debugging again with the new script changes.\\\\n* `help` -- this command is passed to the Redis Lua debugger, that will print a list of commands like the following:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nlua debugger> help\\\\nRedis Lua debugger help:\\\\n[h]elp               Show this help.\\\\n[s]tep               Run current line and stop again.\\\\n[n]ext               Alias for step.\\\\n[c]ontinue           Run till next breakpoint.\\\\n[l]ist               List source code around current line.\\\\n[l]ist [line]        List source code around [line].\\\\n                     line = 0 means: current position.\\\\n[l]ist [line] [ctx]  In this form [ctx] specifies how many lines\\\\n                     to show before/after [line].\\\\n[w]hole              List all source code. Alias for \'list 1 1000000\'.\\\\n[p]rint              Show all the local variables.\\\\n[p]rint <var>        Show the value of the specified variable.\\\\n                     Can also show global vars KEYS and ARGV.\\\\n[b]reak              Show all breakpoints.\\\\n[b]reak <line>       Add a breakpoint to the specified line.\\\\n[b]reak -<line>      Remove breakpoint from the specified line.\\\\n[b]reak 0            Remove all breakpoints.\\\\n[t]race              Show a backtrace.\\\\n[e]val <code>        Execute some Lua code (in a different callframe).\\\\n[r]edis <cmd>        Execute a Redis command.\\\\n[m]axlen [len]       Trim logged Redis replies and Lua var dumps to len.\\\\n                     Specifying zero as <len> means unlimited.\\\\n[a]bort              Stop the execution of the script. In sync\\\\n                     mode dataset changes will be retained.\\\\n\\\\nDebugger functions you can call from Lua scripts:\\\\nredis.debug()        Produce logs in the debugger console.\\\\nredis.breakpoint()   Stop execution as if there was a breakpoint in the\\\\n                     next line of code.\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nNote that when you start the debugger it will start in **stepping mode**.\\\\nIt will stop at the first line of the script that actually does something before executing it.\\\\n\\\\nFrom this point you usually call `step` in order to execute the line and go to the next line.\\\\nWhile you step Redis will show all the commands executed by the server like in the following example:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n* Stopped at 1, stop reason = step over\\\\n-> 1   redis.call(\'ping\')\\\\nlua debugger> step\\\\n<redis> ping\\\\n<reply> \\\\\\"+PONG\\\\\\"\\\\n* Stopped at 2, stop reason = step over\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThe `<redis>` and `<reply>` lines show the command executed by the line just\\\\nexecuted, and the reply from the server. Make judicious use of the `redis.log` function, which writes to the Redis log file.\\\\n1. If the key does not exist, it creates a new filter. |\\\\n| [BF.LOADCHUNK]() | <span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Supported</span><br /><span><br /></span> | <span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Flexible & Annual</span><br /><span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Free & Fixed</nobr></span> | Restores a Bloom filter previously saved with [BF.SCANDUMP](). |\\\\n| [BF.MADD]() | <span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Supported</span><br /><span><br /></span> | <span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Flexible & Annual</span><br /><span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Free & Fixed</nobr></span> | Adds multiple items to the filter. |\\\\n| [BF.MEXISTS]() | <span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Supported</span><br /><span><br /></span> | <span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Flexible & Annual</span><br /><span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Free & Fixed</nobr></span> | For multiple items, checks if each item exists in the filter. |\\\\n| [BF.RESERVE]() | <span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Supported</span><br /><span><br /></span> | <span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Flexible & Annual</span><br /><span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Free & Fixed</nobr></span> | Creates a Bloom filter. Sets the false positive rate and capacity. |\\\\n| [BF.SCANDUMP]() | <span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Supported</span><br /><span><br /></span> | <span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Flexible & Annual</span><br /><span title=\\\\\\"Supported\\\\\\">✅ Free & Fixed</nobr></span> | Starts an incremental save of a Bloom filter. |\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -0.9308,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"1c57d308\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"1c57d308-001\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/deprecated-features/triggers-and-functions/Debugging.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Debugging\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Overview > Use Redis pub/sub\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"If you have access to the Redis log files, `redis.log` is a good method to use when debugging. However, there is a drawback. Redis Cloud users do not have access to the Redis log files, and it\'s pretty common that only system administrators have access to them on self-hosted installations. Fortunately, you can also use Redis pub/sub, which will be discussed in the next section.\\\\n\\\\nYou don\'t have to do anything special to use `redis.log`, as it\'s always available. Here is an example:\\\\n\\\\n```javascript\\\\n#!js api_version=1.0 name=lib\\\\n\\\\nredis.registerFunction(\'hello\', ()=> {\\\\n  redis.log(\'Hello log\')\\\\n  return \'Hello from an external file\'\\\\n})\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nAfter loading the library and executing the function with `TFCALL`, you\'ll see something like the following in your Redis log file:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n45718:M 01 Nov 2023 07:02:40.593 * <redisgears_2> Hello log\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nIf you don\'t have access to your Redis database log files, you can use pub/sub. The following example demonstrates how to use the [client.call]() API to publish to a pub/sub channel.\\\\n\\\\n```javascript\\\\n#!js api_version=1.0 name=lib\\\\n\\\\nconst logChannel = \'tfLogChannel\'\\\\n\\\\nfunction publog(client, message) {\\\\n  client.call(\'publish\', logChannel, message)\\\\n}\\\\n\\\\nredis.registerFunction(\'tflog\', (client) => {\\\\n  publog(client, \'sample pub/sub log message\')\\\\n  return \'sample\'\\\\n})\\\\n```\\\\nIn a CLI session, subscribe to the `tfLogChannel` channel and watch for messages.\\\\n\\\\n```redis\\\\n$ redis-cli\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> subscribe tfLogChannel\\\\n1) \\\\\\"subscribe\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"tfLogChannel\\\\\\"\\\\n3) (integer) 1\\\\nReading messages... (press Ctrl-C to quit or any key to type command)\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nIn another CLI session, load the library, replacing what was already there, and then call the new function:\\\\n\\\\n```redis\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> TFCALL lib.tflog 0\\\\n\\\\\\"sample\\\\\\"\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nYou\'ll see the following in the previous CLI session:\\\\n\\\\n```redis\\\\n1) \\\\\\"message\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"tfLogChannel\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"sample pub/sub log message\\\\\\"\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThere is a downside to using pub/sub. Redis pub/sub provides at-most-once message delivery semantics, which means that once a message is sent, it won\'t be sent again. So, if a message isn\'t consumed, it\'s gone forever. This is likely okay for debugging, but for the longer term, `redis.log` is the better solution for log persistence.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -1.0794,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"81091cbf\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"81091cbf-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/programmability/lua-debugging.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Debugging Lua scripts in Redis\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Starting with version 3.2 Redis includes a complete Lua debugger, that can be\\\\nused in order to make the task of writing complex Redis scripts much simpler.\\\\n\\\\nThe Redis Lua debugger, codenamed LDB, has the following important features:\\\\n\\\\n* It uses a server-client model, so it\'s a remote debugger.\\\\nThe Redis server acts as the debugging server, while the default client is `redis-cli`. \\\\nHowever other clients can be developed by following the simple protocol implemented by the server.\\\\n* By default every new debugging session is a forked session.\\\\nIt means that while the Redis Lua script is being debugged, the server does not block and is usable for development or in order to execute multiple debugging sessions in parallel.\\\\nThis also means that changes are **rolled back** after the script debugging session finished, so that\'s possible to restart a new debugging session again, using exactly the same Redis data set as the previous debugging session.\\\\n* An alternative synchronous (non forked) debugging model is available on demand, so that changes to the dataset can be retained.\\\\nIn this mode the server blocks for the time the debugging session is active.\\\\n* Support for step by step execution.\\\\n* Support for static and dynamic breakpoints.\\\\n* Support from logging the debugged script into the debugger console.\\\\n* Inspection of Lua variables.\\\\n* Tracing of Redis commands executed by the script.\\\\n* Pretty printing of Redis and Lua values.\\\\n* Infinite loops and long execution detection, which simulates a breakpoint.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text='根据检索结果，Redis debugging 有以下常用工具和命令：

## 1. 客户端管理与调试

**CLIENT 命令系列** — 检查和管理客户端连接状态：
- `CLIENT LIST` — 列出所有连接的客户端及其状态（地址、文件描述符、空闲时间、执行的命令等）
- `CLIENT KILL` — 关闭指定客户端连接
- `CLIENT SETNAME` / `CLIENT GETNAME` — 设置/获取客户端连接名称（便于在 SLOWLOG 中识别）

## 2. Lua 脚本调试

**LDB (Lua Debugger)** — Redis 3.2+ 内置的完整 Lua 调试器：
```bash
redis-cli --ldb --eval /tmp/script.lua
```

主要调试命令：
- `step` / `next` — 单步执行
- `continue` — 运行到下一个断点
- `break <line>` — 设置断点
- `print <var>` — 查看变量值
- `list` — 查看源代码
- `redis <cmd>` — 执行 Redis 命令
- `redis.debug()` — 在脚本中输出调试信息到控制台

## 3. GDB 调试（崩溃分析）

当 Redis 进程崩溃时：
- 使用 `make noopt` 编译无优化版本（便于调试）
- 用 GDB 附加到运行中的进程或分析 core dump 文件
- 适用于需要深入分析内存状态和崩溃原因的场景

## 4. 内存测试

**redis-server --test-memory** — 内置内存测试工具，用于排查硬件 RAM 问题（很多崩溃实际是由损坏的 RAM 引起）

## 5. 向量集调试（Vector Sets）

针对向量搜索的专用调试命令：
- `VSIM ... TRUTH` — 使用线性扫描验证结果准确性
- `VGETATTR` — 检查元素属性（排查过滤器问题）
- `VLINKS ... WITHSCORES` — 检查 HNSW 图的节点连接情况

## 6. 日志与监控

- `redis.log()` — 在 Lua 脚本或 Redis Stack 函数中写入日志
- `SLOWLOG` — 查看慢查询日志（配合 CLIENT SETNAME 识别问题客户端）
- Pub/Sub — 用于无法访问日志文件时的调试输出

## 7. 性能与延迟排查

参考 Redis 延迟故障排查指南（Latency Troubleshooting Guide）处理性能问题。

---

**来源**：
- [redis-docs/develop/reference/clients.md > CLIENT 命令](chunk_id: c5c59021-005)
- [redis-docs/develop/programmability/lua-debugging.md](chunk_id: 81091cbf-000, 81091cbf-001, 81091cbf-003)
- [redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/debugging.md](chunk_id: 41480601-000)
- [redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/troubleshooting.md](chunk_id: 1d4c65d2-000)
- [redis-docs/develop/data-types/vector-sets/troubleshooting.md](chunk_id: dacbe75d-000)')]

query: How to upgrade a Redis cluster without downtime?
answer:
Based on the knowledge base search, here's how to upgrade a Redis cluster without downtime:

## Upgrade Process (Rolling Upgrade)

The key is to upgrade nodes **one at a time**, starting with replicas, then masters:

### 1. Prepare and Backup
Before upgrading, create snapshots on each node:
```bash
redis-cli -p <port> SAVE
```

Identify data directories:
```bash
redis-cli -p <port> CONFIG GET dir
```

Make copies of all data files (`dump.rdb` or `appendonly.aof.*`) before proceeding.

### 2. Upgrade Replica Nodes First
Replicas are straightforward:
- Stop the replica node
- Install Redis 8
- Restart with the new version

Clients using replicas for read scaling will automatically reconnect to other available replicas during the upgrade.

### 3. Upgrade Master Nodes (Zero-Downtime)
For each master, follow this procedure:

1. **Trigger manual failover** to promote a replica to master:
   ```bash
   CLUSTER FAILOVER
   ```

2. **Wait** for the old master to become a replica

3. **Upgrade** the node (now a replica) using the same process as other replicas

4. **(Optional)** Trigger another manual failover to restore the upgraded node as master

### 4. Verify the Upgrade
After upgrading each node, verify:
```bash
redis-cli -p <port> INFO server | grep redis_version
redis-cli -p <port> cluster info
redis-cli --cluster check <IP address>:<port>
```

Also verify data accessibility and client connectivity.

## Important Notes

⚠️ **Redis Query Engine**: Won't be fully operational until all master shards complete their upgrades. Queries during upgrade may return errors or "Waiting for all nodes to connect".

⚠️ **Practice First**: Test the upgrade in a controlled environment (Docker recommended) before production.

**Supported Upgrade Paths**:
- Redis 7.x → Redis 8
- Redis Stack 7.2/7.4 → Redis 8

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/install/upgrade/cluster.md > Verify the upgrade]

This guide assumes you have installed Redis using one of the supported methods listed [here]().\\\\n\\\\nBefore upgrading, create a snapshot of your current dataset on each node (identified by its port) using the following command:\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\nredis-cli -p <port> SAVE\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nRepeat for every node in your cluster, both masters and replicas.\\\\n\\\\nThis creates or updates an `RDB` file, for example `dump.rdb`, in the node\'s Redis data directory. Use the names defined in your `redis.conf` file if different from the defaults.\\\\n\\\\nUse the following command on each node to identify where your data directories are located:\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\nredis-cli -p <port> CONFIG GET dir\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nMake a copy of the files contained in each of those directories before proceeding.\\\\n\\\\nUpgrade each node one at a time, starting with the replicas, using these steps:\\\\n\\\\n1. Stop the current version of Redis Open Source or Redis Stack server.\\\\n1. Follow the installation steps that correspond to your [Redis distribution]() to install Redis 8.\\\\n1. Start Redis 8 if it didn\'t start automatically.\\\\n\\\\nIf necessary, restore the saved files to their original locations on each node. Then restart Redis on each node.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nRedis Query Engine won\'t be fully operational until all master shards have completed their upgrades.\\\\nAny queries sent during the upgrade process will either return errors or a message such as \\\\\\"Waiting for all nodes to connect\\\\\\".\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\nredis-cli -p <port> INFO server | grep redis_version\\\\nredis-cli -p <port> cluster info\\\\nredis-cli --cluster check <IP address>:<port>\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nYou should also verify that your data is accessible and that your clients can connect successfully.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.8464,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"a21b6283\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"a21b6283-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/install/upgrade-module.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Upgrade Module\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Upgrade a module for a database\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Upgrade a module in Redis Software to get the latest features and fixes.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n- If you upgrade a single-node cluster, it does not load the new modules that are bundled with the new cluster version.\\\\n\\\\n- Before you upgrade a database with the RediSearch module enabled to Redis 5.0, you must upgrade the RediSearch module to version 1.4.2 or later.\\\\n\\\\nBefore you upgrade a module enabled in a database, [install the new version of the module on the cluster]().\\\\n\\\\nAfter you install an updated module on the cluster, you can upgrade databases to use the new module version.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nAfter you upgrade the module for a database, the database shards restart. This causes a short interruption in the availability of this database across the cluster.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nTo upgrade a module enabled for a database:\\\\n\\\\n1. Connect to the terminal of a node in the cluster.\\\\n1. Run `rladmin status` to list the databases on the node.\\\\n1. Copy the name of the database that uses the module that you want to upgrade.\\\\n\\\\n    \\\\n\\\\n1. Find the exact module name and version:\\\\n\\\\n    1. Extract the module archive (zip) file.\\\\n    1. Open the JSON file.\\\\n    1. Find the module name and version number in the file.\\\\n\\\\n    Here\'s an example of the JSON file for the RediSearch module:\\\\n\\\\n    \\\\n\\\\n1. To see the versions of the modules on the cluster, run either:\\\\n\\\\n    - `rladmin status modules` - Shows the latest modules available on the cluster and the modules used by databases.\\\\n    - `rladmin status modules all` - Shows all of the modules available on the cluster and the modules used by databases.\\\\n\\\\n1. To upgrade a database to the latest version of Redis and its modules to the latest version without changing the module arguments:\\\\n\\\\n    - For clusters with Redis Software versions 7.8.2 or later, run:\\\\n\\\\n        ```sh\\\\n        rladmin upgrade db < database-name | database-ID >\\\\n        ```\\\\n\\\\n    - For clusters with versions earlier than 7.8.2, include the `latest_with_modules` option:\\\\n\\\\n        ```sh\\\\n        rladmin upgrade db < database-name | database-ID > latest_with_modules\\\\n        ```\\\\n\\\\n    \\\\nThe upgrade process does not validate the module upgrade arguments, and incorrect arguments can cause unexpected downtime. Test module upgrade commands in a test environment before you upgrade modules in production. \\\\n    \\\\n\\\\n    - Use `keep_redis_version` to upgrade the modules without upgrading the database to the latest Redis version.\\\\n    \\\\n        `keep_redis_version` is deprecated as of Redis Software version 7.8.2. To upgrade modules without upgrading the Redis database version, set `redis_version` to the current Redis database version instead.\\\\n\\\\n    - To specify the modules to upgrade, add the following for each module:\\\\n\\\\n        ```sh\\\\n        and module module_name <module_name> version <new_module_version_number> module_args \\\\\\"<module arguments>\\\\\\"\\\\n        ```\\\\n\\\\n        For the module arguments, use one of the following:\\\\n\\\\n        - `module_args \\\\\\"<module_arguments>\\\\\\"` to replace the existing module arguments.\\\\n\\\\n        - `module_args \\\\\\"\\\\\\"` without arguments to remove the existing module arguments.\\\\n\\\\n        - `module_args keep_args` to use the existing module arguments.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.7408,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"3022c99e\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"3022c99e-018\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/scaling.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Scale with Redis Cluster\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Create and use a Redis Cluster > Upgrade nodes in a Redis Cluster\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Upgrading replica nodes is easy since you just need to stop the node and restart\\\\nit with an updated version of Redis. If there are clients scaling reads using\\\\nreplica nodes, they should be able to reconnect to a different replica if a given\\\\none is not available.\\\\n\\\\nUpgrading masters is a bit more complex, and the suggested procedure is:\\\\n\\\\n1. Use [`CLUSTER FAILOVER`](/commands/cluster-failover) to trigger a manual failover of the master to one of its replicas.\\\\n   (See the [Manual failover](#manual-failover) in this topic.)\\\\n2. Wait for the master to turn into a replica.\\\\n3. Finally upgrade the node as you do for replicas.\\\\n4. If you want the master to be the node you just upgraded, trigger a new manual failover in order to turn back the upgraded node into a master.\\\\n\\\\nFollowing this procedure you should upgrade one node after the other until\\\\nall the nodes are upgraded.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -0.0883,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"731bcf79\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"731bcf79-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/install/add-module-to-cluster.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Add Module To Cluster\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Add user-defined modules during bootstrapping (Redis Software v8.0.6 and later) {#bootstrap-user-defined-module}\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"[Redis Software]() comes packaged with several modules that provide additional Redis capabilities such as [search and query](), [JSON](), [time series](), and [probabilistic data structures](). As of version 8.0, Redis Software includes multiple feature sets, compatible with different Redis database versions. You can view the installed modules, their versions, and their minimum compatible Redis database versions from **Cluster > Modules** in the Cluster Manager UI.\\\\n\\\\nTo use other modules or upgrade an existing module to a more recent version, you need to install the new module package on your cluster.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nSome module versions are not supported or recommended for use with Redis Software.\\\\n\\\\nThe module must be packaged as a `.zip` file containing:\\\\n\\\\n- **module.json**: A metadata file with module information including:\\\\n  - `module_name`: The actual module name\\\\n  - `version`: Numeric version\\\\n  - `semantic_version`: Semantic version string (for example, \\\\\\"1.0.0\\\\\\")\\\\n  - `min_redis_version`: Minimum compatible Redis version\\\\n  - `commands`: List of commands the module provides\\\\n  - `capabilities`: List of module capabilities\\\\n\\\\n- **Module binary**: The compiled `.so` file for the target platform\\\\n\\\\nTo install or upgrade a module on a [Redis Software]() cluster, you need a module package.\\\\n\\\\n- For versions of official Redis modules that are not available from the [Redis download center](https://redis.io/downloads/), [contact support](https://redis.io/support/).\\\\n\\\\n- For custom-packaged modules, download a [custom-packaged module](https://redislabs.com/community/redis-modules-hub/) from the developer.\\\\n\\\\n- User-defined modules are downloaded automatically if you [add them during bootstrapping](#bootstrap-user-defined-module).\\\\n\\\\nAs of Redis Software version 8.0.6, you can include `user_defined_modules` in REST API requests to [initiate boostrap operations]() such as `create_cluster`, `join_cluster`, or `recover_cluster`. Each node in the cluster independently downloads and installs the specified modules during its bootstrap process.\\\\n\\\\n`user_defined_modules` has the following JSON schema:\\\\n\\\\n```json\\\\n{\\\\n  \\\\\\"user_defined_modules\\\\\\": [\\\\n    {\\\\n      \\\\\\"name\\\\\\": \\\\\\"string (required)\\\\\\",\\\\n      \\\\\\"location\\\\\\": {\\\\n        \\\\\\"location_type\\\\\\": \\\\\\"http | https (required)\\\\\\",\\\\n        \\\\\\"url\\\\\\": \\\\\\"string (required)\\\\\\",\\\\n        \\\\\\"credentials\\\\\\": {\\\\n          \\\\\\"username\\\\\\": \\\\\\"string (optional)\\\\\\",\\\\n          \\\\\\"password\\\\\\": \\\\\\"string (optional)\\\\\\"\\\\n        }\\\\n      }\\\\n    }\\\\n  ]\\\\n}\\\\n```\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -0.1488,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"23a2172f\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"23a2172f-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/search/redisearch-2-upgrade.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisearch 2 Upgrade\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Replicate data from RediSearch 1.x to RediSearch 2.x\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"RediSearch 2.x includes some significant architectural changes that improve functionality.\\\\nThe main change is that RediSearch 2.x stores indexes outside of the Redis database that contains the data.\\\\nThis makes commands more efficient and improves replication between clusters because the index changes are managed by the participating clusters rather than being synchronized with the data.\\\\n\\\\nThis change allows databases with RediSearch to support:\\\\n\\\\n- [Active-Active databases]()\\\\n- Database cluster re-sharding\\\\n- Replica Of to a sharded destination database\\\\n- [EXPIRE]() of documents reflected in the index\\\\n\\\\nIn addition, RediSearch 2.x indexes data that already existed in the database at the time that the index was created.\\\\n\\\\nTo upgrade a Redis Software database with RediSearch 1.x to RediSearch 2.x, you have to set up a new database with RediSearch 2.x and use the `RediSearch_Syncer.py` script to replicate the data from the old database into the new database.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nAfter you create the database or after you replicate the data, [create an index]() with a prefix or filter that defines the keys that you want to index.\\\\n\\\\nInstall Python 3 on the host where you plan to run the synchronization script:\\\\n\\\\n```sh\\\\nsudo apt install python3\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n- Suggestions (`FT.SUG` APIs) and spell check dictionaries are not replicated from the source database. You need to add them manually.\\\\n- If there are multiple indexes on the source and the documents do not have prefixes that identify them with an index, RediSearch 2.x can\'t index the documents in their respective indexes.\\\\n- The `NOSAVE` option is no longer supported. Indexes created with the `NOSAVE` option can\'t be upgraded.\\\\n- Databases that contain temporary indexes can\'t be upgraded.\\\\n- Any attempt to add, delete, or modify an index during the upgrade will cause the replication process to fail. During the upgrade, the source database can only receive `FT.ADD` and `FT.DEL` commands.\\\\n\\\\nTo replicate a RediSearch 1.x database to a RediSearch 2.x database:\\\\n\\\\n1. Sign in to the admin console of the Redis Software cluster where you want to host the new RediSearch 2.x database.\\\\n\\\\n1. [Add the RediSearch 2.x module](#add-new-module) to the cluster.\\\\n\\\\n1. [Create a new database](#create-db) with RediSearch 2.x.\\\\n\\\\n1. [Migrate data](#migrate-data) to the RediSearch 2.x database.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text='Based on the knowledge base search, here's how to upgrade a Redis cluster without downtime:

## Upgrade Process (Rolling Upgrade)

The key is to upgrade nodes **one at a time**, starting with replicas, then masters:

### 1. Prepare and Backup
Before upgrading, create snapshots on each node:
```bash
redis-cli -p <port> SAVE
```

Identify data directories:
```bash
redis-cli -p <port> CONFIG GET dir
```

Make copies of all data files (`dump.rdb` or `appendonly.aof.*`) before proceeding.

### 2. Upgrade Replica Nodes First
Replicas are straightforward:
- Stop the replica node
- Install Redis 8
- Restart with the new version

Clients using replicas for read scaling will automatically reconnect to other available replicas during the upgrade.

### 3. Upgrade Master Nodes (Zero-Downtime)
For each master, follow this procedure:

1. **Trigger manual failover** to promote a replica to master:
   ```bash
   CLUSTER FAILOVER
   ```

2. **Wait** for the old master to become a replica

3. **Upgrade** the node (now a replica) using the same process as other replicas

4. **(Optional)** Trigger another manual failover to restore the upgraded node as master

### 4. Verify the Upgrade
After upgrading each node, verify:
```bash
redis-cli -p <port> INFO server | grep redis_version
redis-cli -p <port> cluster info
redis-cli --cluster check <IP address>:<port>
```

Also verify data accessibility and client connectivity.

## Important Notes

⚠️ **Redis Query Engine**: Won't be fully operational until all master shards complete their upgrades. Queries during upgrade may return errors or "Waiting for all nodes to connect".

⚠️ **Practice First**: Test the upgrade in a controlled environment (Docker recommended) before production.

**Supported Upgrade Paths**:
- Redis 7.x → Redis 8
- Redis Stack 7.2/7.4 → Redis 8

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/install/upgrade/cluster.md > Verify the upgrade]

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/scaling.md > Upgrade nodes in a Redis Cluster]')]

query: What signals does Redis handle and how to gracefully shutdown?
answer:
Based on the search results, here's what I found about Redis signal handling and graceful shutdown:

## Signal Handling

Redis handles the following POSIX signals:

### SIGTERM and SIGINT (Graceful Shutdown)
When Redis receives `SIGTERM` or `SIGINT`, it performs a **graceful shutdown** rather than exiting immediately. The shutdown is scheduled and starts as soon as the current command completes (with a possible delay of ≤0.1 seconds).

**Shutdown Process:**
1. **Wait for replicas** (Redis 7.0+): Pauses write clients and waits up to `shutdown-timeout` (default 10 seconds) for lagging replicas to catch up with replication offset
2. **Kill background processes**: Terminates any child process performing RDB save or AOF rewrite
3. **Flush AOF**: If AOF is active, calls `fsync()` to flush buffers to disk
4. **Synchronous RDB save**: If configured for RDB persistence, performs a blocking save (doesn't use extra memory)
5. **Cleanup**: Removes PID file (if daemonized) and Unix domain socket (if enabled)
6. **Exit**: Server exits with code 0

**Important Notes:**
- If RDB save fails, shutdown is aborted and server continues running to prevent data loss
- If a long-running Lua script is blocking, use `SCRIPT KILL` first
- Before Redis 7.0, shutting down a diskless master could cause data loss - consider using `FAILOVER` to demote the master first

### Crash Signals
The following signals are treated as crashes:
- **SIGSEGV** (segmentation fault)
- **SIGBUS** (bus error)  
- **SIGFPE** (floating point exception)
- **SIGILL** (illegal instruction)

When trapped, Redis:
1. Logs a bug report with stack trace and client state
2. Performs fast memory test (Redis 2.8+)
3. Removes PID file if daemonized
4. Resends signal to itself for default action (e.g., core dump)

### SIGUSR1 (Kill RDB Child Without Error)
Since Redis 2.6.10, `SIGUSR1` can kill the RDB-saving child process without triggering an error condition. This allows stopping RDB saves without Redis entering the `MISCONFIG` error state that blocks writes.

[Source: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/reference/signals.md > SIGTERM and SIGINT, Kill the RDB file without errors]
