Data locality reduces overall latency and saves networking resources.\\\\n* Blocking semantics that ensure the script\'s atomic execution.\\\\n* Enabling the composition of simple capabilities that are either missing from Redis or are too niche to be a part of it.\\\\n\\\\nLua lets you run part of your application logic inside Redis.\\\\nSuch scripts can perform conditional updates across multiple keys, possibly combining several different data types atomically.\\\\n\\\\nScripts are executed in Redis by an embedded execution engine.\\\\nPresently, Redis supports a single scripting engine, the [Lua 5.1](https://www.lua.org/) interpreter.\\\\nPlease refer to the [Redis Lua API Reference]() page for complete documentation.\\\\n\\\\nAlthough the server executes them, Eval scripts are regarded as a part of the client-side application, which is why they\'re not named, versioned, or persisted.\\\\nSo all scripts may need to be reloaded by the application at any time if missing (after a server restart, fail-over to a replica, etc.).\\\\nAs of version 7.0, [Redis Functions]() offer an alternative approach to programmability which allow the server itself to be extended with additional programmed logic.\\\\n\\\\nWe\'ll start scripting with Redis by using the [`EVAL`]() command.\\\\n\\\\nHere\'s our first example:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n> EVAL \\\\\\"return \'Hello, scripting!\'\\\\\\" 0\\\\n\\\\\\"Hello, scripting!\\\\\\"\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nIn this example, [`EVAL`]() takes two arguments.\\\\nThe first argument is a string that consists of the script\'s Lua source code.\\\\nThe script doesn\'t need to include any definitions of Lua function.\\\\nIt is just a Lua program that will run in the Redis engine\'s context.\\\\n\\\\nThe second argument is the number of arguments that follow the script\'s body, starting from the third argument, representing Redis key names.\\\\nIn this example, we used the value _0_ because we didn\'t provide the script with any arguments, whether the names of keys or not.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 4.983,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"15b2f0ac\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"15b2f0ac-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/programmability/functions-intro.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis functions\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Prologue (or, what\'s wrong with Eval Scripts?)\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Redis Functions is an API for managing code to be executed on the server. This feature, which became available in Redis 7, supersedes the use of [EVAL]() in prior versions of Redis.\\\\n\\\\nPrior versions of Redis made scripting available only via the [`EVAL`]() command, which allows a Lua script to be sent for execution by the server.\\\\nThe core use cases for [Eval Scripts]() is executing part of your application logic inside Redis, efficiently and atomically.\\\\nSuch script can perform conditional updates across multiple keys, possibly combining several different data types.\\\\n\\\\nUsing [`EVAL`]() requires that the application sends the entire script for execution every time.\\\\nBecause this results in network and script compilation overheads, Redis provides an optimization in the form of the [`EVALSHA`]() command. By first calling [`SCRIPT LOAD`]() to obtain the script\'s SHA1, the application can invoke it repeatedly afterward with its digest alone.\\\\n\\\\nBy design, Redis only caches the loaded scripts.\\\\nThat means that the script cache can become lost at any time, such as after calling [`SCRIPT FLUSH`](), after restarting the server, or when failing over to a replica.\\\\nThe application is responsible for reloading scripts during runtime if any are missing.\\\\nThe underlying assumption is that scripts are a part of the application and not maintained by the Redis server.\\\\n\\\\nThis approach suits many light-weight scripting use cases, but introduces several difficulties once an application becomes complex and relies more heavily on scripting, namely:\\\\n\\\\n1. All client application instances must maintain a copy of all scripts. That means having some mechanism that applies script updates to all of the application\'s instances.\\\\n1. Calling cached scripts within the context of a [transaction]() increases the probability of the transaction failing because of a missing script. Being more likely to fail makes using cached scripts as building blocks of workflows less attractive.\\\\n1. SHA1 digests are meaningless, making debugging the system extremely hard (e.g., in a [`MONITOR`]() session).\\\\n1. When used naively, [`EVAL`]() promotes an anti-pattern in which scripts the client application renders verbatim scripts instead of responsibly using the [`KEYS` and `ARGV` Lua APIs]().\\\\n1. Because they are ephemeral, a script can\'t call another script. This makes sharing and reusing code between scripts nearly impossible, short of client-side preprocessing (see the first point).\\\\n\\\\nTo address these needs while avoiding breaking changes to already-established and well-liked ephemeral scripts, Redis v7.0 introduces Redis Functions.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 4.9816,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"3ff5468a\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"3ff5468a-002\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/programmability/eval-intro.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Scripting with Lua\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Script cache\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"It is possible to call Redis commands from a Lua script either via [`redis.call()`]() or [`redis.pcall()`]().\\\\n\\\\nThe two are nearly identical.\\\\nBoth execute a Redis command along with its provided arguments, if these represent a well-formed command.\\\\nHowever, the difference between the two functions lies in the manner in which runtime errors (such as syntax errors, for example) are handled.\\\\nErrors raised from calling `redis.call()` function are returned directly to the client that had executed it.\\\\nConversely, errors encountered when calling the `redis.pcall()` function are returned to the script\'s execution context instead for possible handling.\\\\n\\\\nFor example, consider the following:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n> EVAL \\\\\\"return redis.call(\'SET\', KEYS[1], ARGV[1])\\\\\\" 1 foo bar\\\\nOK\\\\n```\\\\nThe above script accepts one key name and one value as its input arguments.\\\\nWhen executed, the script calls the [`SET`]() command to set the input key, _foo_, with the string value \\\\\\"bar\\\\\\".\\\\n\\\\nUntil this point, we\'ve used the [`EVAL`]() command to run our script.\\\\n\\\\nWhenever we call [`EVAL`](), we also include the script\'s source code with the request.\\\\nRepeatedly calling [`EVAL`]() to execute the same set of parameterized scripts, wastes both network bandwidth and also has some overheads in Redis.\\\\nNaturally, saving on network and compute resources is key, so, instead, Redis provides a caching mechanism for scripts.\\\\n\\\\nEvery script you execute with [`EVAL`]() is stored in a dedicated cache that the server keeps.\\\\nThe cache\'s contents are organized by the scripts\' SHA1 digest sums, so the SHA1 digest sum of a script uniquely identifies it in the cache.\\\\nYou can verify this behavior by running [`EVAL`]() and calling [`INFO`]() afterward.\\\\nYou\'ll notice that the _used_memory_scripts_eval_ and _number_of_cached_scripts_ metrics grow with every new script that\'s executed.\\\\n\\\\nAs mentioned above, dynamically-generated scripts are an anti-pattern.\\\\nGenerating scripts during the application\'s runtime may, and probably will, exhaust the host\'s memory resources for caching them.\\\\nInstead, scripts should be as generic as possible and provide customized execution via their arguments.\\\\n\\\\nA script is loaded to the server\'s cache by calling the [`SCRIPT LOAD`]() command and providing its source code.\\\\nThe server doesn\'t execute the script, but instead just compiles and loads it to the server\'s cache.\\\\nOnce loaded, you can execute the cached script with the SHA1 digest returned from the server.\\\\n\\\\nHere\'s an example of loading and then executing a cached script:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nredis> SCRIPT LOAD \\\\\\"return \'Immabe a cached script\'\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\\\"c664a3bf70bd1d45c4284ffebb65a6f2299bfc9f\\\\\\"\\\\nredis> EVALSHA c664a3bf70bd1d45c4284ffebb65a6f2299bfc9f 0\\\\n\\\\\\"Immabe a cached script\\\\\\"\\\\n```\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 3.6902,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"3ff5468a\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"3ff5468a-008\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/programmability/eval-intro.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Scripting with Lua\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Eval flags\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Starting with Redis 3.2, Redis has support for native Lua debugging.\\\\nThe Redis Lua debugger is a remote debugger consisting of a server, which is Redis itself, and a client, which is by default [`redis-cli`]().\\\\n\\\\nThe Lua debugger is described in the [Lua scripts debugging]() section of the Redis documentation.\\\\n\\\\nWhen memory usage in Redis exceeds the `maxmemory` limit, the first write command encountered in the script that uses additional memory will cause the script to abort (unless [`redis.pcall`]() was used).\\\\n\\\\nHowever, an exception to the above is when the script\'s first write command does not use additional memory, as is the case with  (for example, [`DEL`]() and [`LREM`]()).\\\\nIn this case, Redis will allow all commands in the script to run to ensure atomicity.\\\\nIf subsequent writes in the script consume additional memory, Redis\' memory usage can exceed the threshold set by the `maxmemory` configuration directive.\\\\n\\\\nAnother scenario in which a script can cause memory usage to cross the `maxmemory` threshold is when the execution begins when Redis is slightly below `maxmemory`, so the script\'s first write command is allowed.\\\\nAs the script executes, subsequent write commands consume more memory leading to the server using more RAM than the configured `maxmemory` directive.\\\\n\\\\nIn those scenarios, you should consider setting the `maxmemory-policy` configuration directive to any values other than `noeviction`.\\\\nIn addition, Lua scripts should be as fast as possible so that eviction can kick in between executions.\\\\n\\\\nNote that you can change this behaviour by using [flags](#eval-flags)\\\\n\\\\nNormally, when you run an Eval script, the server does not know how it accesses the database.\\\\nBy default, Redis assumes that all scripts read and write data.\\\\nHowever, starting with Redis 7.0, there\'s a way to declare flags when creating a script in order to tell Redis how it should behave.\\\\n\\\\nThe way to do that is by using a Shebang statement on the first line of the script like so:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n#!lua flags=no-writes,allow-stale\\\\nlocal x = redis.call(\'get\',\'x\')\\\\nreturn x\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nNote that as soon as Redis sees the `#!` comment, it\'ll treat the script as if it declares flags, even if no flags are defined,\\\\nit still has a different set of defaults compared to a script without a `#!` line.\\\\n\\\\nAnother difference is that scripts without `#!` can run commands that access keys belonging to different cluster hash slots, but ones with `#!` inherit the default flags, so they cannot.\\\\n\\\\nPlease refer to [Script flags]() to learn about the various scripts and the defaults.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 3.5281,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"3ff5468a\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"3ff5468a-004\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/programmability/eval-intro.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Scripting with Lua\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"The `SCRIPT` command\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"The Redis [`SCRIPT`]() provides several ways for controlling the scripting subsystem.\\\\nThese are:\\\\n\\\\n* [`SCRIPT FLUSH`](): this command is the only way to force Redis to flush the scripts cache.\\\\n  It is most useful in environments where the same Redis instance is reassigned to different uses.\\\\n  It is also helpful for testing client libraries\' implementations of the scripting feature.\\\\n\\\\n* [`SCRIPT EXISTS`](): given one or more SHA1 digests as arguments, this command returns an array of _1_\'s and _0_\'s.\\\\n  _1_ means the specific SHA1 is recognized as a script already present in the scripting cache. _0_\'s meaning is that a script with this SHA1 wasn\'t loaded before (or at least never since the latest call to [`SCRIPT FLUSH`]()).\\\\n\\\\n* `SCRIPT LOAD script`: this command registers the specified script in the Redis script cache. \\\\n  It is a useful command in all the contexts where we want to ensure that [`EVALSHA`]() doesn\'t not fail (for instance, in a pipeline or when called from a [`MULTI`]()/[`EXEC`]() [transaction](), without the need to execute the script.\\\\n\\\\n* [`SCRIPT KILL`](): this command is the only way to interrupt a long-running script (a.k.a slow script), short of shutting down the server.\\\\n  A script is deemed as slow once its execution\'s duration exceeds the configured [maximum execution time]() threshold.\\\\n  The [`SCRIPT KILL`]() command can be used only with scripts that did not modify the dataset during their execution (since stopping a read-only script does not violate the scripting engine\'s guaranteed atomicity).\\\\n\\\\n* [`SCRIPT DEBUG`](): controls use of the built-in [Redis Lua scripts debugger]().\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text='Based on the knowledge base search, here's how to use Redis Lua scripting with the EVAL command:

## Basic EVAL Syntax

The `EVAL` command takes two main arguments:

```
EVAL "script" numkeys [key ...] [arg ...]
```

- **First argument**: The Lua script source code as a string
- **Second argument**: The number of Redis key names that follow (starting from the third argument)

## Simple Example

```
> EVAL "return 'Hello, scripting!'" 0
"Hello, scripting!"
```

The `0` indicates no key arguments are provided.

## Executing Redis Commands in Scripts

Use `redis.call()` or `redis.pcall()` to execute Redis commands within your script:

```
> EVAL "return redis.call('SET', KEYS[1], ARGV[1])" 1 foo bar
OK
```

This script:
- Accepts 1 key name (`KEYS[1]` = "foo")
- Accepts 1 value argument (`ARGV[1]` = "bar")
- Executes `SET foo bar`

**Difference between `redis.call()` and `redis.pcall()`:**
- `redis.call()`: Errors are returned directly to the client
- `redis.pcall()`: Errors are returned to the script for handling

## Script Caching with EVALSHA

To avoid sending the script source repeatedly:

1. Load the script once:
```
redis> SCRIPT LOAD "return 'Immabe a cached script'"
"c664a3bf70bd1d45c4284ffebb65a6f2299bfc9f"
```

2. Execute using the SHA1 digest:
```
redis> EVALSHA c664a3bf70bd1d45c4284ffebb65a6f2299bfc9f 0
"Immabe a cached script"
```

## Key Properties

- **Atomic execution**: All server activities are blocked during script execution
- **Data locality**: Logic executes where data lives, reducing latency
- **Conditional updates**: Can perform complex operations across multiple keys and data types

## Script Flags (Redis 7.0+)

Declare script behavior using shebang:

```
#!lua flags=no-writes,allow-stale
local x = redis.call('get','x')
return x
```

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/programmability/eval-intro.md > Getting started, Script cache]')]

messages.result:
Based on the knowledge base search, here's how to use Redis Lua scripting with the EVAL command:

## Basic EVAL Syntax

The `EVAL` command takes two main arguments:

```
EVAL "script" numkeys [key ...] [arg ...]
```

- **First argument**: The Lua script source code as a string
- **Second argument**: The number of Redis key names that follow (starting from the third argument)

## Simple Example

```
> EVAL "return 'Hello, scripting!'" 0
"Hello, scripting!"
```

The `0` indicates no key arguments are provided.

## Executing Redis Commands in Scripts

Use `redis.call()` or `redis.pcall()` to execute Redis commands within your script:

```
> EVAL "return redis.call('SET', KEYS[1], ARGV[1])" 1 foo bar
OK
```

This script:
- Accepts 1 key name (`KEYS[1]` = "foo")
- Accepts 1 value argument (`ARGV[1]` = "bar")
- Executes `SET foo bar`

**Difference between `redis.call()` and `redis.pcall()`:**
- `redis.call()`: Errors are returned directly to the client
- `redis.pcall()`: Errors are returned to the script for handling

## Script Caching with EVALSHA

To avoid sending the script source repeatedly:

1. Load the script once:
```
redis> SCRIPT LOAD "return 'Immabe a cached script'"
"c664a3bf70bd1d45c4284ffebb65a6f2299bfc9f"
```

2. Execute using the SHA1 digest:
```
redis> EVALSHA c664a3bf70bd1d45c4284ffebb65a6f2299bfc9f 0
"Immabe a cached script"
```

## Key Properties

- **Atomic execution**: All server activities are blocked during script execution
- **Data locality**: Logic executes where data lives, reducing latency
- **Conditional updates**: Can perform complex operations across multiple keys and data types

## Script Flags (Redis 7.0+)

return x

query: My Redis is using too much memory, maxmemory is set but keys keep growing. How does eviction work?
answer:
Based on the Redis documentation, here's how eviction works when `maxmemory` is set:

## How Redis Eviction Works

When you set `maxmemory`, Redis **does not prevent keys from growing**. Instead, it evicts keys **reactively** when memory exceeds the limit:

1. **Trigger**: When a client runs a command that adds new data, Redis checks if memory usage exceeds `maxmemory`
2. **Eviction**: If over the limit, Redis evicts keys according to your `maxmemory-policy` until memory drops back below the limit
3. **Temporary spikes**: Commands that add lots of data (e.g., large set intersections) can temporarily exceed the limit by a large amount

## Why Keys Keep Growing

If your keys keep growing despite `maxmemory` being set, check:

- **Eviction policy**: If set to `noeviction` (default in some cases), Redis will **refuse new writes** but won't evict existing keys. You'll get errors instead.
- **Replication/persistence buffers**: Memory used for replication or AOF buffers is **not counted** toward `maxmemory`. Use `INFO memory` to check `mem_not_counted_for_evict`.

## Available Eviction Policies

Configure with `maxmemory-policy`:

**All keys:**
- `allkeys-lru`: Evict least recently used keys (good default)
- `allkeys-lrm`: Evict least recently modified keys (Redis 8.6+, preserves frequently read data)
- `allkeys-lfu`: Evict least frequently used keys
- `allkeys-random`: Random eviction

**Keys with TTL only:**
- `volatile-lru/lrm/lfu/random`: Same as above, but only for keys with expiration set
- `volatile-ttl`: Evict keys with shortest remaining TTL

**No eviction:**
- `noeviction`: Return errors on new writes (keys won't shrink)

## Recommendation

If keys are growing uncontrollably, you likely have `noeviction` set. Change to `allkeys-lru`:

```bash
CONFIG SET maxmemory-policy allkeys-lru
```

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/reference/eviction/index.md > Using the `maxmemory` configuration directive, Eviction policies]

[ToolResultBlock(tool_use_id='tooluse_riH9uhi4Uzmyq0OrfYaGOJ', content='{"result":"[\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 4.1264,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"a52aee63\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"a52aee63-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/reference/eviction/index.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Key eviction\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Using the `maxmemory` configuration directive {#maxmem}\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Redis is commonly used as a cache to speed up read accesses to a slower server\\\\nor database. Since cache entries are copies of persistently-stored data, it\\\\nis usually safe to evict them when the cache runs out of memory (they can be\\\\ncached again in the future if necessary).\\\\n\\\\nRedis lets you specify an eviction policy to evict keys automatically\\\\nwhen the size of the cache exceeds a set memory limit. Whenever a client\\\\nruns a new command that adds more data to the cache, Redis checks the memory usage.\\\\nIf it is greater than the limit, Redis evicts keys according to the chosen\\\\neviction policy until the total memory used is back below the limit.\\\\n\\\\nNote that when a command adds a lot of data to the cache (for example, a big set\\\\nintersection stored into a new key), this might temporarily exceed the limit by\\\\na large amount.\\\\n\\\\nThe sections below explain how to [configure the memory limit](#maxmem) for the cache\\\\nand also describe the available [eviction policies](#eviction-policies) and when to\\\\nuse them.\\\\n\\\\nThe `maxmemory` configuration directive specifies\\\\nthe maximum amount of memory to use for the cache data. You can\\\\nset `maxmemory` with the [`redis.conf`](https://github.com/redis/redis/blob/7.4.0/redis.conf)\\\\nfile at startup time. For example, to configure a memory limit of 100 megabytes,\\\\nyou can use the following directive inside `redis.conf`:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nmaxmemory 100mb\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nYou can also use [`CONFIG SET`]() to\\\\nset `maxmemory` at runtime using [`redis-cli`]():\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\n> CONFIG SET maxmemory 100mb\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nSet `maxmemory` to zero to specify that you don\'t want to limit the memory\\\\nfor the dataset. This is the default behavior for 64-bit systems, while 32-bit\\\\nsystems use an implicit memory limit of 3GB.\\\\n\\\\nWhen the size of your cache exceeds the limit set by `maxmemory`, Redis will\\\\nenforce your chosen [eviction policy](#eviction-policies) to prevent any\\\\nfurther growth of the cache.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 2.5331,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"a52aee63\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"a52aee63-002\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/reference/eviction/index.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Key eviction\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Eviction policies\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Use the `maxmemory-policy` configuration directive to select the eviction\\\\npolicy you want to use when the limit set by `maxmemory` is reached.\\\\n\\\\nThe following policies are available:\\\\n\\\\n-   `noeviction`: Keys are not evicted but the server will return an error\\\\n    when you try to execute commands that cache new data. If your database uses replication\\\\n    then this condition only applies to the primary database. Note that commands that only\\\\n    read existing data still work as normal.\\\\n-   `allkeys-lru`: Evict the [least recently used](#apx-lru) (LRU) keys.\\\\n-   `allkeys-lrm`: Evict the [least recently modified](#lrm-eviction) (LRM) keys.\\\\n-   `allkeys-lfu`: Evict the [least frequently used](#lfu-eviction) (LFU) keys.\\\\n-   `allkeys-random`: Evict keys at random.\\\\n-   `volatile-lru`: Evict the least recently used keys that have an associated expiration (TTL).\\\\n-   `volatile-lrm`: Evict the least recently modified keys that have an associated expiration (TTL).\\\\n-   `volatile-lfu`: Evict the least frequently used keys that have an associated expiration (TTL).\\\\n-   `volatile-random`: Evicts random keys that have an associated expiration (TTL).\\\\n-   `volatile-ttl`: Evict keys with an associated expiration (TTL) that have the shortest remaining TTL value.\\\\n\\\\nThe `volatile-xxx` policies behave like `noeviction` if no keys have an associated expiration.\\\\n\\\\nYou should choose an eviction policy that fits the way your app\\\\naccesses keys. You may be able to predict the access pattern in advance\\\\nbut you can also use information from the `INFO` command at runtime to\\\\ncheck or improve your choice of policy (see\\\\n[Using the `INFO` command](#using-the-info-command) below for more information).\\\\n\\\\nAs a rule of thumb:\\\\n\\\\n-   Use `allkeys-lru` when you expect that a subset of elements will be accessed far\\\\n    more often than the rest. This is a very common case according to the\\\\n    [Pareto principle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pareto_principle), so\\\\n    `allkeys-lru` is a good default option if you have no reason to prefer any others.\\\\n-   Use `allkeys-lrm` when you want to preserve frequently read data but evict data\\\\n    that hasn\'t been modified recently. This is useful for read-heavy workloads where\\\\n    you want to distinguish between data that\'s actively being updated versus data\\\\n    that\'s only being read.\\\\n-   Use `allkeys-random` when you expect all keys to be accessed with roughly equal\\\\n    frequency. An example of this is when your app reads data items in a repeating cycle.\\\\n-   Use `volatile-ttl` if your code can estimate which keys are good candidates for eviction\\\\n    and assign short TTLs to them. Note also that if you make good use of\\\\n    key expiration, then you are less likely to run into the cache memory limit because keys\\\\n    will often expire before they need to be evicted.\\\\n\\\\nThe `volatile-lru`, `volatile-lrm`, and `volatile-random` policies are mainly useful when you want to use\\\\na single Redis instance for both caching and for a set of persistent keys. However,\\\\nyou should consider running two separate Redis instances in a case like this, if possible.\\\\n\\\\nAlso note that setting an `expire` value for a key costs memory, so a\\\\npolicy like `allkeys-lru` is more memory efficient since it doesn\'t need an\\\\n`expire` value to operate.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 2.283,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"a52aee63\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"a52aee63-006\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/reference/eviction/index.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Key eviction\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"LRM eviction {#lrm-eviction}\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Starting with Redis 8.6, the Least Recently Modified (LRM) eviction policy is available. LRM is similar to LRU but only updates the timestamp on write operations, not read operations. This makes it useful for evicting keys that haven\'t been modified recently, regardless of how frequently they are read.\\\\n\\\\nThe key difference between LRU and LRM is:\\\\n\\\\n- **LRU (Least Recently Used)**: Updates the access timestamp on both read and write operations\\\\n- **LRM (Least Recently Modified)**: Updates the access timestamp only on write operations\\\\n\\\\nThis distinction makes LRM particularly useful in scenarios where:\\\\n\\\\n- Your application has a clear distinction between read-heavy and write-heavy workloads\\\\n- You want to evict stale data that hasn\'t been updated, regardless of read activity\\\\n\\\\nTo configure LRM eviction, the following policies are available:\\\\n\\\\n* `volatile-lrm` Evict using LRM among the keys with an an associated expiration (TTL).\\\\n* `allkeys-lrm` Evict any key using LRM.\\\\n\\\\nLike LRU, LRM uses an approximation algorithm that samples a small number of keys at random and evicts the ones with the longest time since last modification. The same `maxmemory-samples` configuration directive that affects LRU performance also applies to LRM.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.5629,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"a52aee63\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"a52aee63-001\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/reference/eviction/index.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Key eviction\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Using the `maxmemory` configuration directive {#maxmem} > Setting `maxmemory` for a replicated or persisted instance\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"If you are using\\\\n[replication]()\\\\nor [persistence]()\\\\nfor a server, Redis will use some RAM as a buffer to store the set of updates waiting\\\\nto be written to the replicas or AOF files.\\\\nThe memory used by this buffer is not included in the total that\\\\nis compared to `maxmemory` to see if eviction is required.\\\\n\\\\nThis is because the key evictions themselves generate updates that must be added\\\\nto the buffer. If the updates were counted among the used\\\\nmemory then in some circumstances, the memory saved by\\\\nevicting keys would be immediately used up by the update data added to the buffer.\\\\nThis, in turn, would trigger even more evictions and the resulting feedback loop\\\\ncould evict many items from the cache unnecessarily.\\\\n\\\\nIf you are using replication or persistence, we recommend that you set\\\\n`maxmemory` to leave a little RAM free to store the buffers. Note that this is not\\\\nnecessary for the `noeviction` policy (see [the section below](#eviction-policies)\\\\nfor more information about eviction policies).\\\\n\\\\nThe [`INFO`]() command returns a\\\\n`mem_not_counted_for_evict` value in the `memory` section (you can use\\\\nthe `INFO memory` option to see just this section). This is the amount of\\\\nmemory currently used by the buffers. Although the exact amount will vary,\\\\nyou can use it to estimate how much to subtract from the total available RAM\\\\nbefore setting `maxmemory`.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.4435,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"a52aee63\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"a52aee63-004\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/reference/eviction/index.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Key eviction\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Approximated LRU algorithm {#apx-lru}\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"The Redis LRU algorithm uses an approximation of the least recently used\\\\nkeys rather than calculating them exactly. It samples a small number of keys\\\\nat random and then evicts the ones with the longest time since last access.\\\\n\\\\nFrom Redis 3.0 onwards, the algorithm also tracks a pool of good\\\\ncandidates for eviction. This improves the performance of the algorithm, making\\\\nit a close approximation to a true LRU algorithm.\\\\n\\\\n(Redis Open Source only) You can tune the performance of the algorithm by changing the number of samples to check\\\\nbefore every eviction with the `maxmemory-samples` configuration directive:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nmaxmemory-samples 5\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nSee these pages for information on eviction policies in: (1) [Redis Software]() and (2) [Redis Cloud]().\\\\n\\\\nThe reason Redis does not use a true LRU implementation is because it\\\\ncosts more memory. However, the approximation is virtually equivalent for an\\\\napplication using Redis. This figure compares\\\\nthe LRU approximation used by Redis with true LRU.\\\\n\\\\n![LRU comparison](lru_comparison.png)\\\\n\\\\nThe test to generate the above graphs filled a Redis server with a given number of keys. The keys were accessed from the first to the last. The first keys are the best candidates for eviction using an LRU algorithm. Later more 50% of keys are added, in order to force half of the old keys to be evicted.\\\\n\\\\nYou can see three kind of dots in the graphs, forming three distinct bands.\\\\n\\\\n* The light gray band are objects that were evicted.\\\\n* The gray band are objects that were not evicted.\\\\n* The green band are objects that were added.\\\\n\\\\nIn a theoretical LRU implementation we expect that, among the old keys, the first half will be expired. The Redis LRU algorithm will instead only *probabilistically* expire the older keys.\\\\n\\\\nAs you can see Redis 3.0 does a better job with 5 samples compared to Redis 2.8, however most objects that are among the latest accessed are still retained by Redis 2.8. Using a sample size of 10 in Redis 3.0 the approximation is very close to the theoretical performance of Redis 3.0.\\\\n\\\\nNote that LRU is just a model to predict how likely a given key will be accessed in the future. Moreover, if your data access pattern closely\\\\nresembles the power law, most of the accesses will be in the set of keys\\\\nthe LRU approximated algorithm can handle well.\\\\n\\\\nIn simulations we found that using a power law access pattern, the difference between true LRU and Redis approximation were minimal or non-existent.\\\\n\\\\nHowever you can raise the sample size to 10 at the cost of some additional CPU\\\\nusage to closely approximate true LRU, and check if this makes a\\\\ndifference in your cache misses rate.\\\\n\\\\nTo experiment in production with different values for the sample size by using\\\\nthe `CONFIG SET maxmemory-samples <count>` command, is very simple.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

query: Redis Sentinel 一直报 failover-abort-no-good-slave，怎么排查？
answer:
找到了！在 Redis Sentinel 文档的第 766 行有关于 `no-good-slave` 事件的说明。让我提取关键信息：

## `failover-abort-no-good-slave` 排查方法

根据 Redis Sentinel 官方文档，这个错误表示 **没有合适的 replica 可以提升为 master**。

### 原因分析

Sentinel 在选择 replica 时会评估以下条件（按优先级排序）：

1. **与 master 的断连时间**
   - replica 与 master 断连时间超过 `(down-after-milliseconds * 10) + master 进入 SDOWN 状态的时长` 会被认为不可靠，直接跳过
   
2. **replica-priority（副本优先级）**
   - 优先级为 0 的 replica **永远不会被提升为 master**
   - 数值越小优先级越高

3. **复制偏移量（replication offset）**
   - 接收到更多 master 数据的 replica 优先

4. **Run ID**
   - 字典序更小的 Run ID 优先（用于确定性选择）

### 排查步骤

1. **检查所有 replica 的状态**
   ```bash
   redis-cli -p 26379 SENTINEL replicas mymaster
   ```
   查看每个 replica 的：
   - `flags`（是否包含 `s_down`）
   - `master-link-down-time`（与 master 断连时长）
   - `replica-priority`（是否为 0）

2. **检查 replica-priority 配置**
   ```bash
   redis-cli -p 6380 CONFIG GET replica-priority
   ```
   如果所有 replica 的 `replica-priority` 都设置为 0，failover 会失败

3. **检查复制延迟**
   ```bash
   redis-cli -p 6380 INFO replication
   ```
   查看 `master_link_status` 和 `master_last_io_seconds_ago`

4. **检查 Sentinel 配置**
   ```bash
   redis-cli -p 26379 SENTINEL master mymaster
   ```
   确认 `down-after-milliseconds` 设置是否合理（默认 60000ms）

### 常见原因

- 所有 replica 的 `replica-priority` 都设置为 0
- 所有 replica 与 master 断连时间过长（超过阈值）
- 所有 replica 都处于 SDOWN 状态
- 网络分区导致 Sentinel 无法连接到任何 replica

### 解决方案

1. 至少保留一个 replica 的 `replica-priority > 0`
2. 缩短 `down-after-milliseconds` 或修复 replica 与 master 的连接
3. 检查网络连通性，确保 Sentinel 能访问 replica
4. 查看 Sentinel 日志中的 `+sdown` 事件，确认哪些 replica 被标记为下线

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/sentinel.md > Pub/Sub messages (line 766) + Replica selection and priority (lines 1000-1043)]

Since Sentinel is both responsible\\\\nfor reconfiguring instances during failovers, and providing configurations to\\\\nclients connecting to Redis masters or replicas, clients are required to have\\\\nexplicit support for Redis Sentinel.\\\\n\\\\nThis document is targeted at Redis clients developers that want to support Sentinel in their clients implementation with the following goals:\\\\n\\\\n* Automatic configuration of clients via Sentinel.\\\\n* Improved safety of Redis Sentinel automatic failover.\\\\n\\\\nFor details about how Redis Sentinel works, please check the [Redis Documentation](), as this document only contains information needed for Redis client developers, and it is expected that readers are familiar with the way Redis Sentinel works.\\\\n\\\\nRedis Sentinel identifies every master with a name like \\\\\\"stats\\\\\\" or \\\\\\"cache\\\\\\".\\\\nEvery name actually identifies a *group of instances*, composed of a master\\\\nand a variable number of replicas.\\\\n\\\\nThe address of the Redis master that is used for a specific purpose inside a network may change after events like an automatic failover, a manually triggered failover (for instance in order to upgrade a Redis instance), and other reasons.\\\\n\\\\nNormally Redis clients have some kind of hard-coded configuration that specifies the address of a Redis master instance within a network as IP address and port number. However if the master address changes, manual intervention in every client is needed.\\\\n\\\\nA Redis client supporting Sentinel can automatically discover the address of a Redis master from the master name using Redis Sentinel. So instead of a hard coded IP address and port, a client supporting Sentinel should optionally be able to take as input:\\\\n\\\\n* A list of ip:port pairs pointing to known Sentinel instances.\\\\n* The name of the service, like \\\\\\"cache\\\\\\" or \\\\\\"timelines\\\\\\".\\\\n\\\\nThis is the procedure a client should follow in order to obtain the master address starting from the list of Sentinels and the service name.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -0.2839,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"a2f680a5\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"a2f680a5-002\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/sentinel.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"High availability with Redis Sentinel\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Sentinel quick start > Configuring Sentinel\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"The Redis source distribution contains a file called `sentinel.conf`\\\\nthat is a self-documented example configuration file you can use to\\\\nconfigure Sentinel, however a typical minimal configuration file looks like the\\\\nfollowing:\\\\n\\\\n    sentinel monitor mymaster 127.0.0.1 6379 2\\\\n    sentinel down-after-milliseconds mymaster 60000\\\\n    sentinel failover-timeout mymaster 180000\\\\n    sentinel parallel-syncs mymaster 1\\\\n\\\\n    sentinel monitor resque 192.168.1.3 6380 4\\\\n    sentinel down-after-milliseconds resque 10000\\\\n    sentinel failover-timeout resque 180000\\\\n    sentinel parallel-syncs resque 5\\\\n\\\\nYou only need to specify the masters to monitor, giving to each separated\\\\nmaster (that may have any number of replicas) a different name. There is no\\\\nneed to specify replicas, which are auto-discovered. Sentinel will update the\\\\nconfiguration automatically with additional information about replicas (in\\\\norder to retain the information in case of restart). The configuration is\\\\nalso rewritten every time a replica is promoted to master during a failover\\\\nand every time a new Sentinel is discovered.\\\\n\\\\nThe example configuration above basically monitors two sets of Redis\\\\ninstances, each composed of a master and an undefined number of replicas.\\\\nOne set of instances is called `mymaster`, and the other `resque`.\\\\n\\\\nThe meaning of the arguments of `sentinel monitor` statements is the following:\\\\n\\\\n    sentinel monitor <master-name> <ip> <port> <quorum>\\\\n\\\\nFor the sake of clarity, let\'s check line by line what the configuration\\\\noptions mean:\\\\n\\\\nThe first line is used to tell Redis to monitor a master called *mymaster*,\\\\nthat is at address 127.0.0.1 and port 6379, with a quorum of 2. Everything\\\\nis pretty obvious but the **quorum** argument:\\\\n\\\\n* The **quorum** is the number of Sentinels that need to agree about the fact the master is not reachable, in order to really mark the master as failing, and eventually start a failover procedure if possible.\\\\n* However **the quorum is only used to detect the failure**. In order to actually perform a failover, one of the Sentinels need to be elected leader for the failover and be authorized to proceed. This only happens with the vote of the **majority of the Sentinel processes**.\\\\n\\\\nSo for example if you have 5 Sentinel processes, and the quorum for a given\\\\nmaster set to the value of 2, this is what happens:\\\\n\\\\n* If two Sentinels agree at the same time about the master being unreachable, one of the two will try to start a failover.\\\\n* If there are at least a total of three Sentinels reachable, the failover will be authorized and will actually start.\\\\n\\\\nIn practical terms this means during failures **Sentinel never starts a failover if the majority of Sentinel processes are unable to talk** (aka no failover in the minority partition).\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -0.5152,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"redis-failover-001\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"redis-failover-001-003\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"docs/runbook/redis-failover.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis 主从切换故障恢复手册\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis 主从切换故障恢复手册 > 相关文档\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"high\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"- 所有应用必须使用 Sentinel 客户端，禁止直连 master IP\\\\n- 连接池配置 `minEvictableIdleTimeMillis=60000`\\\\n- 定期演练 failover：`redis-cli -p 26379 SENTINEL failover mymaster`\\\\n\\\\n- Redis Sentinel 架构设计\\\\n- 应用连接池配置规范\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

     2→categories:

     8→description: High availability for non-clustered Redis
     9→id: a2f680a5
    10→ingested_at: '2026-02-14T15:01:27Z'
    11→linkTitle: High availability with Sentinel
    12→source_commit: a9ff1a3
    13→source_path: content/operate/oss_and_stack/management/sentinel.md
    14→source_repo: https://github.com/redis/docs
    15→title: High availability with Redis Sentinel
    16→weight: 4
    17→---
    18→
    19→Redis Sentinel provides high availability for Redis when not using [Redis Cluster]({{< relref "/operate/oss_and_stack/management/scaling" >}}). 
    20→
    21→Redis Sentinel also provides other collateral tasks such as monitoring,
    22→notifications and acts as a configuration provider for clients.
    23→
    24→This is the full list of Sentinel capabilities at a macroscopic level (i.e. the *big picture*):
    25→
    26→* **Monitoring**. Sentinel constantly checks if your master and replica instances are working as expected.
    27→* **Notification**. Sentinel can notify the system administrator, or other computer programs, via an API, that something is wrong with one of the monitored Redis instances.
    28→* **Automatic failover**. If a master is not working as expected, Sentinel can start a failover process where a replica is promoted to master, the other additional replicas are reconfigured to use the new master, and the applications using the Redis server are informed about the new address to use when connecting.
    29→* **Configuration provider**. Sentinel acts as a source of authority for clients service discovery: clients connect to Sentinels in order to ask for the address of the current Redis master responsible for a given service. If a failover occurs, Sentinels will report the new address.
    30→
    31→## Sentinel as a distributed system
    32→
    33→Redis Sentinel is a distributed system:
    34→
    35→Sentinel itself is designed to run in a configuration where there are multiple Sentinel processes cooperating together. The advantage of having multiple Sentinel processes cooperating are the following:
    36→
    37→1. Failure detection is performed when multiple Sentinels agree about the fact a given master is no longer available. This lowers the probability of false positives.
    38→2. Sentinel works even if not all the Sentinel processes are working, making the system robust against failures. There is no fun in having a failover system which is itself a single point of failure, after all.
    39→
    40→The sum of Sentinels, Redis instances (masters and replicas) and clients
    41→connecting to Sentinel and Redis, are also a larger distributed system with
    42→specific properties. In this document concepts will be introduced gradually
    43→starting from basic information needed in order to understand the basic
    44→properties of Sentinel, to more complex information (that are optional) in
    45→order to understand how exactly Sentinel works.
    46→
    47→## Sentinel quick start
    48→
    49→### Obtaining Sentinel
    50→
    51→The current version of Sentinel is called **Sentinel 2**. It is a rewrite of
    52→the initial Sentinel implementation using stronger and simpler-to-predict
    53→algorithms (that are explained in this documentation).
    54→
    55→A stable release of Redis Sentinel is shipped since Redis 2.8.
    56→
    57→New developments are performed in the *unstable* branch, and new features
    58→sometimes are back ported into the latest stable branch as soon as they are
    59→considered to be stable.
    60→
    61→Redis Sentinel version 1, shipped with Redis 2.6, is deprecated and should not be used.
    62→
    63→### Running Sentinel
    64→
    65→If you are using the `redis-sentinel` executable (or if you have a symbolic
    66→link with that name to the `redis-server` executable) you can run Sentinel
    67→with the following command line:
    68→
    69→    redis-sentinel /path/to/sentinel.conf
    70→
    71→Otherwise you can use directly the `redis-server` executable starting it in
    72→Sentinel mode:
    73→
    74→    redis-server /path/to/sentinel.conf --sentinel
    75→
    76→Both ways work the same.
    77→
    78→However **it is mandatory** to use a configuration file when running Sentinel, as this file will be used by the system in order to save the current state that will be reloaded in case of restarts. Sentinel will simply refuse to start if no configuration file is given or if the configuration file path is not writable.
    79→
    80→Sentinels by default run **listening for connections to TCP port 26379**, so
    81→for Sentinels to work, port 26379 of your servers **must be open** to receive
    82→connections from the IP addresses of the other Sentinel instances.
    83→Otherwise Sentinels can't talk and can't agree about what to do, so failover
    84→will never be performed.
    85→
    86→### Fundamental things to know about Sentinel before deploying
    87→
    88→1. You need at least three Sentinel instances for a robust deployment.
    89→2. The three Sentinel instances should be placed into computers or virtual machines that are believed to fail in an independent way. So for example different physical servers or Virtual Machines executed on different availability zones.
    90→3. Sentinel + Redis distributed system does not guarantee that acknowledged writes are retained during failures, since Redis uses asynchronous replication. However there are ways to deploy Sentinel that make the window to lose writes limited to certain moments, while there are other less secure ways to deploy it.
    91→4. You need Sentinel support in your clients. Popular client libraries have Sentinel support, but not all.
    92→5. There is no HA setup which is safe if you don't test from time to time in development environments, or even better if you can, in production environments, if they work. You may have a misconfiguration that will become apparent only when it's too late (at 3am when your master stops working).
    93→6. **Sentinel, Docker, or other forms of Network Address Translation or Port Mapping should be mixed with care**: Docker performs port remapping, breaking Sentinel auto discovery of other Sentinel processes and the list of replicas for a master. Check the [section about _Sentinel and Docker_](#sentinel-docker-nat-and-possible-issues) later in this document for more information.
    94→
    95→### Configuring Sentinel
    96→
    97→The Redis source distribution contains a file called `sentinel.conf`
    98→that is a self-documented example configuration file you can use to
    99→configure Sentinel, however a typical minimal configuration file looks like the
   100→following:
   101→
   102→    sentinel monitor mymaster 127.0.0.1 6379 2
   103→    sentinel down-after-milliseconds mymaster 60000
   104→    sentinel failover-timeout mymaster 180000
   105→    sentinel parallel-syncs mymaster 1
   106→
   107→    sentinel monitor resque 192.168.1.3 6380 4
   108→    sentinel down-after-milliseconds resque 10000
   109→    sentinel failover-timeout resque 180000
   110→    sentinel parallel-syncs resque 5
   111→
   112→You only need to specify the masters to monitor, giving to each separated
   113→master (that may have any number of replicas) a different name. There is no
   114→need to specify replicas, which are auto-discovered. Sentinel will update the
   115→configuration automatically with additional information about replicas (in
   116→order to retain the information in case of restart). The configuration is
   117→also rewritten every time a replica is promoted to master during a failover
   118→and every time a new Sentinel is discovered.
   119→
   120→The example configuration above basically monitors two sets of Redis
   121→instances, each composed of a master and an undefined number of replicas.
   122→One set of instances is called `mymaster`, and the other `resque`.
   123→
   124→The meaning of the arguments of `sentinel monitor` statements is the following:
   125→
   126→    sentinel monitor <master-name> <ip> <port> <quorum>
   127→
   128→For the sake of clarity, let's check line by line what the configuration
   129→options mean:
   130→
   131→The first line is used to tell Redis to monitor a master called *mymaster*,
   132→that is at address 127.0.0.1 and port 6379, with a quorum of 2. Everything
   133→is pretty obvious but the **quorum** argument:
   134→
   135→* The **quorum** is the number of Sentinels that need to agree about the fact the master is not reachable, in order to really mark the master as failing, and eventually start a failover procedure if possible.
   136→* However **the quorum is only used to detect the failure**. In order to actually perform a failover, one of the Sentinels need to be elected leader for the failover and be authorized to proceed. This only happens with the vote of the **majority of the Sentinel processes**.
   137→
   138→So for example if you have 5 Sentinel processes, and the quorum for a given
   139→master set to the value of 2, this is what happens:
   140→
   141→* If two Sentinels agree at the same time about the master being unreachable, one of the two will try to start a failover.
   142→* If there are at least a total of three Sentinels reachable, the failover will be authorized and will actually start.
   143→
   144→In practical terms this means during failures **Sentinel never starts a failover if the majority of Sentinel processes are unable to talk** (aka no failover in the minority partition).
   145→
   146→### Other Sentinel options
   147→
   148→The other options are almost always in the form:
   149→
   150→    sentinel <option_name> <master_name> <option_value>
   151→
   152→And are used for the following purposes:
   153→
   154→* `down-after-milliseconds` is the time in milliseconds an instance should not
   155→be reachable (either does not reply to our PINGs or it is replying with an
   156→error) for a Sentinel starting to think it is down.
   157→* `parallel-syncs` sets the number of replicas that can be reconfigured to use
   158→the new master after a failover at the same time. The lower the number, the
   159→more time it will take for the failover process to complete, however if the
   160→replicas are configured to serve old data, you may not want all the replicas to
   161→re-synchronize with the master at the same time. While the replication
   162→process is mostly non blocking for a replica, there is a moment when it stops to
   163→load the bulk data from the master. You may want to make sure only one replica
   164→at a time is not reachable by setting this option to the value of 1.
   165→
   166→Additional options are described in the rest of this document and
   167→documented in the example `sentinel.conf` file shipped with the Redis
   168→distribution.
   169→
   170→Configuration parameters can be modified at runtime:
   171→
   172→* Master-specific configuration parameters are modified using `SENTINEL SET`.
   173→* Global configuration parameters are modified using `SENTINEL CONFIG SET`.
   174→
   175→See the [_Reconfiguring Sentinel at runtime_ section](#reconfiguring-sentinel-at-runtime) for more information.
   176→
   177→### Example Sentinel deployments
   178→
   179→Now that you know the basic information about Sentinel, you may wonder where
   180→you should place your Sentinel processes, how many Sentinel processes you need
   181→and so forth. This section shows a few example deployments.
   182→
   183→We use ASCII art in order to show you configuration examples in a *graphical*
   184→format, this is what the different symbols means:
   185→
   186→    +--------------------+
   187→    | This is a computer |
   188→    | or VM that fails   |
   189→    | independently. We  |
   190→    | call it a "box"    |
   191→    +--------------------+
   192→
   193→We write inside the boxes what they are running:
   194→
   195→    +-------------------+
   196→    | Redis master M1   |
   197→    | Redis Sentinel S1 |
   198→    +-------------------+
   199→
   200→Different boxes are connected by lines, to show that they are able to talk:
   201→
   202→    +-------------+               +-------------+
   203→    | Sentinel S1 |---------------| Sentinel S2 |
   204→    +-------------+               +-------------+
   205→
   206→Network partitions are shown as interrupted lines using slashes:
   207→
   208→    +-------------+                +-------------+
   209→    | Sentinel S1 |------ // ------| Sentinel S2 |
   210→    +-------------+                +-------------+
   211→
   212→Also note that:
   213→
   214→* Masters are called M1, M2, M3, ..., Mn.
   215→* Replicas are called R1, R2, R3, ..., Rn (R stands for *replica*).
   216→* Sentinels are called S1, S2, S3, ..., Sn.
   217→* Clients are called C1, C2, C3, ..., Cn.
   218→* When an instance changes role because of Sentinel actions, we put it inside square brackets, so [M1] means an instance that is now a master because of Sentinel intervention.
   219→
   220→Note that we will never show **setups where just two Sentinels are used**, since
   221→Sentinels always need **to talk with the majority** in order to start a
   222→failover.
   223→
   224→#### Example 1: just two Sentinels, DON'T DO THIS
   225→
   226→    +----+         +----+
   227→    | M1 |---------| R1 |
   228→    | S1 |         | S2 |
   229→    +----+         +----+
   230→
   231→    Configuration: quorum = 1
   232→
   233→* In this setup, if the master M1 fails, R1 will be promoted since the two Sentinels can reach agreement about the failure (obviously with quorum set to 1) and can also authorize a failover because the majority is two. So apparently it could superficially work, however check the next points to see why this setup is broken.
   234→* If the box where M1 is running stops working, also S1 stops working. The Sentinel running in the other box S2 will not be able to authorize a failover, so the system will become not available.
   235→
   236→Note that a majority is needed in order to order different failovers, and later propagate the latest configuration to all the Sentinels. Also note that the ability to failover in a single side of the above setup, without any agreement, would be very dangerous:
   237→
   238→    +----+           +------+
   239→    | M1 |----//-----| [M1] |
   240→    | S1 |           | S2   |
   241→    +----+           +------+
   242→
   243→In the above configuration we created two masters (assuming S2 could failover
   244→without authorization) in a perfectly symmetrical way. Clients may write
   245→indefinitely to both sides, and there is no way to understand when the
   246→partition heals what configuration is the right one, in order to prevent
   247→a *permanent split brain condition*.
   248→
   249→So please **deploy at least three Sentinels in three different boxes** always.
   250→
   251→#### Example 2: basic setup with three boxes
   252→
   253→This is a very simple setup, that has the advantage to be simple to tune
   254→for additional safety. It is based on three boxes, each box running both
   255→a Redis process and a Sentinel process.
   256→
   257→
   258→           +----+
   259→           | M1 |
   260→           | S1 |
   261→           +----+
   262→              |
   263→    +----+    |    +----+
   264→    | R2 |----+----| R3 |
   265→    | S2 |         | S3 |
   266→    +----+         +----+
   267→
   268→    Configuration: quorum = 2
   269→
   270→If the master M1 fails, S2 and S3 will agree about the failure and will
   271→be able to authorize a failover, making clients able to continue.
   272→
   273→In every Sentinel setup, as Redis uses asynchronous replication, there is
   274→always the risk of losing some writes because a given acknowledged write
   275→may not be able to reach the replica which is promoted to master. However in
   276→the above setup there is a higher risk due to clients being partitioned away
   277→with an old master, like in the following picture:
   278→
   279→             +----+
   280→             | M1 |
   281→             | S1 | <- C1 (writes will be lost)
   282→             +----+
   283→                |
   284→                /
   285→                /
   286→    +------+    |    +----+
   287→    | [M2] |----+----| R3 |
   288→    | S2   |         | S3 |
   289→    +------+         +----+
   290→
   291→In this case a network partition isolated the old master M1, so the
   292→replica R2 is promoted to master. However clients, like C1, that are
   293→in the same partition as the old master, may continue to write data
   294→to the old master. This data will be lost forever since when the partition
   295→will heal, the master will be reconfigured as a replica of the new master,
   296→discarding its data set.
   297→
   298→This problem can be mitigated using the following Redis replication
   299→feature, that allows to stop accepting writes if a master detects that
   300→it is no longer able to transfer its writes to the specified number of replicas.
   301→
   302→    min-replicas-to-write 1
   303→    min-replicas-max-lag 10
   304→
   305→With the above configuration (please see the self-commented `redis.conf` example in the Redis distribution for more information) a Redis instance, when acting as a master, will stop accepting writes if it can't write to at least 1 replica. Since replication is asynchronous *not being able to write* actually means that the replica is either disconnected, or is not sending us asynchronous acknowledges for more than the specified `max-lag` number of seconds.
   306→
   307→Using this configuration, the old Redis master M1 in the above example, will become unavailable after 10 seconds. When the partition heals, the Sentinel configuration will converge to the new one, the client C1 will be able to fetch a valid configuration and will continue with the new master.
   308→
   309→However there is no free lunch. With this refinement, if the two replicas are
   310→down, the master will stop accepting writes. It's a trade off.
   311→
   312→#### Example 3: Sentinel in the client boxes
   313→
   314→Sometimes we have only two Redis boxes available, one for the master and
   315→one for the replica. The configuration in the example 2 is not viable in
   316→that case, so we can resort to the following, where Sentinels are placed
   317→where clients are:
   318→
   319→                +----+         +----+
   320→                | M1 |----+----| R1 |
   321→                |    |    |    |    |
   322→                +----+    |    +----+
   323→                          |
   324→             +------------+------------+
   325→             |            |            |
   326→             |            |            |
   327→          +----+        +----+      +----+
   328→          | C1 |        | C2 |      | C3 |
   329→          | S1 |        | S2 |      | S3 |
   330→          +----+        +----+      +----+
   331→
   332→          Configuration: quorum = 2
   333→
   334→In this setup, the point of view Sentinels is the same as the clients: if
   335→a master is reachable by the majority of the clients, it is fine.
   336→C1, C2, C3 here are generic clients, it does not mean that C1 identifies
   337→a single client connected to Redis. It is more likely something like
   338→an application server, a Rails app, or something like that.
   339→
   340→If the box where M1 and S1 are running fails, the failover will happen
   341→without issues, however it is easy to see that different network partitions
   342→will result in different behaviors. For example Sentinel will not be able
   343→to setup if the network between the clients and the Redis servers is
   344→disconnected, since the Redis master and replica will both be unavailable.
   345→
   346→Note that if C3 gets partitioned with M1 (hardly possible with
   347→the network described above, but more likely possible with different
   348→layouts, or because of failures at the software layer), we have a similar
   349→issue as described in Example 2, with the difference that here we have
   350→no way to break the symmetry, since there is just a replica and master, so
   351→the master can't stop accepting queries when it is disconnected from its replica,
   352→otherwise the master would never be available during replica failures.
   353→
   354→So this is a valid setup but the setup in the Example 2 has advantages
   355→such as the HA system of Redis running in the same boxes as Redis itself
   356→which may be simpler to manage, and the ability to put a bound on the amount
   357→of time a master in the minority partition can receive writes.
   358→
   359→#### Example 4: Sentinel client side with less than three clients
   360→
   361→The setup described in the Example 3 cannot be used if there are less than
   362→three boxes in the client side (for example three web servers). In this
   363→case we need to resort to a mixed setup like the following:
   364→
   365→                +----+         +----+
   366→                | M1 |----+----| R1 |
   367→                | S1 |    |    | S2 |
   368→                +----+    |    +----+
   369→                          |
   370→                   +------+-----+
   371→                   |            |
   372→                   |            |
   373→                +----+        +----+
   374→                | C1 |        | C2 |
   375→                | S3 |        | S4 |
   376→                +----+        +----+
   377→
   378→          Configuration: quorum = 3
   379→
   380→This is similar to the setup in Example 3, but here we run four Sentinels
   381→in the four boxes we have available. If the master M1 becomes unavailable
   382→the other three Sentinels will perform the failover.
   383→
   384→In theory this setup works removing the box where C2 and S4 are running, and
   385→setting the quorum to 2. However it is unlikely that we want HA in the
   386→Redis side without having high availability in our application layer.
   387→
   388→### Sentinel, Docker, NAT, and possible issues
   389→
   390→Docker uses a technique called port mapping: programs running inside Docker
   391→containers may be exposed with a different port compared to the one the
   392→program believes to be using. This is useful in order to run multiple
   393→containers using the same ports, at the same time, in the same server.
   394→
   395→Docker is not the only software system where this happens, there are other
   396→Network Address Translation setups where ports may be remapped, and sometimes
   397→not ports but also IP addresses.
   398→
   399→Remapping ports and addresses creates issues with Sentinel in two ways:
   400→
   401→1. Sentinel auto-discovery of other Sentinels no longer works, since it is based on *hello* messages where each Sentinel announce at which port and IP address they are listening for connection. However Sentinels have no way to understand that an address or port is remapped, so it is announcing an information that is not correct for other Sentinels to connect.
   402→2. Replicas are listed in the [`INFO`](/commands/info) output of a Redis master in a similar way: the address is detected by the master checking the remote peer of the TCP connection, while the port is advertised by the replica itself during the handshake, however the port may be wrong for the same reason as exposed in point 1.
   403→
   404→Since Sentinels auto detect replicas using masters [`INFO`](/commands/info) output information,
   405→the detected replicas will not be reachable, and Sentinel will never be able to
   406→failover the master, since there are no good replicas from the point of view of
   407→the system, so there is currently no way to monitor with Sentinel a set of
   408→master and replica instances deployed with Docker, **unless you instruct Docker
   409→to map the port 1:1**.
   410→
   411→For the first problem, in case you want to run a set of Sentinel
   412→instances using Docker with forwarded ports (or any other NAT setup where ports
   413→are remapped), you can use the following two Sentinel configuration directives
   414→in order to force Sentinel to announce a specific set of IP and port:
   415→
   416→    sentinel announce-ip <ip>
   417→    sentinel announce-port <port>
   418→
   419→Note that Docker has the ability to run in *host networking mode* (check the `--net=host` option for more information). This should create no issues since ports are not remapped in this setup.
   420→
   421→### IP Addresses and DNS names
   422→
   423→Older versions of Sentinel did not support host names and required IP addresses to be specified everywhere.
   424→Starting with version 6.2, Sentinel has *optional* support for host names.
   425→
   426→**This capability is disabled by default. If you're going to enable DNS/hostnames support, please note:**
   427→
   428→1. The name resolution configuration on your Redis and Sentinel nodes must be reliable and be able to resolve addresses quickly. Unexpected delays in address resolution may have a negative impact on Sentinel.
   429→2. You should use hostnames everywhere and avoid mixing hostnames and IP addresses. To do that, use `replica-announce-ip <hostname>` and `sentinel announce-ip <hostname>` for all Redis and Sentinel instances, respectively.
   430→
   431→Enabling the `resolve-hostnames` global configuration allows Sentinel to accept host names:
   432→
   433→* As part of a `sentinel monitor` command
   434→* As a replica address, if the replica uses a host name value for `replica-announce-ip`
   435→
   436→Sentinel will accept host names as valid inputs and resolve them, but will still refer to IP addresses when announcing an instance, updating configuration files, etc.
   437→
   438→Enabling the `announce-hostnames` global configuration makes Sentinel use host names instead. This affects replies to clients, values written in configuration files, the [`REPLICAOF`](/commands/replicaof) command issued to replicas, etc.
   439→
   440→This behavior may not be compatible with all Sentinel clients, that may explicitly expect an IP address.
   441→
   442→Using host names may be useful when clients use TLS to connect to instances and require a name rather than an IP address in order to perform certificate ASN matching.
   443→
   444→## A quick tutorial
   445→
   446→In the next sections of this document, all the details about [_Sentinel API_](#sentinel-api),
   447→configuration and semantics will be covered incrementally. However for people
   448→that want to play with the system ASAP, this section is a tutorial that shows
   449→how to configure and interact with 3 Sentinel instances.
   450→
   451→Here we assume that the instances are executed at port 5000, 5001, 5002.
   452→We also assume that you have a running Redis master at port 6379 with a
   453→replica running at port 6380. We will use the IPv4 loopback address 127.0.0.1
   454→everywhere during the tutorial, assuming you are running the simulation
   455→on your personal computer.
   456→
   457→The three Sentinel configuration files should look like the following:
   458→
   459→    port 5000
   460→    sentinel monitor mymaster 127.0.0.1 6379 2
   461→    sentinel down-after-milliseconds mymaster 5000
   462→    sentinel failover-timeout mymaster 60000
   463→    sentinel parallel-syncs mymaster 1
   464→
   465→The other two configuration files will be identical but using 5001 and 5002
   466→as port numbers.
   467→
   468→A few things to note about the above configuration:
   469→
   470→* The master set is called `mymaster`. It identifies the master and its replicas. Since each *master set* has a different name, Sentinel can monitor different sets of masters and replicas at the same time.
   471→* The quorum was set to the value of 2 (last argument of `sentinel monitor` configuration directive).
   472→* The `down-after-milliseconds` value is 5000 milliseconds, that is 5 seconds, so masters will be detected as failing as soon as we don't receive any reply from our pings within this amount of time.
   473→
   474→Once you start the three Sentinels, you'll see a few messages they log, like:
   475→
   476→    +monitor master mymaster 127.0.0.1 6379 quorum 2
   477→
   478→This is a Sentinel event, and you can receive this kind of events via Pub/Sub
   479→if you [`SUBSCRIBE`](/commands/subscribe) to the event name as specified later in [_Pub/Sub Messages_ section](#pubsub-messages).
   480→
   481→Sentinel generates and logs different events during failure detection and
   482→failover.
   483→
   484→Asking Sentinel about the state of a master
   485→---
   486→
   487→The most obvious thing to do with Sentinel to get started, is check if the
   488→master it is monitoring is doing well:
   489→
   490→    $ redis-cli -p 5000
   491→    127.0.0.1:5000> sentinel master mymaster
   492→     1) "name"
   493→     2) "mymaster"
   494→     3) "ip"
   495→     4) "127.0.0.1"
   496→     5) "port"
   497→     6) "6379"
   498→     7) "runid"
   499→     8) "953ae6a589449c13ddefaee3538d356d287f509b"
   500→     9) "flags"
   501→    10) "master"
   502→    11) "link-pending-commands"
   503→    12) "0"
   504→    13) "link-refcount"
   505→    14) "1"
   506→    15) "last-ping-sent"
   507→    16) "0"
   508→    17) "last-ok-ping-reply"
   509→    18) "735"
   510→    19) "last-ping-reply"
   511→    20) "735"
   512→    21) "down-after-milliseconds"
   513→    22) "5000"
   514→    23) "info-refresh"
   515→    24) "126"
   516→    25) "role-reported"
   517→    26) "master"
   518→    27) "role-reported-time"
   519→    28) "532439"
   520→    29) "config-epoch"
   521→    30) "1"
   522→    31) "num-slaves"
   523→    32) "1"
   524→    33) "num-other-sentinels"
   525→    34) "2"
   526→    35) "quorum"
   527→    36) "2"
   528→    37) "failover-timeout"
   529→    38) "60000"
   530→    39) "parallel-syncs"
   531→    40) "1"
   532→
   533→As you can see, it prints a number of information about the master. There are
   534→a few that are of particular interest for us:
   535→
   536→1. `num-other-sentinels` is 2, so we know the Sentinel already detected two more Sentinels for this master. If you check the logs you'll see the `+sentinel` events generated.
   537→2. `flags` is just `master`. If the master was down we could expect to see `s_down` or `o_down` flag as well here.
   538→3. `num-slaves` is correctly set to 1, so Sentinel also detected that there is an attached replica to our master.
   539→
   540→In order to explore more about this instance, you may want to try the following
   541→two commands:
   542→
   543→    SENTINEL replicas mymaster
   544→    SENTINEL sentinels mymaster
   545→
   546→The first will provide similar information about the replicas connected to the
   547→master, and the second about the other Sentinels.
   548→
   549→Obtaining the address of the current master
   550→---
   551→
   552→As we already specified, Sentinel also acts as a configuration provider for
   553→clients that want to connect to a set of master and replicas. Because of
   554→possible failovers or reconfigurations, clients have no idea about who is
   555→the currently active master for a given set of instances, so Sentinel exports
   556→an API to ask this question:
   557→
   558→    127.0.0.1:5000> SENTINEL get-master-addr-by-name mymaster
   559→    1) "127.0.0.1"
   560→    2) "6379"
   561→
   562→### Testing the failover
   563→
   564→At this point our toy Sentinel deployment is ready to be tested. We can
   565→just kill our master and check if the configuration changes. To do so
   566→we can just do:
   567→
   568→    redis-cli -p 6379 DEBUG sleep 30
   569→
   570→This command will make our master no longer reachable, sleeping for 30 seconds.
   571→It basically simulates a master hanging for some reason.
   572→
   573→If you check the Sentinel logs, you should be able to see a lot of action:
   574→
   575→1. Each Sentinel detects the master is down with an `+sdown` event.
   576→2. This event is later escalated to `+odown`, which means that multiple Sentinels agree about the fact the master is not reachable.
   577→3. Sentinels vote a Sentinel that will start the first failover attempt.
   578→4. The failover happens.
   579→
   580→If you ask again what is the current master address for `mymaster`, eventually
   581→we should get a different reply this time:
   582→
   583→    127.0.0.1:5000> SENTINEL get-master-addr-by-name mymaster
   584→    1) "127.0.0.1"
   585→    2) "6380"
   586→
   587→So far so good... At this point you may jump to create your Sentinel deployment
   588→or can read more to understand all the Sentinel commands and internals.
   589→
   590→## Sentinel API
   591→
   592→Sentinel provides an API in order to inspect its state, check the health
   593→of monitored masters and replicas, subscribe in order to receive specific
   594→notifications, and change the Sentinel configuration at run time.
   595→
   596→By default Sentinel runs using TCP port 26379 (note that 6379 is the normal
   597→Redis port). Sentinels accept commands using the Redis protocol, so you can
   598→use `redis-cli` or any other unmodified Redis client in order to talk with
   599→Sentinel.
   600→
   601→It is possible to directly query a Sentinel to check what is the state of
   602→the monitored Redis instances from its point of view, to see what other
   603→Sentinels it knows, and so forth. Alternatively, using Pub/Sub, it is possible
   604→to receive *push style* notifications from Sentinels, every time some event
   605→happens, like a failover, or an instance entering an error condition, and
   606→so forth.
   607→
   608→### Sentinel commands
   609→
   610→The `SENTINEL` command is the main API for Sentinel. The following is the list of its subcommands (minimal version is noted for where applicable):
   611→
   612→* **SENTINEL CONFIG GET `<name>`** (`>= 6.2`) Get the current value of a global Sentinel configuration parameter. The specified name may be a wildcard, similar to the Redis [`CONFIG GET`](/commands/config-get) command.
   613→* **SENTINEL CONFIG SET `<name>` `<value>`** (`>= 6.2`) Set the value of a global Sentinel configuration parameter.
   614→* **SENTINEL CKQUORUM `<master name>`** Check if the current Sentinel configuration is able to reach the quorum needed to failover a master, and the majority needed to authorize the failover. This command should be used in monitoring systems to check if a Sentinel deployment is ok.
   615→* **SENTINEL FLUSHCONFIG** Force Sentinel to rewrite its configuration on disk, including the current Sentinel state. Normally Sentinel rewrites the configuration every time something changes in its state (in the context of the subset of the state which is persisted on disk across restart). However sometimes it is possible that the configuration file is lost because of operation errors, disk failures, package upgrade scripts or configuration managers. In those cases a way to force Sentinel to rewrite the configuration file is handy. This command works even if the previous configuration file is completely missing.
   616→* **SENTINEL FAILOVER `<master name>`** Force a failover as if the master was not reachable, and without asking for agreement to other Sentinels (however a new version of the configuration will be published so that the other Sentinels will update their configurations).
   617→* **SENTINEL GET-MASTER-ADDR-BY-NAME `<master name>`** Return the ip and port number of the master with that name. If a failover is in progress or terminated successfully for this master it returns the address and port of the promoted replica.
   618→* **SENTINEL INFO-CACHE** (`>= 3.2`) Return cached [`INFO`](/commands/info) output from masters and replicas.
   619→* **SENTINEL IS-MASTER-DOWN-BY-ADDR <ip> <port> <current-epoch> <runid>** Check if the master specified by ip:port is down from current Sentinel's point of view. This command is mostly for internal use.
   620→* **SENTINEL MASTER `<master name>`** Show the state and info of the specified master.
   621→* **SENTINEL MASTERS** Show a list of monitored masters and their state.
   622→* **SENTINEL MONITOR** Start Sentinel's monitoring. Refer to the [_Reconfiguring Sentinel at Runtime_ section](#reconfiguring-sentinel-at-runtime) for more information.
   623→* **SENTINEL MYID** (`>= 6.2`) Return the ID of the Sentinel instance.
   624→* **SENTINEL PENDING-SCRIPTS** This command returns information about pending scripts.
   625→* **SENTINEL REMOVE** Stop Sentinel's monitoring. Refer to the [_Reconfiguring Sentinel at Runtime_ section](#reconfiguring-sentinel-at-runtime) for more information.
   626→* **SENTINEL REPLICAS `<master name>`** (`>= 5.0`) Show a list of replicas for this master, and their state.
   627→* **SENTINEL SENTINELS `<master name>`** Show a list of sentinel instances for this master, and their state.
   628→* **SENTINEL SET** Set Sentinel's monitoring configuration. Refer to the [_Reconfiguring Sentinel at Runtime_ section](#reconfiguring-sentinel-at-runtime) for more information.
   629→* **SENTINEL SIMULATE-FAILURE (crash-after-election|crash-after-promotion|help)** (`>= 3.2`) This command simulates different Sentinel crash scenarios.
   630→* **SENTINEL RESET `<pattern>`** This command will reset all the masters with matching name. The pattern argument is a glob-style pattern. The reset process clears any previous state in a master (including a failover in progress), and removes every replica and sentinel already discovered and associated with the master.
   631→
   632→For connection management and administration purposes, Sentinel supports the following subset of Redis' commands:
   633→
   634→* **ACL** (`>= 6.2`) This command manages the Sentinel Access Control List. For more information refer to the [ACL]({{< relref "/operate/oss_and_stack/management/security/acl" >}}) documentation page and the [_Sentinel Access Control List authentication_](#sentinel-access-control-list-authentication).
   635→* **AUTH** (`>= 5.0.1`) Authenticate a client connection. For more information refer to the [`AUTH`](/commands/auth) command and the [_Configuring Sentinel instances with authentication_ section](#configuring-sentinel-instances-with-authentication).
   636→* **CLIENT** This command manages client connections. For more information refer to its subcommands' pages.
   637→* **COMMAND** (`>= 6.2`) This command returns information about commands. For more information refer to the [`COMMAND`](/commands/command) command and its various subcommands.
   638→* **HELLO** (`>= 6.0`) Switch the connection's protocol. For more information refer to the [`HELLO`](/commands/hello) command.
   639→* **INFO** Return information and statistics about the Sentinel server. For more information see the [`INFO`](/commands/info) command.
   640→* **PING** This command simply returns PONG.
   641→* **ROLE** This command returns the string "sentinel" and a list of monitored masters. For more information refer to the [`ROLE`](/commands/role) command.
