K-nearest neighbors (KNN) search\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"The KNN algorithm calculates the distance between the query vector and each vector in Redis based on the chosen distance function. It then returns the top K items with the smallest distances to the query vector. These are the most semantically similar items.\\\\n\\\\nNow construct a query to do just that:\\\\n\\\\n```python\\\\nquery = (\\\\n    Query(\'(*)=>[KNN 3 @vector $query_vector AS vector_score]\')\\\\n     .sort_by(\'vector_score\')\\\\n     .return_fields(\'vector_score\', \'id\', \'brand\', \'model\', \'description\')\\\\n     .dialect(2)\\\\n)\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nLet\'s break down the above query template:\\\\n- The filter expression `(*)` means `all`. In other words, no filtering was applied. You could replace it with an expression that filters by additional metadata.\\\\n- The `KNN` part of the query searches for the top 3 nearest neighbors.\\\\n- The query vector must be passed in as the param `query_vector`.\\\\n- The distance to the query vector is returned as `vector_score`.\\\\n- The results are sorted by this `vector_score`.\\\\n- Finally, it returns the fields `vector_score`,  `id`, `brand`, `model`, and `description` for each result.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nTo utilize a vector query with the [`FT.SEARCH`]() command, you must specify DIALECT 2 or greater.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nYou must pass the vectorized query as a byte array with the param name `query_vector`. The following code creates a Python NumPy array from the query vector and converts it into a compact, byte-level representation that can be passed as a parameter to the query:\\\\n\\\\n```python\\\\nfor i, encoded_query in enumerate(encoded_queries):\\\\n    result = client.ft(\'idx:bikes_vss\').search(\\\\n        query,\\\\n        {\\\\n          \'query_vector\': np.array(encoded_query, dtype=np.float32).tobytes()\\\\n        }\\\\n    )\\\\n    print(f\\\\\\"Results for query \'{queries[i]}\':\\\\\\")\\\\n    for doc in result.docs:\\\\n        print(f\\\\\\"\\\\\\\\t{doc.id}: {doc.brand} {doc.model}\\\\\\")\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWith the template for the query in place, you can execute all queries in a loop. Notice that the script calculates the `vector_score` for each result as `1 - doc.vector_score`. Because the cosine distance is used as the metric, the items with the smallest distance are closer and, therefore, more similar to the query.\\\\n\\\\nThen, loop over the matched documents and create a list of results that can be converted into a Pandas table to visualize the results:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nThe query results show the individual queries\' top three matches (our K parameter) along with the bike\'s id, brand, and model for each query.\\\\n\\\\nFor example, for the query \\\\\\"Best Mountain bikes for kids\\\\\\", the highest similarity score (`0.54`) and, therefore the closest match was the \'Nord\' brand \'Chook air 5\' bike model, described as:\\\\n\\\\n> The Chook Air 5 gives kids aged six years and older a durable and uberlight mountain bike for their first experience on tracks and easy cruising through forests and fields. It’s a single... |\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -0.0679,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"a4f96baf\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"a4f96baf-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/get-started/rag.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"RAG with Redis\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"The role of Redis in RAG\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Large Language Models (LLMs) generate human-like text but are limited by the data they were trained on. RAG enhances LLMs by integrating them with external, domain-specific data stored in a Redis [vector database]().\\\\n\\\\nRAG involves three main steps:\\\\n\\\\n- **Retrieve**: Fetch relevant information from Redis using vector search and filters based on the user query.\\\\n- **Augment**: Create a prompt for the LLM, including the user query, relevant context, and additional instructions.\\\\n- **Generate**: Return the response generated by the LLM to the user.\\\\n\\\\nRAG enables LLMs to use real-time information, improving the accuracy and relevance of generated content.\\\\nRedis is ideal for RAG due to its speed, versatility, and familiarity.\\\\n\\\\nRedis provides a robust platform for managing real-time data. It supports the storage and retrieval of vectors, essential for handling large-scale, unstructured data and performing similarity searches. Key features and components of Redis that make it suitable for RAG include:\\\\n\\\\n1. **Vector database**: Stores and indexes vector embeddings that semantically represent unstructured data.\\\\n1. **Semantic cache**: Caches frequently asked questions (FAQs) in a RAG pipeline. Using vector search, Redis retrieves similar previously answered questions, reducing LLM inference costs and latency.\\\\n1. **LLM session manager**: Stores conversation history between an LLM and a user. Redis fetches recent and relevant portions of the chat history to provide context, improving the quality and accuracy of responses.\\\\n1. **High performance and scalability**: Known for its [low latency and high throughput](https://redis.io/blog/benchmarking-results-for-vector-databases/), Redis is ideal for RAG systems and AI agents requiring rapid data retrieval and generation.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -0.1772,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"2485f6b9\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"2485f6b9-006\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisearch/redisearch-2.10-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisearch 2.10 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"v2.10 GA (v2.10.5) (July 2024) > What\'s new in 2.10.5\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"This new major version introduces new `BFLOAT16` and `FLOAT16` vector data types, reducing memory consumed by vectors while preserving accuracy. As a result, keys with expired fields may still be included in the query results, leading to potentially incorrect or inconsistent results.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -0.2318,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"d2a9a627\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"d2a9a627-046\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisstack/redisstack-6.2.6-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisstack 6.2.6 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Stack Server 6.2.6-v0 (December 2022) > Details:\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"**RediSearch**  introduces the following features:\\\\n* Support for [wildcard queries](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/reference/query_syntax/#wildcard-matching)  for TEXT and TAG fields, where\\\\n  - `?` matches any single character\\\\n  - `*` matches zero or more characters\\\\n  - use `\'` and `\\\\\\\\` for escaping, other special characters are ignored\\\\n  - Optimized wildcard query support (i.e., suffix trie)\\\\n* Multi-value indexing and querying\\\\n  - Multi-value text search - perform full-text search on [array of string or on a JSONPath](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/indexing_json/#index-json-arrays-as-tag) leading to multiple strings\\\\n  - Support for Geo, Vector, Numeric, Tag\\\\n  - Return JSON rather than scalars from multi-value attributes. This is enabled via Dialect 3 in order not to break existing applications.\\\\n  - Support indexing and querying of multi-value JSONPath attributes and/or arrays (requires JSON >2.4.1)\\\\n  - Support for `SORTABLE` fields on JSON in an implicit un-normalized form (UNF)\\\\n* Vector similarity 0.5.1:\\\\n  - Better space optimization selection\\\\n  - Aligning index capacity with block size\\\\n  - Support FLOAT64 as vector data type\\\\n  - Range query support\\\\n  - Support query attributes for vector queries\\\\n\\\\n**RedisJSON**  introduces the following features:\\\\n* Add JSONPath filter the regexp match operator\\\\n* Support legacy JSONpath with dollar `$`\\\\n* A new JSONPath library which enhances the performance of parsing any JSONPath expression in RedisJSON.\\\\n* Floating point numbers which become round numbers due to some operation, for example by `JSON.NUMINCRBY`, will now return as a floating point with a trailing `.0`, e.g., instead of just `42`, now `42.0` will be returned.\\\\n\\\\n**RedisBloom** introduces the following new features:\\\\n* A new sketch data structure: t-digest. t-digest is a sketch data structure for estimating quantiles based on a data stream or a large dataset of values. As for other sketch data structures, t-digest requires sublinear space and has controllable space-accuracy tradeoffs.\\\\n\\\\n**RedisGraph** introduces the following new features:\\\\n* New path-finding algorithms: \\\\n  - The `algo.SPpaths` procedure returns one, _n_, or all minimal-weight, optionally bounded-cost, optionally bounded-length paths between a given pair of nodes.\\\\n  - The `algo.SSpaths` procedure returns one, _n_, or all minimal-weight, optionally bounded-cost, optionally bounded-length paths from a given node.\\\\n* Introduce `SET` for adding node labels and `REMOVE` for removing node labels, node properties, and edge properties\\\\n* Support deleting paths with `DELETE`\\\\n* Introduce `toBoolean`, `toBooleanOrNull`, `toFloatOrNull`, `toIntegerOrNull`, `toStringOrNull`, `toBooleanList`, `toFloatList`, `toIntegerList`, `toStringList`, `properties`, `split`, `last`, `isEmpty`,`e`, `exp`, `log`, `log10`, `sin`, `cos`, `tan`, `cot`, `asin`, `acos`, `atan`, `atan2`, `degrees`, `radians`, `pi`, and `haversin` functions.\\\\n* Graph slow log can be reset with `GRAPH.SLOWLOG g RESET`\\\\n* Queries are now atomic (_Atomicity_ is the guarantee that each query either succeeds or fails with no side effects). Whenever a failure occurs, the query effect is rolled-back from an undo-log.\\\\n \\\\n**RedisTimeSeries** introduces the following new features:\\\\n* Introduction of a new aggregator: `twa` (time-weighted average)\\\\n* Introduction of a new optional `EMPTY` flag to `TS.RANGE`, `TS.REVRANGE`, `TS.MRANGE`, and `TS.MREVRANGE` to retrieve aggregations for empty buckets as well.\\\\n* Gap-filling: Using `EMPTY` when the aggregator is `twa` allows estimating the average of a continuous signal even for empty buckets based on linear interpolation of previous and next samples. Using `EMPTY` when the aggregator is `last` would repeat the value of the previous sample when the bucket is empty.\\\\n* Introduction of a new optional `BUCKETTIMESTAMP` parameter to `TS.RANGE`, `TS.REVRANGE`, `TS.MRANGE`, and `TS.MREVRANGE`. It is now possible to report the start time, the end time, or the mid time for each bucket.\\\\n* Introduction of a new optional `alignTimestamp` parameter to `TS.CREATERULE` and to `COMPACTION_POLICY` configuration parameter.  It is now possible to define alignment for compaction rules, so one can, for example, aggregate daily events from 06:00 to 06:00 the next day.\\\\n* Introduction of additional reducer types in This enables the frequently requested feature **suffix search** (`*vatore` and `ant?rez` are now supported).\\\\nIn addition, the 2.6 release is all about **multi-value indexing and querying of attributes** for any attribute type ( [Text](#index-json-arrays-as-text), [Tag](#index-json-arrays-as-tag), [Numeric](#index-json-arrays-as-numeric), [Geo](#index-json-arrays-as-geo) and [Vector](#index-json-arrays-as-vector)) defined by a [JSONPath]() leading to an array or to multiple scalar values.\\\\nLastly, this version adds support for indexing double-precision floating-point vectors and range queries from a given vector.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -0.3443,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"d2a9a627\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"d2a9a627-049\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisstack/redisstack-6.2.6-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisstack 6.2.6 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Stack Server 6.2.6-RC1 (November 2022) > Details:\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"**RediSearch**  introduces the following features:\\\\n* the ability to search using wildcard queries for TEXT and TAG fields. This enables the frequently asked feature of affix search and includes optimized wildcard query support :\\\\n   - `?` matches any single character\\\\n   - `*` matches zero or more characters\\\\n   - use `’` and `\\\\\\\\` for escaping, other special characters are ignored\\\\n* Multi-value indexing and querying of attributes for any attribute type ([Text](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/indexing_json/#index-json-arrays-as-text), [Tag](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/indexing_json/#index-json-arrays-as-tag), [Numeric](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/indexing_json/#index-json-arrays-as-numeric), [Geo](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/indexing_json/#index-json-arrays-as-geo) and [Vector](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/indexing_json/#index-json-arrays-as-vector)) defined by a [JSONPath](https://redis.io/docs/stack/json/path/) leading to an array:\\\\n  - Multi-value text search - perform full-text search on [array of string or on a JSONPath](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/indexing_json/#index-json-arrays-as-tag) leading to multiple strings\\\\n  - Return JSON rather than scalars from multi-value attributes. This is enabled via Dialect 3 in order not to break existing applications.\\\\n  - Support for `SORTABLE` fields on JSON in an implicit un-normalized form (UNF)\\\\n* Support for indexing double-precision floating-point vectors and range queries from a given vector:\\\\n  - Better space optimization selection\\\\n  - Aligning index capacity with block size\\\\n  - Support FLOAT64 as vector data type\\\\n  - Range query support\\\\n  - Support query attributes for vector queries\\\\n \\\\n**RedisJSON**  introduces the following features:\\\\n* A new JSONPath library which enhances the performance of parsing any JSONPath expression in RedisJSON.\\\\n \\\\n**RedisBloom** introduces the following new features:\\\\n* A new sketch data structure: t-digest. t-digest is a sketch data structure for estimating quantiles based on a data stream or a large dataset of values. As for other sketch data structures, t-digest requires sublinear space and has controllable space-accuracy tradeoffs.\\\\n\\\\n**RedisGraph** introduces the following new features:\\\\n* New path-finding algorithms: \\\\n  - The `algo.SPpaths` procedure returns one, _n_, or all minimal-weight, optionally bounded-cost, optionally bounded-length paths between a given pair of nodes.\\\\n  - The `algo.SSpaths` procedure returns one, _n_, or all minimal-weight, optionally bounded-cost, optionally bounded-length paths from a given node.\\\\n* Introduce `SET` for adding node labels and `REMOVE` for removing node labels, node properties, and edge properties\\\\n* Support deleting paths with `DELETE`\\\\n* Introduce `toBoolean`, `toBooleanOrNull`, `toFloatOrNull`, `toIntegerOrNull`, `toStringOrNull`, `toBooleanList`, `toFloatList`, `toIntegerList`, `toStringList`, `properties`, `split`, `last`, `isEmpty`,`e`, `exp`, `log`, `log10`, `sin`, `cos`, `tan`, `cot`, `asin`, `acos`, `atan`, `atan2`, `degrees`, `radians`, `pi`, and `haversin` functions.\\\\n* Graph slow log can be reset with `GRAPH.SLOWLOG g RESET` (also added in 2.8.20)\\\\n* Queries are now atomic (_Atomicity_ is the guarantee that each query either succeeds or fails with no side effects). Whenever a failure occurs, the query effect is rolled-back from an undo-log.\\\\n \\\\n**RedisTimeSeries** introduces the following new features:\\\\n* Introduction of a new aggregator: `twa` (time-weighted average)\\\\n* Introduction of a new optional `EMPTY` flag to `TS.RANGE`, `TS.REVRANGE`, `TS.MRANGE`, and `TS.MREVRANGE` to retrieve aggregations for empty buckets as well.\\\\n* Gap-filling: Using `EMPTY` when the aggregator is `twa` allows estimating the average of a continuous signal even for empty buckets based on linear interpolation of previous and next samples. Using `EMPTY` when the aggregator is `last` would repeat the value of the previous sample when the bucket is empty.\\\\n* Introduction of a new optional `BUCKETTIMESTAMP` parameter to `TS.RANGE`, `TS.REVRANGE`, `TS.MRANGE`, and `TS.MREVRANGE`. It is now possible to report the start time, the end time, or the mid time for each bucket.\\\\n* Introduction of a new optional `alignTimestamp` parameter to `TS.CREATERULE` and to `COMPACTION_POLICY` configuration parameter.  It is now possible to define alignment for compaction rules, so one can, for example, aggregate daily events from 06:00 to 06:00 the next day.\\\\n* Introduction of additional reducer types in `GROUPBY` (`TS.MRANGE`, and `TS.MREVRANGE`): `avg`, `range`, `count`, `std.p`, `std.s`, `var.p`, and `var.s`\\\\n* Introduction of a new optional `LATEST` flag to `TS.GET`, `TS.MGET`, `TS.RANGE`, `TS.REVRANGE`, `TS.MRANGE`, and `TS.MREVRANGE`. it is possible to retrieve the latest (possibly partial) bucket as well.\\\\n\\\\n \\\\n**Redis version** (no changes)\\\\n* [Redis 6.2.7](https://github.com/redis/redis/blob/6.2.7/00-RELEASENOTES)\\\\n \\\\n\\\\n**Module versions**\\\\n* __[RediSearch 2.6.1](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/releases/tag/v2.6.1)__\\\\n* __[RedisJSON 2.4.0](https://github.com/RedisJSON/RedisJSON/releases/tag/v2.4.0)__\\\\n* __[RedisGraph 2.10-RC1 (v2.10.2)](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/releases/tag/v2.10.2)__\\\\n* __[RedisTimeSeries 1.8-RC3 (v1.8.2)](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/RedisTimeSeries/releases/tag/v1.8.2)__\\\\n* __[RedisBloom 2.4-RC3 (v2.4.2)](https://github.com/RedisBloom/RedisBloom/releases/tag/v2.4.2)__\\\\n\\\\n**Recommended Client Libraries  (no changes)**\\\\n* Java\\\\n  * [Jedis 4.2.0 or greater ](https://github.com/redis/jedis/releases/tag/v4.2.0)\\\\n  * [redis-om-spring](https://github.com/redis/redis-om-spring)\\\\n* Python\\\\n  * [redis-py 4.3.1 or greater ](https://github.com/redis/redis-py/releases/tag/v4.3.1)\\\\n  * [redis-om-python](https://github.com/redis/redis-om-python)\\\\n* NodeJS\\\\n  * [node-redis 4.4.0  or greater](https://www.npmjs.com/package/redis)\\\\n  * [redis-om-node](https://github.com/redis/redis-om-node)\\\\n* .NET\\\\n  * [redis-om-dotnet](https://github.com/redis/redis-om-dotnet)\\\\n\\\\nCompatible with the latest [RedisInsight](https://redis.io/download). The docker image redis/redis-stack for this version is bundled with RedisInsight 2.12.0.\\\\n\\\\nNote: version numbers follow the pattern:\\\\n\\\\n`x.y.z-b`\\\\n* `x.y` Redis major version\\\\n* `z` increases with even numbers as a module x.y version increases.\\\\n* `b` denotes a patch to Redis or a module (any `z` of Redis or modules). `b` will consist of a `v` + numeric value.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -0.3478,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"7b321ff7\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"7b321ff7-003\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisearch/redisearch-2.0-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisearch 2.0 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"v2.0.0 (September 2020)\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"This is a maintenance release for version 2.0.\\\\n\\\\nDetails:\\\\n\\\\n- Bugfixes in RediSearch:\\\\n    - [#1668](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/1668) Stopwords are not filtered out on tag fields.\\\\n- Bugfixes in RSCoordinator:\\\\n    - [#206](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/206) `FT.AGGREGATE` with `LIMIT` and `offset` greater than `0` returned fewer results than requested.\\\\n\\\\nThis is a maintenance release for version 2.0.\\\\n\\\\nMinor bugfixes:\\\\n\\\\n- Added [`OSS_GLOBAL_PASSWORD`](https://github.com/RediSearch/RSCoordinator#running-rscoordinator) config argument to allow specify shards password on OSS cluster.\\\\n- Update `min_redis_pack_version` to 6.0.8\\\\n\\\\nThis is a maintenance release for version 2.0.\\\\n\\\\n- Minor enhancements:\\\\n\\\\n    - [#1625](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/1625) MAXPREFIXEXPANSIONS configuration which replaces the now deprecated config MAXEXPANSIONS. Same behaviour, more declarative naming.\\\\n    - [#1614](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/1614) Prevent multiple sortby steps on FT.AGGREGATE\\\\n\\\\n- Minor bug fixes:\\\\n\\\\n    - [#1605](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/1605) Rare bug where identical results would get a lower score\\\\n\\\\nThis is a maintenance release for version 2.0.\\\\n\\\\n- Minor additions:\\\\n\\\\n    - [#1432](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/1432) FT.AGGREGATE allows filtering by key and returning the key by using LOAD \\\\\\"@__key\\\\\\" .\\\\n\\\\n- Minor bug fixes:\\\\n\\\\n    - [#1571](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/1571) Using FILTER in FT.CREATE might cause index to not be in sync with data.\\\\n    - [#1572](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/1572) Crash when using WITHSORTKEYS without SORTBY.\\\\n    - [#1540](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/1540) SORTBY should raise an error if the field is not defined as SORTABLE.\\\\n\\\\nRediSearch 2.0 is a public preview release meeting GA standards. This release includes several improvements in performance and usability over RediSearch 1.0. These improvements necessitate a few backward-breaking changes to the API.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text='根据检索结果，Redis vector sets 支持 **filtered search**，并且可以结合标签（属性）进行过滤。以下是详细说明：

## Filtered Search 功能

Redis vector sets 通过 `FILTER` 选项在 `VSIM` 命令中实现过滤搜索，可以将向量相似度搜索与标量属性过滤结合起来。

### 基本用法

```bash
# 基本的过滤查询
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '.year >= 1980 and .rating > 7'
```

### 设置和管理属性

**添加属性（添加向量时）：**
```bash
VADD vset VALUES 3 1 1 1 a SETATTR '{"year": 1950}'
```

**更新属性：**
```bash
VSETATTR vset a '{"year": 1960}'
```

**查询属性：**
```bash
VGETATTR vset a
```

## 支持的过滤表达式

过滤器支持类似 JavaScript 的语法：

- **算术运算**：`+`, `-`, `*`, `/`, `%`, `**`
- **比较运算**：`==`, `!=`, `>`, `<`, `>=`, `<=`
- **逻辑运算**：`and`, `or`, `not`（或 `&&`, `||`, `!`）
- **包含运算**：`in`（用于数组）
- **分组**：括号 `()`

### 实际示例

```bash
# 按年份范围过滤
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '.year >= 1980 and .year < 1990'

# 按类型和评分过滤
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '.genre == "action" and .rating > 8.0'

# 使用 IN 操作符（标签数组）
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '.director in ["Spielberg", "Nolan"]'

# 复杂的数学和逻辑表达式
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '(.year - 2000) ** 2 < 100 and .rating / 2 > 4'
```

## FILTER-EF 参数调优

`FILTER-EF` 参数控制引擎检查多少候选节点以找到足够的过滤结果（默认值：`COUNT * 100`）：

```bash
# 为稀有过滤条件使用更高的值
VSIM vset VALUES 3 0 0 0 COUNT 10 FILTER '.year > 2000' FILTER-EF 500

# 扫描所有必要节点直到满足请求
VSIM vset VALUES 3 0 0 0 FILTER '.year > 2000' FILTER-EF 0
```

## 注意事项

- **仅支持顶层字段**：例如 `.genre` 可以，但 `.movie.genre` 不支持
- **缺失或无效字段**：如果字段缺失或无效，该元素会被静默跳过，不会报错
- **数据类型**：支持数字、字符串、布尔值（转换为 1 或 0）、数组（用于 `in` 操作）

## 故障排查

如果过滤器排除了太多项目，可以：
1. 使用 `VGETATTR` 验证属性
2. 检查字段名、JSON 有效性和值类型
3. 简化过滤表达式

**[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/vector-sets/filtered-search.md]**  
**[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/vector-sets/troubleshooting.md > See also]**')]

query: How to install Redis Stack on Ubuntu with apt?
answer:
To install Redis Stack on Ubuntu with apt, follow these steps:

**1. Add the Redis repository:**

```bash
sudo apt-get install lsb-release curl gpg
curl -fsSL https://packages.redis.io/gpg | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /usr/share/keyrings/redis-archive-keyring.gpg
sudo chmod 644 /usr/share/keyrings/redis-archive-keyring.gpg
echo "deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/redis-archive-keyring.gpg] https://packages.redis.io/deb $(lsb_release -cs) main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/redis.list
```

**2. Update and install Redis Stack:**

```bash
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install redis-stack-server
```

**3. Enable and start the service:**

Redis won't start automatically after installation. To enable it at boot and start it now:

```bash
sudo systemctl enable redis-stack-server
sudo systemctl start redis-stack-server
```

**4. Verify the installation:**

```bash
redis-cli
127.0.0.1:6379> ping
PONG
```

[来源: redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/install/archive/install-stack/linux.md > On Ubuntu with Snap]

[TextBlock(text='To install Redis Stack on Ubuntu with apt, follow these steps:

**1. Add the Redis repository:**

```bash
sudo apt-get install lsb-release curl gpg
curl -fsSL https://packages.redis.io/gpg | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /usr/share/keyrings/redis-archive-keyring.gpg
sudo chmod 644 /usr/share/keyrings/redis-archive-keyring.gpg
echo "deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/redis-archive-keyring.gpg] https://packages.redis.io/deb $(lsb_release -cs) main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/redis.list
```

**2. Update and install Redis Stack:**

```bash
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install redis-stack-server
```

**3. Enable and start the service:**

Redis won't start automatically after installation. To enable it at boot and start it now:

```bash
sudo systemctl enable redis-stack-server
sudo systemctl start redis-stack-server
```

**4. Verify the installation:**

```bash
redis-cli
127.0.0.1:6379> ping
PONG
```

[来源: redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/install/archive/install-stack/linux.md > On Ubuntu with Snap]')]

messages.result:
To install Redis Stack on Ubuntu with apt, follow these steps:

**1. Add the Redis repository:**

```bash
sudo apt-get install lsb-release curl gpg
curl -fsSL https://packages.redis.io/gpg | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /usr/share/keyrings/redis-archive-keyring.gpg
sudo chmod 644 /usr/share/keyrings/redis-archive-keyring.gpg
echo "deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/redis-archive-keyring.gpg] https://packages.redis.io/deb $(lsb_release -cs) main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/redis.list
```

**2. Update and install Redis Stack:**

```bash
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install redis-stack-server
```

**3. Enable and start the service:**

Redis won't start automatically after installation. To enable it at boot and start it now:

```bash
sudo systemctl enable redis-stack-server
sudo systemctl start redis-stack-server
```

**4. Verify the installation:**

```bash
redis-cli
127.0.0.1:6379> ping
PONG
```

query: How to build a local RAG agent with Llama?
answer:
Based on the knowledge base, here's how to build a local RAG agent with Llama:

## Overview

You can build a fully local RAG agent using **Llama 3.2** with **Ollama**, **Qdrant** for vector storage, and **Agno v2.0** framework. This setup requires no external API dependencies.

## Step-by-Step Setup

### 1. Prerequisites
```bash
# Install Ollama
# Download from https://ollama.com/download

# Pull Llama 3.2 model
ollama pull llama3.2

# Pull embedding model
ollama pull openhermes
```

### 2. Set Up Vector Database
```bash
# Install and run Qdrant locally
docker pull qdrant/qdrant
docker run -p 6333:6333 qdrant/qdrant
```

### 3. Install Dependencies
```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/local_rag_agent

# Install requirements
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

### 4. Run the Application
```bash
python local_rag_agent.py
```

Access the web interface at `http://localhost:7777` through the AgentOS interface.

## Key Features

- **Fully local implementation** - No external API calls
- **Llama 3.2** via Ollama for text generation
- **Qdrant** for vector search
- **Agno v2.0 Knowledge class** for document management
- **Interactive web UI** through AgentOS

## How It Works

1. Documents (e.g., PDFs) are loaded into the knowledge base on first run
2. Content is chunked and embedded using the local embedding model
3. Embeddings are stored in Qdrant vector database
4. User queries are embedded and searched against the knowledge base
5. Llama 3.2 generates answers based on retrieved context

## Note

After the first run, you can comment out the `knowledge_base.add_content()` line to avoid reloading documents.

**[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/local_rag_agent/README.md > 🦙 Local RAG Agent with Llama 3.2 > Note]**

For a complete step-by-step tutorial with detailed code walkthroughs, visit: https://www.theunwindai.com/p/build-a-local-rag-agent

[TextBlock(text="Based on the knowledge base, here's how to build a local RAG agent with Llama:

## Overview

You can build a fully local RAG agent using **Llama 3.2** with **Ollama**, **Qdrant** for vector storage, and **Agno v2.0** framework. This setup requires no external API dependencies.

## Step-by-Step Setup

### 1. Prerequisites
```bash
# Install Ollama
# Download from https://ollama.com/download

# Pull Llama 3.2 model
ollama pull llama3.2

# Pull embedding model
ollama pull openhermes
```

### 2. Set Up Vector Database
```bash
# Install and run Qdrant locally
docker pull qdrant/qdrant
docker run -p 6333:6333 qdrant/qdrant
```

### 3. Install Dependencies
```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/local_rag_agent

# Install requirements
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

### 4. Run the Application
```bash
python local_rag_agent.py
```

Access the web interface at `http://localhost:7777` through the AgentOS interface.

## Key Features

- **Fully local implementation** - No external API calls
- **Llama 3.2** via Ollama for text generation
- **Qdrant** for vector search
- **Agno v2.0 Knowledge class** for document management
- **Interactive web UI** through AgentOS

## How It Works

1. Documents (e.g., PDFs) are loaded into the knowledge base on first run
2. Content is chunked and embedded using the local embedding model
3. Embeddings are stored in Qdrant vector database
4. User queries are embedded and searched against the knowledge base
5. Llama 3.2 generates answers based on retrieved context

## Note

After the first run, you can comment out the `knowledge_base.add_content()` line to avoid reloading documents.

**[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/local_rag_agent/README.md > 🦙 Local RAG Agent with Llama 3.2 > Note]**

For a complete step-by-step tutorial with detailed code walkthroughs, visit: https://www.theunwindai.com/p/build-a-local-rag-agent")]

Based on the knowledge base, here's how to build a local RAG agent with Llama:

## Overview

You can build a fully local RAG agent using **Llama 3.2** with **Ollama**, **Qdrant** for vector storage, and **Agno v2.0** framework. This setup requires no external API dependencies.

## Step-by-Step Setup

### 1. Prerequisites
```bash
# Install Ollama
# Download from https://ollama.com/download

# Pull Llama 3.2 model
ollama pull llama3.2

# Pull embedding model
ollama pull openhermes
```

### 2. Set Up Vector Database
```bash
# Install and run Qdrant locally
docker pull qdrant/qdrant
docker run -p 6333:6333 qdrant/qdrant
```

### 3. Install Dependencies
```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/local_rag_agent

# Install requirements
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

### 4. Run the Application
```bash
python local_rag_agent.py
```

Access the web interface at `http://localhost:7777` through the AgentOS interface.

## Key Features

- **Fully local implementation** - No external API calls
- **Llama 3.2** via Ollama for text generation
- **Qdrant** for vector search
- **Agno v2.0 Knowledge class** for document management
- **Interactive web UI** through AgentOS

## How It Works

1. Documents (e.g., PDFs) are loaded into the knowledge base on first run
2. Content is chunked and embedded using the local embedding model
3. Embeddings are stored in Qdrant vector database
4. User queries are embedded and searched against the knowledge base
5. Llama 3.2 generates answers based on retrieved context

## Note

After the first run, you can comment out the `knowledge_base.add_content()` line to avoid reloading documents.

query: What is Corrective RAG and how does it improve retrieval quality?
answer:
Based on the knowledge base search, here's what Corrective RAG is and how it improves retrieval quality:

## What is Corrective RAG?

Corrective RAG is a sophisticated multi-stage Retrieval-Augmented Generation system that implements a corrective workflow to provide more comprehensive and accurate responses. Unlike traditional RAG systems that simply retrieve and generate, Corrective RAG adds quality control and fallback mechanisms.

## How It Improves Retrieval Quality

Corrective RAG enhances retrieval through several key mechanisms:

1. **Document Relevance Grading**: Uses an LLM (like Claude 4.5 Sonnet) to assess whether retrieved documents are actually relevant to the query, filtering out low-quality results.

2. **Query Transformation**: When initial retrieval results are insufficient, the system optimizes and reformulates the query to improve search effectiveness.

3. **Web Search Fallback**: If local documents aren't sufficient or relevant enough, the system automatically falls back to web search (using tools like Tavily API) to find additional information.

4. **Multi-Stage Workflow**: Combines multiple retrieval strategies in a coordinated workflow managed by LangGraph, ensuring each stage validates and corrects the previous one.

## Architecture

The system typically includes:
- Vector store (like Qdrant) for efficient document retrieval
- LLM-based relevance grading to validate retrieved documents
- Query rewriting capabilities when initial results are poor
- External search integration as a safety net
- Interactive UI for document upload and querying

This corrective approach significantly reduces hallucinations and improves answer accuracy by ensuring only relevant information reaches the generation stage.

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/corrective_rag/README.md > 🔄 Corrective RAG Agent]

Key features and components of Redis that make it suitable for RAG include:\\\\n\\\\n1. **Vector database**: Stores and indexes vector embeddings that semantically represent unstructured data.\\\\n1. **Semantic cache**: Caches frequently asked questions (FAQs) in a RAG pipeline. Redis fetches recent and relevant portions of the chat history to provide context, improving the quality and accuracy of responses.\\\\n1. **High performance and scalability**: Known for its [low latency and high throughput](https://redis.io/blog/benchmarking-results-for-vector-databases/), Redis is ideal for RAG systems and AI agents requiring rapid data retrieval and generation.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text="Based on the knowledge base search, here's what Corrective RAG is and how it improves retrieval quality:

## What is Corrective RAG?

Corrective RAG is a sophisticated multi-stage Retrieval-Augmented Generation system that implements a corrective workflow to provide more comprehensive and accurate responses. Unlike traditional RAG systems that simply retrieve and generate, Corrective RAG adds quality control and fallback mechanisms.

## How It Improves Retrieval Quality

Corrective RAG enhances retrieval through several key mechanisms:

1. **Document Relevance Grading**: Uses an LLM (like Claude 4.5 Sonnet) to assess whether retrieved documents are actually relevant to the query, filtering out low-quality results.

2. **Query Transformation**: When initial retrieval results are insufficient, the system optimizes and reformulates the query to improve search effectiveness.

3. **Web Search Fallback**: If local documents aren't sufficient or relevant enough, the system automatically falls back to web search (using tools like Tavily API) to find additional information.

4. **Multi-Stage Workflow**: Combines multiple retrieval strategies in a coordinated workflow managed by LangGraph, ensuring each stage validates and corrects the previous one.

## Architecture

The system typically includes:
- Vector store (like Qdrant) for efficient document retrieval
- LLM-based relevance grading to validate retrieved documents
- Query rewriting capabilities when initial results are poor
- External search integration as a safety net
- Interactive UI for document upload and querying

This corrective approach significantly reduces hallucinations and improves answer accuracy by ensuring only relevant information reaches the generation stage.

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/corrective_rag/README.md > 🔄 Corrective RAG Agent]")]

Based on the knowledge base search, here's what Corrective RAG is and how it improves retrieval quality:

## What is Corrective RAG?

Corrective RAG is a sophisticated multi-stage Retrieval-Augmented Generation system that implements a corrective workflow to provide more comprehensive and accurate responses. Unlike traditional RAG systems that simply retrieve and generate, Corrective RAG adds quality control and fallback mechanisms.

## How It Improves Retrieval Quality

Corrective RAG enhances retrieval through several key mechanisms:

1. **Document Relevance Grading**: Uses an LLM (like Claude 4.5 Sonnet) to assess whether retrieved documents are actually relevant to the query, filtering out low-quality results.

2. **Query Transformation**: When initial retrieval results are insufficient, the system optimizes and reformulates the query to improve search effectiveness.

3. **Web Search Fallback**: If local documents aren't sufficient or relevant enough, the system automatically falls back to web search (using tools like Tavily API) to find additional information.

4. **Multi-Stage Workflow**: Combines multiple retrieval strategies in a coordinated workflow managed by LangGraph, ensuring each stage validates and corrects the previous one.

## Architecture

The system typically includes:
- Vector store (like Qdrant) for efficient document retrieval
- LLM-based relevance grading to validate retrieved documents
- Query rewriting capabilities when initial results are poor
- External search integration as a safety net
- Interactive UI for document upload and querying

This corrective approach significantly reduces hallucinations and improves answer accuracy by ensuring only relevant information reaches the generation stage.

query: 怎么用 Agentic RAG 实现带推理能力的检索？
answer:
找到了关于 Agentic RAG 实现推理能力的详细文档。以下是核心实现方法：

## 核心架构

Agentic RAG 通过以下组件实现推理能力：

### 1. 推理工具集成（ReasoningTools）
- 使用 **Gemini 2.5 Flash** 或 **Deepseek R1** 等支持推理的模型
- 集成 ReasoningTools 让 Agent 进行逐步分析
- 实时展示 Agent 的思考过程（thinking process visualization）

### 2. 透明推理流程
系统将推理过程分为两个并行展示：
- **左侧面板**：实时显示 Agent 的推理步骤（reasoning steps）
- **右侧面板**：最终答案和来源引用
- 用户可以清晰看到从查询到答案的完整 RAG 过程

### 3. 智能查询处理流程

```
用户查询 
  ↓
查询重写（Query Rewriting）
  ↓
向量检索（Vector Search + Semantic Matching）
  ↓
相似度阈值过滤
  ↓
自动降级到 Web 搜索（如果文档不相关）
  ↓
推理生成（Reasoning + Response Generation）
  ↓
来源归因（Source Attribution）
```

### 4. 关键技术栈

**推理层**：
- Gemini 2.5 Flash Thinking / Deepseek R1（推理模型）
- Agno v2.0 框架（Agent 编排）
- ReasoningTools（逐步分析）

**检索层**：
- OpenAI Embeddings / Snowflake Arctic（向量编码）
- Qdrant / LanceDB（向量存储）
- 相似度阈值过滤（threshold filtering）

**增强层**：
- Exa AI（Web 搜索降级）
- 自定义域名过滤
- 上下文感知生成

### 5. 实现示例

```python
# 核心流程（基于 Agno 框架）
agent = Agent(
    model=Gemini("gemini-2.5-flash"),
    tools=[ReasoningTools()],
    knowledge=Knowledge(
        vector_db=LanceDB(),
        embedder=OpenAIEmbedder()
    ),
    show_tool_calls=True,  # 展示推理过程
    markdown=True
)

# 流式输出推理步骤
for event in agent.run(query, stream=True):
    if event.event == "reasoning":
        display_reasoning(event.content)
    elif event.event == "response":
        display_answer(event.content)
```

### 6. 推理能力的关键特性

- **逐步思考**：Agent 将复杂问题分解为多个推理步骤
- **工具调用可见性**：Debug 模式展示每次工具调用和执行流程
- **上下文感知**：基于检索到的文档进行推理，而非通用知识
- **来源追溯**：每个推理步骤都标注信息来源
- **自动降级**：文档不足时自动切换到 Web 搜索

## 最佳实践

1. **选择支持推理的模型**：Gemini 2.5 Flash Thinking、Deepseek R1、Claude 3.5 Sonnet
2. **启用流式输出**：让用户看到推理过程，增强可信度
3. **设置相似度阈值**：避免不相关文档干扰推理
4. **集成 Web 搜索降级**：知识库不足时自动扩展信息源
5. **记录完整推理链**：便于调试和评估推理质量

[TextBlock(text='找到了关于 Agentic RAG 实现推理能力的详细文档。以下是核心实现方法：

## 核心架构

Agentic RAG 通过以下组件实现推理能力：

### 1. 推理工具集成（ReasoningTools）
- 使用 **Gemini 2.5 Flash** 或 **Deepseek R1** 等支持推理的模型
- 集成 ReasoningTools 让 Agent 进行逐步分析
- 实时展示 Agent 的思考过程（thinking process visualization）

### 2. 透明推理流程
系统将推理过程分为两个并行展示：
- **左侧面板**：实时显示 Agent 的推理步骤（reasoning steps）
- **右侧面板**：最终答案和来源引用
- 用户可以清晰看到从查询到答案的完整 RAG 过程

### 3. 智能查询处理流程

```
用户查询 
  ↓
查询重写（Query Rewriting）
  ↓
向量检索（Vector Search + Semantic Matching）
  ↓
相似度阈值过滤
  ↓
自动降级到 Web 搜索（如果文档不相关）
  ↓
推理生成（Reasoning + Response Generation）
  ↓
来源归因（Source Attribution）
```

### 4. 关键技术栈

**推理层**：
- Gemini 2.5 Flash Thinking / Deepseek R1（推理模型）
- Agno v2.0 框架（Agent 编排）
- ReasoningTools（逐步分析）

**检索层**：
- OpenAI Embeddings / Snowflake Arctic（向量编码）
- Qdrant / LanceDB（向量存储）
- 相似度阈值过滤（threshold filtering）

**增强层**：
- Exa AI（Web 搜索降级）
- 自定义域名过滤
- 上下文感知生成

### 5. 实现示例

```python
# 核心流程（基于 Agno 框架）
agent = Agent(
    model=Gemini("gemini-2.5-flash"),
    tools=[ReasoningTools()],
    knowledge=Knowledge(
        vector_db=LanceDB(),
        embedder=OpenAIEmbedder()
    ),
    show_tool_calls=True,  # 展示推理过程
    markdown=True
)

# 流式输出推理步骤
for event in agent.run(query, stream=True):
    if event.event == "reasoning":
        display_reasoning(event.content)
    elif event.event == "response":
        display_answer(event.content)
```

### 6. 推理能力的关键特性

- **逐步思考**：Agent 将复杂问题分解为多个推理步骤
- **工具调用可见性**：Debug 模式展示每次工具调用和执行流程
- **上下文感知**：基于检索到的文档进行推理，而非通用知识
- **来源追溯**：每个推理步骤都标注信息来源
- **自动降级**：文档不足时自动切换到 Web 搜索

## 最佳实践

1. **选择支持推理的模型**：Gemini 2.5 Flash Thinking、Deepseek R1、Claude 3.5 Sonnet
2. **启用流式输出**：让用户看到推理过程，增强可信度
3. **设置相似度阈值**：避免不相关文档干扰推理
4. **集成 Web 搜索降级**：知识库不足时自动扩展信息源
5. **记录完整推理链**：便于调试和评估推理质量

[来源: awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/agentic_rag_with_reasoning/README.md > How It Works]  
[来源: awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/gemini_agentic_rag/README.md > Features]  
[来源: awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/deepseek_local_rag_agent/README.md > Features]')]

query: How to build a RAG app that can chat with PDF documents?
answer:
Based on the knowledge base, here's how to build a RAG app that can chat with PDF documents:

## Quick Start: Chat with PDF in 30 Lines of Python

The simplest approach uses Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) with these steps:

**1. Clone and Setup**
```bash
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_pdf
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

**2. Get API Key**
- Sign up for an [OpenAI account](https://platform.openai.com/) and obtain your API key

**3. Run the App**
```bash
streamlit run chat_pdf.py
```

**Key Features:**
- Upload PDF documents
- Ask questions about the content
- Get accurate answers using RAG and LLM

[来源: awesome-llm-apps/chat_with_pdf/README.md > 📄 Chat with PDF]

---

## Advanced Options

### Voice-Enabled RAG with PDF
For a more sophisticated system with text-to-speech:

**Features:**
- PDF document processing and chunking
- Qdrant vector database for similarity search
- Real-time text-to-speech with multiple voice options
- Download audio responses

**Setup:**
```bash
cd awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/voice_rag_openaisdk
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

Create `.env` file:
```bash
OPENAI_API_KEY='your-openai-api-key'
QDRANT_URL='your-qdrant-url'
QDRANT_API_KEY='your-qdrant-api-key'
```

Run: `streamlit run rag_voice.py`

[来源: awesome-llm-apps/voice_rag_openaisdk/README.md]

### Autonomous RAG with Vector Database
For production-grade systems with persistent storage:

**Features:**
- PDF upload and processing
- PostgreSQL + Pgvector for knowledge base
- Web search capability (DuckDuckGo)
- Persistent conversations

**Setup:**
```bash
cd awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/autonomous_rag
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Start PgVector database
docker run -d \
  -e POSTGRES_DB=ai \
  -e POSTGRES_USER=ai \
  -e POSTGRES_PASSWORD=ai \
  -p 5532:5432 \
  --name pgvector \
  phidata/pgvector:16

streamlit run autorag.py
```

[来源: awesome-llm-apps/autonomous_rag/README.md]

### Hybrid Search RAG
For better retrieval accuracy combining semantic and keyword matching:

**Features:**
- Hybrid search (semantic + keyword)
- Reranking for better context selection
- Multi-model integration (Claude + OpenAI + Cohere)

**Required API Keys:**
- OpenAI (embeddings)
- Anthropic (Claude for generation)
- Cohere (reranking)
- Neon PostgreSQL database

[来源: awesome-llm-apps/hybrid_search_rag/README.md]

All tutorials include complete step-by-step guides with code walkthroughs and best practices.

[TextBlock(text="Based on the knowledge base, here's how to build a RAG app that can chat with PDF documents:

## Quick Start: Chat with PDF in 30 Lines of Python

The simplest approach uses Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) with these steps:

**1. Clone and Setup**
```bash
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_pdf
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

**2. Get API Key**
- Sign up for an [OpenAI account](https://platform.openai.com/) and obtain your API key

**3. Run the App**
```bash
streamlit run chat_pdf.py
```

**Key Features:**
- Upload PDF documents
- Ask questions about the content
- Get accurate answers using RAG and LLM

[来源: awesome-llm-apps/chat_with_pdf/README.md > 📄 Chat with PDF]

---

## Advanced Options

### Voice-Enabled RAG with PDF
For a more sophisticated system with text-to-speech:

**Features:**
- PDF document processing and chunking
- Qdrant vector database for similarity search
- Real-time text-to-speech with multiple voice options
- Download audio responses

**Setup:**
```bash
cd awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/voice_rag_openaisdk
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

Create `.env` file:
```bash
OPENAI_API_KEY='your-openai-api-key'
QDRANT_URL='your-qdrant-url'
QDRANT_API_KEY='your-qdrant-api-key'
```

Run: `streamlit run rag_voice.py`

[来源: awesome-llm-apps/voice_rag_openaisdk/README.md]

### Autonomous RAG with Vector Database
For production-grade systems with persistent storage:

**Features:**
- PDF upload and processing
- PostgreSQL + Pgvector for knowledge base
- Web search capability (DuckDuckGo)
- Persistent conversations

**Setup:**
```bash
cd awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/autonomous_rag
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Start PgVector database
docker run -d \
  -e POSTGRES_DB=ai \
  -e POSTGRES_USER=ai \
  -e POSTGRES_PASSWORD=ai \
  -p 5532:5432 \
  --name pgvector \
  phidata/pgvector:16

streamlit run autorag.py
```

[来源: awesome-llm-apps/autonomous_rag/README.md]

### Hybrid Search RAG
For better retrieval accuracy combining semantic and keyword matching:

**Features:**
- Hybrid search (semantic + keyword)
- Reranking for better context selection
- Multi-model integration (Claude + OpenAI + Cohere)

**Required API Keys:**
- OpenAI (embeddings)
- Anthropic (Claude for generation)
- Cohere (reranking)
- Neon PostgreSQL database

[来源: awesome-llm-apps/hybrid_search_rag/README.md]

All tutorials include complete step-by-step guides with code walkthroughs and best practices.")]

query: What is Vision RAG? How to do RAG with images?
answer:
## Vision RAG: Multimodal Retrieval-Augmented Generation

**Vision RAG** is a visual Retrieval-Augmented Generation system that extends traditional text-based RAG to work with images and visual content. It enables you to ask questions about images, diagrams, charts, and PDF pages using natural language.

### How It Works

Vision RAG follows a two-stage process:

**1. Retrieval Stage:**
- Images (or PDF pages) are converted to base64 strings
- A multimodal embedding model (like Cohere Embed-4) generates vector embeddings for each image
- When you ask a text question, it's embedded using the same model
- Cosine similarity finds the most relevant image for your query

**2. Generation Stage:**
- The retrieved image and your question are passed to a vision-capable LLM (like Google Gemini 2.5 Flash)
- The model analyzes the image content and generates a text answer based on what it sees

### Key Capabilities

- **No OCR Required**: Directly processes complex images and visual elements without separate text extraction
- **PDF Support**: Automatically extracts PDF pages as images for analysis
- **Multimodal Search**: Finds semantically relevant images based on text queries
- **Flexible Content**: Works with charts, diagrams, infographics, screenshots, and document pages

### Implementation Example

The knowledge base contains a complete Vision RAG implementation using:
- **Cohere Embed-4** (`embed-v4.0`) for multimodal embeddings
- **Google Gemini 2.5 Flash** for visual question answering
- **Streamlit** for the interactive UI

Setup steps:
```bash
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/vision_rag
pip install -r requirements.txt
streamlit run vision_rag.py
```

### Use Cases

- Analyze financial charts and extract key figures or trends
- Answer questions about diagrams, flowcharts, or infographics
- Extract information from tables or text within screenshots
- Build visual knowledge bases queryable with natural language
- Process multi-page reports and complex visual documents

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/vision_rag/README.md > Vision RAG with Cohere Embed-4 🖼️]

Use pre-loaded sample financial charts and infographics.\\\\n - Upload your own custom images (PNG, JPG, JPEG).\\\\n - **Upload PDF documents**: Automatically extracts pages as images for analysis.\\\\n- **No OCR Required**: Directly processes complex images and visual elements within PDF pages without needing separate text extraction steps.\\\\n- **Interactive UI**: Built with Streamlit for easy interaction, including content loading, question input, and result display.\\\\n- **Session Management**: Remembers loaded/uploaded content (images and processed PDF pages) within a session.\\\\n\\\\n- Python 3.8+\\\\n- Cohere API key\\\\n- Google Gemini API key\\\\n\\\\nFollow these steps to set up and run the application:\\\\n\\\\n1. **Clone and Navigate to Directory** :\\\\n ```bash\\\\n git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git\\\\n cd awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/vision_rag\\\\n ```\\\\n\\\\n2. **Install Dependencies**:\\\\n ```bash\\\\n pip install -r requirements.txt\\\\n ```\\\\n *(Ensure you have the latest `PyMuPDF` installed along with other requirements)*\\\\n\\\\n3. **Set up your API keys**:\\\\n - Get a Cohere API key from: [https://dashboard.cohere.com/api-keys](https://dashboard.cohere.com/api-keys)\\\\n - Get a Google API key from: [https://aistudio.google.com/app/apikey](https://aistudio.google.com/app/apikey)\\\\n\\\\n4. **Run the Streamlit app**:\\\\n ```bash\\\\n streamlit run vision_rag.py\\\\n ```\\\\n\\\\n5. **Access the Web Interface**:\\\\n - Cosine similarity is calculated between the question embedding and all image embeddings.\\\\n - The image with the highest similarity score (which could be a regular image or a specific PDF page image) is retrieved as the most relevant context.\\\\n\\\\n2. **Generation**:\\\\n - The original text question and the retrieved image/page image are passed as input to the Google `gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17` model.\\\\n - Gemini analyzes the image content in the context of the question and generates a textual answer.\\"\\n },\\n {\\n \\"score\\": -0.4054,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"5da5431f\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"5da5431f-002\\",\\n \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/vision_rag/README.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Vision RAG with Cohere Embed-4 🖼️\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"Vision RAG with Cohere Embed-4 🖼️ > Note\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"1. Enter your Cohere and Google API keys in the sidebar.\\\\n2. Load content:\\\\n - Click **\\\\\\"Load Sample Images\\\\\\"** to download and process the built-in examples.\\\\n - *OR/AND* Use the **\\\\\\"Upload Your Images or PDFs\\\\\\"** section to upload your own image or PDF files.\\\\n3. Once content is loaded and processed (embeddings generated), the **\\\\\\"Ask a Question\\\\\\"** section will be enabled.\\\\n4. View the results:\\\\n - The **Retrieved Image/Page** deemed most relevant to your question (caption indicates source PDF and page number if applicable).\\\\n - The **Generated Answer** from Gemini based on the image and question.\\\\n\\\\n- Analyze financial charts and extract key figures or trends.\\\\n- Answer specific questions about diagrams, flowcharts, or infographics within images or PDFs.\\\\n- Extract information from tables or text within screenshots or PDF pages without explicit OCR.\\\\n- Build and query visual knowledge bases (from images and PDFs) using natural language.\\\\n- Understand the content of various complex visual documents, including multi-page reports.\\\\n\\\\n- Image and PDF processing (page rendering + embedding) can take time, especially for many items or large files. [TextBlock(text="## Vision RAG: Multimodal Retrieval-Augmented Generation

**Vision RAG** is a visual Retrieval-Augmented Generation system that extends traditional text-based RAG to work with images and visual content. It enables you to ask questions about images, diagrams, charts, and PDF pages using natural language.

### How It Works

Vision RAG follows a two-stage process:

**1. Retrieval Stage:**
- Images (or PDF pages) are converted to base64 strings
- A multimodal embedding model (like Cohere Embed-4) generates vector embeddings for each image
- When you ask a text question, it's embedded using the same model
- Cosine similarity finds the most relevant image for your query

**2. Generation Stage:**
- The retrieved image and your question are passed to a vision-capable LLM (like Google Gemini 2.5 Flash)
- The model analyzes the image content and generates a text answer based on what it sees

### Key Capabilities

- **No OCR Required**: Directly processes complex images and visual elements without separate text extraction
- **PDF Support**: Automatically extracts PDF pages as images for analysis
- **Multimodal Search**: Finds semantically relevant images based on text queries
- **Flexible Content**: Works with charts, diagrams, infographics, screenshots, and document pages

### Implementation Example

The knowledge base contains a complete Vision RAG implementation using:
- **Cohere Embed-4** (`embed-v4.0`) for multimodal embeddings
- **Google Gemini 2.5 Flash** for visual question answering
- **Streamlit** for the interactive UI

Setup steps:
```bash
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/vision_rag
pip install -r requirements.txt
streamlit run vision_rag.py
```

### Use Cases

- Analyze financial charts and extract key figures or trends
- Answer questions about diagrams, flowcharts, or infographics
- Extract information from tables or text within screenshots
- Build visual knowledge bases queryable with natural language
- Process multi-page reports and complex visual documents

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/vision_rag/README.md > Vision RAG with Cohere Embed-4 🖼️]")]

## Vision RAG: Multimodal Retrieval-Augmented Generation

**Vision RAG** is a visual Retrieval-Augmented Generation system that extends traditional text-based RAG to work with images and visual content. It enables you to ask questions about images, diagrams, charts, and PDF pages using natural language.

### How It Works

Vision RAG follows a two-stage process:

**1. Retrieval Stage:**
- Images (or PDF pages) are converted to base64 strings
- A multimodal embedding model (like Cohere Embed-4) generates vector embeddings for each image
- When you ask a text question, it's embedded using the same model
- Cosine similarity finds the most relevant image for your query

**2. Generation Stage:**
- The retrieved image and your question are passed to a vision-capable LLM (like Google Gemini 2.5 Flash)
- The model analyzes the image content and generates a text answer based on what it sees

### Key Capabilities

- **No OCR Required**: Directly processes complex images and visual elements without separate text extraction
- **PDF Support**: Automatically extracts PDF pages as images for analysis
- **Multimodal Search**: Finds semantically relevant images based on text queries
- **Flexible Content**: Works with charts, diagrams, infographics, screenshots, and document pages

### Implementation Example

The knowledge base contains a complete Vision RAG implementation using:
- **Cohere Embed-4** (`embed-v4.0`) for multimodal embeddings
- **Google Gemini 2.5 Flash** for visual question answering
- **Streamlit** for the interactive UI

Setup steps:
```bash
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/vision_rag
pip install -r requirements.txt
streamlit run vision_rag.py
```

### Use Cases

- Analyze financial charts and extract key figures or trends
- Answer questions about diagrams, flowcharts, or infographics
- Extract information from tables or text within screenshots
- Build visual knowledge bases queryable with natural language
- Process multi-page reports and complex visual documents

query: How to build a RAG chain using LangChain?
answer:
Based on the knowledge base, here's how to build a RAG chain using LangChain:

## General Steps

1. **Set up a Vector Database**: Configure a vector store like Redis or Qdrant to handle vector data and embeddings.

2. **Use LangChain Integration**: LangChain provides built-in integrations with vector stores:
   - For Redis: Use [LangChain's Redis integration](https://python.langchain.com/v0.2/docs/integrations/vectorstores/redis/)
   - For Qdrant: LangChain supports Qdrant as a vector store

3. **Embed and Store Data**:
   - Convert your documents into vector embeddings using models like BERT, GPT, or Google's embedding-001
   - Use document loaders like `WebBaseLoader` to fetch content
   - Split documents using `RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter`
   - Store embeddings in your vector database

4. **Build the RAG Pipeline**:
   - Implement query logic to retrieve relevant vectors based on input prompts
   - Feed retrieved context into a generative model (GPT, Gemini, etc.)
   - The model uses the retrieved information to generate augmented responses

5. **Orchestration**: LangChain handles the orchestration of the retrieval-augmented generation process, ensuring relevant information is retrieved and presented.

## Example Implementation

The knowledge base shows a practical example using:
- **Document Processing**: LangChain's `WebBaseLoader` for loading content
- **Text Splitting**: `RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter` for chunking
- **Vector Store**: Qdrant for storing embeddings
- **Embeddings**: Google Gemini API (embedding-001)
- **LLM**: Google Gemini (gemini-2.0-flash)

## Advanced Patterns

For more sophisticated RAG systems, you can use **LangGraph** (built on LangChain) to implement:
- Agentic query processing
- Relevance assessment
- Query refinement
- Graph-based workflows for decision-making

The system automatically routes the query to the most relevant database using a agno agent as the router.\\\\n\\\\n- **RAG Orchestration**: Utilizes Langchain for orchestrating the retrieval augmented generation process, ensuring that the most relevant information is retrieved and presented to the user.\\\\n\\\\n- **Fallback Mechanism**: If no relevant documents are found in the databases, a LangGraph agent with a DuckDuckGo search tool is used to perform web research and provide an answer.\\\\n\\\\n1. **Clone the Repository**:\\\\n   ```bash\\\\n   git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git\\\\n   cd rag_tutorials/rag_database_routing\\\\n   ```\\\\n\\\\n2. **Install Dependencies**:\\\\n   ```bash\\\\n   pip install -r requirements.txt\\\\n   ```\\\\n\\\\n3. **Run the Application**:\\\\n   ```bash\\\\n   streamlit run rag_database_routing.py\\\\n   ```\\\\n\\\\n4. **Get OpenAI API Key**: Obtain an OpenAI API key and set it in the application. This is required for initializing the language models used in the application.\\\\n\\\\n5. **Setup Qdrant Cloud** \\\\n- Visit [Qdrant Cloud](https://cloud.qdrant.io/)\\\\n- Create an account or sign in\\\\n- Create a new cluster\\\\n- Get your credentials:\\\\n   - Qdrant API Key: Found in API Keys section\\\\n   - Qdrant URL: Your cluster URL (format: https://xxx-xxx.aws.cloud.qdrant.io)\\\\n\\\\n5. **Upload Documents**: Use the document upload section to add PDF documents to the desired database.\\\\n\\\\n6. **Ask Questions**: Enter your questions in the query section. The application will route your question to the appropriate database and provide an answer.\\\\n\\\\n- **Langchain**: For RAG orchestration, ensuring efficient retrieval and generation of information.\\\\n- **Agno Agent**: Used as the router agent to determine the most relevant database for a given query.\\\\n- **LangGraph Agent**: Acts as a fallback mechanism, utilizing DuckDuckGo for web research when necessary.\\\\n- **Streamlit**: Provides a user-friendly interface for document upload and querying.\\\\n- **Qdrant**: Used for managing the databases, storing and retrieving document embeddings efficiently.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text="Based on the knowledge base, here's how to build a RAG chain using LangChain:

## General Steps

1. **Set up a Vector Database**: Configure a vector store like Redis or Qdrant to handle vector data and embeddings.

2. **Use LangChain Integration**: LangChain provides built-in integrations with vector stores:
   - For Redis: Use [LangChain's Redis integration](https://python.langchain.com/v0.2/docs/integrations/vectorstores/redis/)
   - For Qdrant: LangChain supports Qdrant as a vector store

3. **Embed and Store Data**:
   - Convert your documents into vector embeddings using models like BERT, GPT, or Google's embedding-001
   - Use document loaders like `WebBaseLoader` to fetch content
   - Split documents using `RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter`
   - Store embeddings in your vector database

4. **Build the RAG Pipeline**:
   - Implement query logic to retrieve relevant vectors based on input prompts
   - Feed retrieved context into a generative model (GPT, Gemini, etc.)
   - The model uses the retrieved information to generate augmented responses

5. **Orchestration**: LangChain handles the orchestration of the retrieval-augmented generation process, ensuring relevant information is retrieved and presented.

## Example Implementation

The knowledge base shows a practical example using:
- **Document Processing**: LangChain's `WebBaseLoader` for loading content
- **Text Splitting**: `RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter` for chunking
- **Vector Store**: Qdrant for storing embeddings
- **Embeddings**: Google Gemini API (embedding-001)
- **LLM**: Google Gemini (gemini-2.0-flash)

## Advanced Patterns

For more sophisticated RAG systems, you can use **LangGraph** (built on LangChain) to implement:
- Agentic query processing
- Relevance assessment
- Query refinement
- Graph-based workflows for decision-making

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/ai_blog_search/README.md > Agentic RAG with LangGraph: AI Blog Search]")]

query: How to chat with YouTube videos using RAG?
answer:
Based on the knowledge base, here's how to build a chat application for YouTube videos using RAG:

## Overview

The application uses **Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG)** to enable chatting with YouTube video content. It leverages OpenAI's GPT-4o, mem0/embedchain for memory, and the youtube-transcript-api to extract and process video transcripts.

## Key Features

- Input a YouTube video URL
- Ask questions about the video content
- Get accurate answers based on the actual video transcript using RAG

## Setup Steps

1. **Clone the repository**
```bash
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_youtube_videos
```

2. **Install dependencies**
```bash
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

3. **Get OpenAI API Key**
   - Sign up for an [OpenAI account](https://platform.openai.com/)
   - Obtain your API key

4. **Run the application**
```bash
streamlit run chat_youtube.py
```

## Technical Implementation

The app uses:
- **youtube-transcript-api** (v1.2.3) to fetch video transcripts
- **RAG pipeline** to index and retrieve relevant content from transcripts
- **mem0/embedchain** for maintaining conversation memory
- **OpenAI GPT-4o** for generating responses
- **Streamlit** for the user interface

## Important Notes

- The app includes robust error handling with clear, actionable error messages
- Pre-tested example URLs are provided for immediate testing
- Progress feedback shows what's happening during video processing
- Comprehensive test coverage ensures reliability

For a complete step-by-step tutorial with detailed code walkthroughs and best practices, check out the [full tutorial](https://www.theunwindai.com/p/build-an-llm-app-with-rag-to-chat-with-youtube-videos).

query: How to build a RAG app with Cohere Command R?
answer:
Found relevant documentation! Here's how to build a RAG app with Cohere Command R:

## Overview

The knowledge base contains a complete RAG Agentic system built with Cohere's Command-r7b-12-2024 model. This application allows users to upload documents, ask questions about them, and get AI-powered responses with automatic fallback to web search when needed.

## Key Components

**Models Used:**
- **Command-r7b-12-2024** for chat and RAG
- **cohere embed-english-v3.0** for embeddings

**Tech Stack:**
- **Qdrant** for vector storage
- **LangChain** for RAG implementation
- **LangGraph** for orchestration (using `create_react_agent` function)
- **DuckDuckGo** for web search fallback

## Features

1. **Document Processing**
   - PDF document upload and processing
   - Automatic text chunking and embedding
   - Vector storage in Qdrant cloud

2. **Intelligent Querying**
   - RAG-based document retrieval
   - Similarity search with threshold filtering
   - Automatic fallback to web search when no relevant documents found
   - Source attribution for answers

3. **Advanced Capabilities**
   - DuckDuckGo web search integration
   - LangGraph agent for web research
   - Context-aware response generation
   - Long answer summarization

## How to Run

```bash
# 1. Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd rag_tutorials/rag_agent_cohere

# 2. Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

# 3. Run the application
streamlit run rag_agent_cohere.py
```

[TextBlock(text="Found relevant documentation! Here's how to build a RAG app with Cohere Command R:

## Overview

The knowledge base contains a complete RAG Agentic system built with Cohere's Command-r7b-12-2024 model. This application allows users to upload documents, ask questions about them, and get AI-powered responses with automatic fallback to web search when needed.

## Key Components

**Models Used:**
- **Command-r7b-12-2024** for chat and RAG
- **cohere embed-english-v3.0** for embeddings

**Tech Stack:**
- **Qdrant** for vector storage
- **LangChain** for RAG implementation
- **LangGraph** for orchestration (using `create_react_agent` function)
- **DuckDuckGo** for web search fallback

## Features

1. **Document Processing**
   - PDF document upload and processing
   - Automatic text chunking and embedding
   - Vector storage in Qdrant cloud

2. **Intelligent Querying**
   - RAG-based document retrieval
   - Similarity search with threshold filtering
   - Automatic fallback to web search when no relevant documents found
   - Source attribution for answers

3. **Advanced Capabilities**
   - DuckDuckGo web search integration
   - LangGraph agent for web research
   - Context-aware response generation
   - Long answer summarization

## How to Run

```bash
# 1. Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd rag_tutorials/rag_agent_cohere

# 2. Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

# 3. Run the application
streamlit run rag_agent_cohere.py
```

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/rag_agent_cohere/README.md > RAG Agent with Cohere ⌘R]")]

query: Can I chat with my Gmail inbox using an LLM?
answer:
Yes! You can chat with your Gmail inbox using an LLM. There's a ready-to-use application that implements this using Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG).

**What it does:**
- Connects to your Gmail inbox
- Lets you ask questions about the content of your emails
- Provides accurate answers using RAG and LLMs (like OpenAI's GPT)

**How to set it up:**

1. Clone the repository and navigate to the chat with Gmail directory
2. Install dependencies (`pip install -r requirements.txt`)
3. Set up Google Cloud project:
   - Create a project in Google Cloud Console
   - Configure OAuth consent screen and publish it
   - Enable the Gmail API
   - Create OAuth client ID credentials
   - Download credentials as `credentials.json`
4. Get your OpenAI API key (or use another LLM provider)
5. Run the Streamlit app: `streamlit run chat_gmail.py`

The app is built in just 30 lines of Python code and uses RAG to provide accurate answers based on your actual email content.

query: How to build a chat app for research papers?
answer:
Based on the knowledge base, here's how to build a chat app for research papers:

## Overview

The knowledge base contains a complete tutorial for building a chat application that interacts with arXiv research papers using RAG (Retrieval Augmented Generation).

## Implementation Steps

**1. Clone the repository**
```bash
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_research_papers
```

**2. Install dependencies**
```bash
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

**3. Set up OpenAI API**
- Sign up for an [OpenAI account](https://platform.openai.com/)
- Obtain your API key

**4. Run the application**
```bash
streamlit run chat_arxiv.py
```

## Key Features

- **Conversational interface** with arXiv research papers
- **Access vast collection** of academic papers
- **Intelligent responses** powered by OpenAI GPT-4o
- **Search and explore** research papers interactively

## Advanced Version with Memory

There's also an enhanced version that includes persistent memory of user interests:

- Uses **GPT-4o-mini** for processing
- **Mem0 + Qdrant** for maintaining user context and past interactions
- Remembers user interests across sessions
- Requires Qdrant running on localhost:6333

```bash
docker pull qdrant/qdrant
docker run -p 6333:6333 -p 6334:6334 \
    -v $(pwd)/qdrant_storage:/qdrant/storage:z \
    qdrant/qdrant
```

[来源: awesome-llm-apps/advanced_llm_apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_research_papers/README.md > 🔎 Chat with Arxiv Research Papers > How to get Started?]

[TextBlock(text="Based on the knowledge base, here's how to build a chat app for research papers:

## Overview

The knowledge base contains a complete tutorial for building a chat application that interacts with arXiv research papers using RAG (Retrieval Augmented Generation).

## Implementation Steps

**1. Clone the repository**
```bash
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_research_papers
```

**2. Install dependencies**
```bash
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

**3. Set up OpenAI API**
- Sign up for an [OpenAI account](https://platform.openai.com/)
- Obtain your API key

**4. Run the application**
```bash
streamlit run chat_arxiv.py
```

## Key Features

- **Conversational interface** with arXiv research papers
- **Access vast collection** of academic papers
- **Intelligent responses** powered by OpenAI GPT-4o
- **Search and explore** research papers interactively

## Advanced Version with Memory

There's also an enhanced version that includes persistent memory of user interests:

- Uses **GPT-4o-mini** for processing
- **Mem0 + Qdrant** for maintaining user context and past interactions
- Remembers user interests across sessions
- Requires Qdrant running on localhost:6333

```bash
docker pull qdrant/qdrant
docker run -p 6333:6333 -p 6334:6334 \
    -v $(pwd)/qdrant_storage:/qdrant/storage:z \
    qdrant/qdrant
```

[来源: awesome-llm-apps/advanced_llm_apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_research_papers/README.md > 🔎 Chat with Arxiv Research Papers > How to get Started?]")]

Based on the knowledge base, here's how to build a chat app for research papers:

## Overview

The knowledge base contains a complete tutorial for building a chat application that interacts with arXiv research papers using RAG (Retrieval Augmented Generation).

## Implementation Steps

**1. Clone the repository**
```bash
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_research_papers
```

**2. Install dependencies**
```bash
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

**3. Set up OpenAI API**
- Sign up for an [OpenAI account](https://platform.openai.com/)
- Obtain your API key

**4. Run the application**
```bash
streamlit run chat_arxiv.py
```

## Key Features

- **Conversational interface** with arXiv research papers
- **Access vast collection** of academic papers
- **Intelligent responses** powered by OpenAI GPT-4o
- **Search and explore** research papers interactively

## Advanced Version with Memory

There's also an enhanced version that includes persistent memory of user interests:

- Uses **GPT-4o-mini** for processing
- **Mem0 + Qdrant** for maintaining user context and past interactions
- Remembers user interests across sessions
- Requires Qdrant running on localhost:6333

```bash
docker pull qdrant/qdrant
docker run -p 6333:6333 -p 6334:6334 \
    -v $(pwd)/qdrant_storage:/qdrant/storage:z \
    qdrant/qdrant
```

[来源: awesome-llm-apps/advanced_llm_apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_research_papers/README.md > 🔎 Chat with Arxiv Research Papers > How to get Started?]

query: How to chat with a GitHub repository using RAG?
answer:
Based on the knowledge base, here's how to chat with a GitHub repository using RAG:

## Overview

You can build an LLM app with RAG to chat with GitHub repositories in just 30 lines of Python code. The app uses Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) to provide accurate answers to questions based on the content of the specified GitHub repository.

## Getting Started

1. **Clone the repository**
   ```bash
   git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
   cd awesome-llm-apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_github
   ```

2. **Install dependencies**
   ```bash
   pip install -r requirements.txt
   ```

3. **Get your OpenAI API Key**
   - Sign up for an [OpenAI account](https://platform.openai.com/) (or the LLM provider of your choice) and obtain your API key

4. **Run the application**
   ```bash
   streamlit run chat_github.py
   ```

## How It Works

The app uses RAG to:
- Retrieve relevant content from the GitHub repository
- Generate accurate answers based on the repository's content
- Allow you to ask questions about code, documentation, and other repository contents

[来源: awesome-llm-apps/advanced_llm_apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_github/README.md > 💬 Chat with GitHub Repo]

Based on the knowledge base, here's how to chat with a GitHub repository using RAG:

## Overview

You can build an LLM app with RAG to chat with GitHub repositories in just 30 lines of Python code. The app uses Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) to provide accurate answers to questions based on the content of the specified GitHub repository.

## Getting Started

1. **Clone the repository**
   ```bash
   git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
   cd awesome-llm-apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_github
   ```

2. **Install dependencies**
   ```bash
   pip install -r requirements.txt
   ```

3. **Get your OpenAI API Key**
   - Sign up for an [OpenAI account](https://platform.openai.com/) (or the LLM provider of your choice) and obtain your API key

4. **Run the application**
   ```bash
   streamlit run chat_github.py
   ```

## How It Works

The app uses RAG to:
- Retrieve relevant content from the GitHub repository
- Generate accurate answers based on the repository's content
- Allow you to ask questions about code, documentation, and other repository contents
